text:
An art song is a genre of Western solo vocal literature in which the voice part, the instrumental accompaniment, and the poetic verses are interwoven to achieve a musically artistic whole.It requires advanced vocal training and musical maturity for its performance, usually on the concert stage.An ordered group of art songs forming a musical entity is called a song cycle.The text is often a set of related poems by a single poet.

The country’s 333-year cultural contact with Spain led to the development of twofolksongstyles predominant at the turn of the century.The first was exemplified in thepasyon,matrimonyo,kaluluwa, andhuluna, all sung in a chant-like manner; the second, in theharana,balitaw,dalit,composo, kundiman, sung in duple or triple meter, in major or minor tonalities and simple harmonic accompaniment on thepiano orrondalla (ensemble of stringed instruments). The second type, especially the folk kundiman, lent itself to the development of the song as personal and artistic self-expression since it has been used traditionally to ventilate emotions.

The expressive folk kundiman was exemplified by the turn-of-the-century “May Dusa Pa Yata” (Misery Still Pervades), cited byAntonioJ.Molina as a young man’s vehicle for expressing his affections for a young maiden in the context of apantapat or harana (serenade).The lyrics consisted of two four-line stanzas, each line with 12 syllables ending in assonance. The music, in triple meter and in a major tonality, consisting of two 16-bar periods corresponding to the stanzas, was in binary form. A note that was longer in duration than others within a phrase unit or agogic accent, or a note followed by a rest or silence, occured with each 6th and 12th syllable of a line.This melodic trait reflected a characteristic of Philippine dodecasyllabic lines as found in Balagtas’sFloranteatLaura(Florante and Laura), wherein a caesura invariably occured after the 6th syllable.Similarly constructed were the lyrics of the folk songs “Kundiman de 1800” (Love Song of 1800) and “Kundiman de 1870: Paalam sa Pagkadalaga” (Love Song of 1870: Farewell to Maidenhood).Like most folksongs, the authorship is unknown and different verses may be set for these songs.

The kundiman as a composed vocal genre expressing intense love for a beloved as well as patriotic fervor emerged in Leon Ignacio’s “Ang Aking Bulaklak” (My Flower), Jose Silos’s “Mutya ng Silangan” (Muse of the East), Paulino Cadsawan’s “Kundiman ni Rizal” (Rizal’s Kundiman), Francisco Buencamino’s “Simoy na Dalisay” (Pure Breeze), and Bonifacio Abdon’s “Kundiman,” among others. In most of these works, the melodic and textual conventions of the folk kundiman were retained but accompaniment on the piano was specified. Moreover, the simple binary structure of two 16-bar periods (AB) was expanded.

Reaching artistic heights in the creative genius ofNicanorS.Abelardoand FranciscoSantiago, the kundiman became a veritable art song written in the chromatic harmonic language of European romanticists.Melody, text, and harmony were intertwined to musically conveythe meaning of theTagalog text in Abelardo’s “NasaanKaIrog?”(Where Are You, My Love?),“MutyangPasig”(Muse of Pasig),“KundimanngLuha”(Love Song of Tears), “Magbalik Ka Hirang” (Come Back My Love), “Himutok” (Outcry), and “Pahimakas” (Last Farewell); and in Santiago’s “Kundiman” (Love Song), “Pakiusap”(Plea) and “Madaling-Araw” (Dawn). The American musicologist Conway Walker referred to the art song kundiman as “graphic miniature music-dramas, small, yet susceptible of expression at will, flexible as no other medium of emotional expression devised by man … with the directness and exactness of an etching, and all-inclusive in its possibilities of emotional portraiture.”

After Abelardo and Santiago, Philippine art song literature continued to grow.Composers who wrote in the vernacular and who were influenced by the art song kundimanincludeFelipePadilla deLeon with his “Ako’y Pilipino” (I Am a Filipino), “Ganyan ang Pagsinta” (That Is Love), and “Dasal ng Pag-ibig” (Prayer of Love); Antonio J. Molina with his “Amihan” (Cool Northeast Wind) and “Kundiman-Kundangan” (Love Song–If Not For); Antonino Buenaventura with his “Ako’y Nangangarap” (I’m Dreaming); Lucio D. San Pedro with his “Diwata ng Pag-ibig” (Goddess of Love), “Sa Ugoy ng Duyan” (In the Cradle’s Rocking), “Sa Mahal Kong Bayan” (In My Beloved Country), and “Sa Simula Ako’y Isang Labong” (In the Beginning I Was a Bamboo Shoot);RosendoSantos with his “Kundiman ng Puso” (Love Song of the Heart);AngelM.Peña with his “Iyo Kailan Pa Man” (Yours Forever); LucinoT.Sacramento with his “Gamugamu” (Moth);ErnaniCuenco with his “Kundiman ’86” and “Gaano Ko Ikaw Kamahal?” (How Much Do I Love You?); Rodolfo S. Cornejo with his “Kalualhatian” (Glory) and “Silahis ng Pag-asa” (Ray of Hope); and Augusto Espino with his “Kundiman ng Langit” (Love Song of Heaven). It is to be noted that 54 art songs, including many of the above, were collected in An Album of Philippine Art Songs published by the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines. In 1996, Antonina E. Siapuatco published the collection The Art Songs of Lucio San Pedro.

Providing the impetus for more contributions to the repertory were theLeagueof Filipino Composers(LFC) and theNationalMusic CompetitionsforYoungArtists (NAMCYA), which conducted competitions in art song composition and commissioned solo vocal contest pieces, respectively.The LFC’s first-prize winner for 1979 was Toti Alvarez’s “Ito ang Iyong Bayan” (This Is Your Country), and in 1990, Von de Guzman’s “Gutiay Pa Ako” (I Was Still Young). The NAMCYA pieces include Lucio D. San Pedro’s “Bayan Ko, Isang Pangarap” (My Country, One Dream), Jerry A. Dadap’s “Kung Hindi Magbukang-liwayway” (If Dawn Never Comes), Manuel P. Maramba’s “Anak Ko, Magpakababa Ka” (My Child, Be Humble), and Francisco F. Feliciano’s “Paalam ni Elias kay Salomeng Irog” (Elias’s Farewell to Beloved Salome).To this list could be added “Kudyapi ng Lahi” (Boat-Lute of the Race) for soprano and string quartet, and “Tagulaylay” (Mourning Song) for baritone and prepared piano.

Art songs with English text include Eliseo M. Pajaro’s “Etude in Blue” and “Etude in Green”; Hilarion F. Rubio’s “Light … a Tenor’s Soliloquy”; Ramon Tapales’s “Carnations” and “Grace for Grace”; Lucrecia R. Kasilag’s “Requiem,” “Renunciation,” and “You Shall Be Free”; and Amada Santos-Ocampo’s “Gloom Casts a Candle.”A number of song cycles had also been written: Ramon P. Santos’sThree Songs of Faith; Lucrecia R. Kasilag’sLove Songs,Three Love Sonnets andA Cycle of Philippine Songs; Eliseo M. Pajaro’s Himig Iloko no. 1 and no. 2 (Iloko Melodies); Jerry A. Dadap’s Song Cycles nos. 1, 2, 3, and 4; Felipe P. de Leon’s Muntawit (Small Song); Rodolfo S. Cornejo’sThe SeasonsandBeneath This Heart of Clay; Eduardo Parungao’sThe Room of Life,Tatlong Yugto(Three Episodes), andIba’t Ibang Kulay ang Buhay (Life Has Many Colors); Angel M. Peña’sNgunit(But); Michael Dadap’sMga Awit ng Pag-ibig at Pangarap (Songs of Love and Dreams); Noni Espina’sMga Awit sa Magdiwata (Songs of the Animist); and Ryan Cayabyab’sOur Poem.

Today, the body of Philippine art song literature consists of the art song kundiman and other songs bearing its influence; songs in English and in the vernacular following Western vocal forms such as the aria, soliloquy, lullaby; prize-winning art songs in competitions
sponsored by the LFC; contest pieces for solo voice commissioned by the NAMCYA; and song cycles. The musical styles range from the romantic to the modern.Noted Filipino poets, such as Deogracias A. del Rosario, JoseCorazondeJesus, FlorentinoBallecer, AlejandroAbadilla, Nina Estrada, Trinidad Tarrosa Subido, Levi Celerio, Marra PL. Lanot, DomingoLandicho, and RolandoTinio, have written the texts.Written by Mauricia D. Borromeo

text:
The ballad is a narrative song usually performed by a solo singer who gives an account of an event that happens in a community. In the urban setting, the term ballad is loosely applied to any popular song with romantic elements, and a singer who performs mainly a repertoire of love songs in nightclubs and music lounges is called balladeer.

Philippine traditional ballads differ in musical style from one group to another. Those in the ethnic musical style are found among groups that have not been completely Westernized. Ballads from indigenous groups include the Bukidnon idangdang, the Mansaka saliada, and the Tausug liyangkit parang sabil. Those in the lowland Spanish-influenced style are the Cuyunon and Hiligaynon composo, and the Pampango “Ing Bangkeru” (The Boatman). Some ballads have instrumental accompaniment, like the composo, which is usually heard with a guitar, and the liyangkit parang sabil with the gabbang (bamboo xylophone).

The indigenous narrative liyangkit parang sabil is sung by a professional singer. Limited range and movement characterize melodies. Texts are rendered syllabically on a reciting tone.

Some ballads use existing melodies from folk songs of the region, like the Pampango “Ing Bangkeru,” which is sung to the tune of the locals’ popular folk song “Atin Cu Pung Singsing” (I Have a Ring). In the Visayas, the composo is sung to stock melodies generally in triple or quadruple, such as the Hiligaynon composo “Montor,” which is in triple meter with an AABC form. While the Cuyunon composo may be rendered solo during fiesta celebrations, it is often performed in chorus with the sayaw (dance) by a group of teenagers accompanied by a string ensemble called de kwerdas. A Cuyunon composo titled “Composo de Capiz” is strophic with four musical phrases of ABCD in quadruple meter. “Magellan,” a contemporary ballad by pop artist Yoyoy Villame, inserts stock formulaic verses, particularly the children’s verse “Mother, mother, I am sick.”Written by Felicidad A. Prudente

Sources:

Abraham and Foss 1968; Apel 1974; Eugenio 1982; Magaña 1975; Opeña and Suarez 1975; Prudente 1977; Trimillos 1965.

text:
The balse (waltz), from the Spanish word valse, is a dance in triple time, which became the most popular dance of the 19th century. It is considered one of the most enduring dance forms, having been adopted locally in the Philippines as music in traditional music theater like the sarsuwela or in modern musicals, and as independent instrumental compositions by many composers of the 19th and 20th centuries.

The music usually consists of two sections played continuously. Dancers may change partners between repetitions. In the country, the balse gained popularity toward the mid-19th century. A British writer observing the country in the 1840s praised the native women’s skills in waltzing.

The balse was used by many composers since then, among them JoseEstella and Julio Nakpil, who composed sectional waltzes called tanda de valses. Estella’s most famous waltz song was “AngMaya” (The Sparrow), which was for Severino Reyes’s sarsuwela titled Filipinas para los Filipinos (The Philippines for the Filipinos). LeonIgnacio also created “Sa Liwanag ng Buwan” (By the Moonlight) and NicanorS.Abelardo composed “Paraluman” (Muse) with lyrics by Mariano Abelardo Velayo. Other waltzes were meant to be listened to such as Francisco Buencamino’s “Gratitud” for piano, Antonio J. Molina’s “Roxas Grand Waltz” for orchestra, and Lucrecia R. Kasilag’s “Valse Tendresse” (Tender Waltz). Constancio de Guzman wrote “Halina Giliw sa Langit” (Come to Heaven, Darling) for the movie Takip-silim (Twilight), and Santiago Suarez wrote “Pista sa Nayon” (Barrio Fiesta), with lyrics by LeviCelerio.

As traditional folk dance music, the balse is still being practiced in Luzon, particularly in Marikina, where it is performed after a religious procession called lutrina. The genre is also still heard in the arakyo, which is a komedya in the town of Peñaranda, Nueva Ecija.Written by Jeanna B. Malabuyoc Updated by James C. Diaz

text:
The abundant year-round supply of the different species of bamboo and its inexpensiveness are reasons why Filipinos have found a variety of ways of using bamboo for construction, cooking, medicine, textile, paper, and music. As many as the number of different linguistic groups in the Philippines is the diversity of music instruments that the Filipinos have made out of the plant, and these instruments differ in terms of timbre (tone quality), name, manner by which sounds are generated from them, and significance in the lives of Filipinos.

Indigenous Philippine bamboo instruments existed long before the Spaniards came to the Philippines. Bamboo music was heard during rituals, feasts, courtship scenes, work, and recreation. Bamboo music instruments can be classified into aerophones, idiophones, and chordophones.

Instruments that produce sounds when blown are called aerophones. Bamboo aerophones include various types of flutes, panpipes, and reed pipes, the most numerous found throughout the country being the paldong or palendag (vertical end-blown flute). The tongali (nose flute) is widespread in northern Philippines, but few are found in southern Philippines. It is played mostly by men and is used for serenading and courting, for quiet moments of relaxation, or for funerals. Flutes of Northern Luzon are tuned in pentatonic scales with or without semitones. The saggeypo, a type of stopped pipes, are aerophones found in the northern Kalinga. Used for entertainment by youth and adults, the saggeypo is also played while walking along mountain trails and may be played individually or as an ensemble. Meanwhile, the diwdiw-as (set of panpipes) found in Northern Philippines consists of open pipes that are tied together.

Idiophones produce sound when struck with an implement or with the hand. The source of vibration is the instrument itself. Bamboo idiophones in the Philippines are the xylophone, quill-shaped tubes, stamping tubes, scrapers, buzzers, clappers, and mouth harps. Bamboo tubes can be struck against each other, struck by sticks or mallets, stamped against hard objects, or shaken. The half-cut bamboo tongues in mouth harps (also called jew’s harps) are plucked. The mouth harp is found all over the Philippines and called by various names such as kulibao, ulibao, aribao, and kubing. Thebunkaka (buzzers), tongatong (stamping tubes), and patang-ug (quill-shaped tubes) are prevalent among the Cordillera highlanders who use them for rites, celebrations, and entertainment. The patatag, a set of xylophone blades or staves, is used by the Kalinga children to learn the rhythmic patterns of the gangsa (gongs). The bamboo xylophone found in southern Philippines is called gabbang and kwintangan. The bamboo tubes with notches etched on the tube, which can only be found in southern Philippines, are called tagutok and kagul.

Chordophones are instruments that generate sound through the vibration of strings, either by plucking, striking, or bowing. A zither is an instrument with strings that run parallel to the length of its body. The body serves as asound box or resonator. The zither has noneck, and the number of its strings varies. Zithers are found in northern Luzon, Mindanao, and Palawan. A common type is a bamboo tube whose strips are detached from its body but remain attached at both ends, with small bridges being inserted between the strips and the body. They are of two types: polychordal zithers with several strings that run around the tube and parallel-stringed zithers that usually have two strings on one side of the tube. Polychordal zithers are found in the Cordilleras, Mindanao, and Palawan, and are commonly called kudlung or kolitong. These are used for expressing human sentiments, for self-entertainment, for courtship, and for festive occasions as dance accompaniment.

The parallel-stringed tube zither has two to four strings that are plucked with the fingers or struck with small bamboo sticks. Boys and men play them for entertainment, with rhythms patterned after those played on the gongs. The bamboo half-tube zither among the Ifugao is called ayudding, and the paired string zither with slight variations found in northern and southern Philippines are called pas­ing, banban, tambi, kudlong, or takumbo.

Aside from its use in indigenous cultures, bamboo is also used to play Western music, as in the bamboo organ in Las Piñas, the musikong bumbong (bamboo wind instruments), the angklung (Indonesian bamboo ensemble), and other diatonically tuned instruments.

The bamboo organ atSaint Joseph Parish Church in Las Piñas is considered a National Cultural Treasure. The instrument is the oldest bamboo pipe organ in the world. Fray Diego Cera de la Virgen del Carmen (1762-1834), a Spanish missionary, started to build the bamboo organ in 1816 with the help of the people of Las Piñas. Cera allegedly buried the bamboos that he used as organ pipes under the sand by the seashore for a year in order to wash out traces of sugar and starch in the wood and thus create tough, mature pipes. The organ was first heard in 1821 but without the horizontal trumpets. Cera completed the work in 1824 after deciding to use metal for the horizontal trumpets whose character of sound he could not get with bamboo resonators. For the general structure, native Philippine wood species, such as narra, molave, and kamagong, were used.

The bamboo organ measures 5.17 m tall, 4.11 m wide, and 1.45 m deep. Hans Gerd Klais, who restored the organ in the mid-1970s, noted that the instrument contains a total of 1,031 pipes, of which 902 are of bamboo and 129 pipes are of metal. The pitch of each pipe is determined by its length. The organ has two unpitched accessory stops: the pajaritos and the tanbor, which produce the coloristic sounds of birds and the rumble of kettledrums, respectively. The Las Piñas Bamboo Organ is based on a typical Spanish baroque model, following the organ construction style of the era in which Cera lived. In 1978, the Bamboo Organ Foundation, a nonstock and nonprofit organization, was founded for the purpose of preserving the instrument. Since the bamboo organ’s return to the Philippines after its restoration in Germany in 1973-75, annual concerts have been held at the Parish of Saint Joseph. The Diego Cera Organ Builders Inc, the first Filipino pipe organ building company, is specifically responsible for the maintenance and preservation of the bamboo organ.

The musikong bumbong is an ensemble of bamboo instruments that are reproductions of European band instruments. It flourished in the villages during the Philippine revolutionary period in the last quarter of the 19th century. The sound of each instrument, like the trumpet, trombone, horn, oboe, clarinet, saxophone, and sousaphone, is different from its original model because the instruments rely on the voice of the performers to produce the sounds. An instrument is open at both ends and has a hole on the side covered with a membrane, which produces a buzzing sound when the player hums rather than blowsintothe mouthpiece. Because it is not the instrument that produces the sound per se but the voice of the player, the band of such instruments is called banda de voca, which is literally “band of the mouth.” The air pressure produced by the hum makes the membrane vibrate and the resulting sound varies in pitch and loudness with the player’s humming. The shape of the instrument helps amplify and project the sound.

The musikong bumbong proliferated in the villages, some organized by the Katipunero (Filipino revolutionaries) who fought against Spain in 1896-98. These Katipunero used their musical talents to entertain their comrades, enlivening their unit’s activities by playing patriotic songs. Gathering as musicians and playing music also served to mask their secret meetings, according to accounts of their descendants who are at present members of musikong bumbong. Organized along the lines of the marching band, these all-bamboo ensembles were attempts by 19th-century Filipino nationalists and revolutionaries to create a uniquely Filipino sound. Through the years, the instrumentation of the musikong bumbong has evolved from the banda de voca to the inclusion of sound-producing bamboo instruments like the bamboo flute, bumbong (bamboo tube which at first looked like a sousaphone, but whose shape later on returned to straight bamboo tubes), clarinet, saxophone, trumpet, and trompas (French horn that sounded like the bumbong). This was the case with Malabon Musikong Bumbong. For the Obando Musikong Bumbong or Banda Santa Clara Musikong Bumbong, instrumentation has not changed much since its establishment. The group simply added sound-producing instruments like the harmonica, bamban (alto saxophone), cymbals, snare, and bass drums.

A possible offshoot of the musikong bumbong are the various bamboo ensembles that were organized during the late 1950s, which employed bamboo instruments tuned diatonically like the bumbong, talungating (bamboo marimba), tulali (bamboo flute), tipangklung (bamboo piano), and angklung. An idiophone, the angklung is an indigenous bamboo instrument popular in Java, Indonesia. It was copied in the Philippines also in the late 1950s when replicas were made by bamboo instrument maker Victor Toledo, who included it, among other bamboo instruments that he made, in the ensemble he founded called the Pangkat Kawayan or the “singing bamboos” of the Philippines. Other manufacturers followed suit. Also called alugtug or tugtug na paalog (played by shaking), angklung is played in groups, with each person playing an instrument traditionally in an interlocking or staccato manner. The angklung and the other diatonically tuned instruments, like the marimba, bumbong, talungating, tulali, tipangklung, angklung, mini tipangklung, lira gabbang, panpipes, chordal angklung, kalagong, kalatok, and kalavien, have been used in a variety of combinations by various bamboo ensembles all over the Philippines and in other countries as well, with repertoire varying from folk song, spiritual, modern to classical music for diverse occasions. Other manufacturers of bamboo instruments are Gilbert M. Ramos of Obando Musikong Bumbong (now called Musikawayan) and Siegfredo B. Calabig of PUP Banda Kawayan (now called Banda Kawayan Pilipinas). The angklung is used in schools, universities, and the communities because the material is abundant and cheap. It is easily played by all ages and can be performed in any setting because of its interesting and beautiful sound. It may also be included in bamboo ensembles and other ensembles, like the rondalla (stringed instrument ensemble), and the orchestra. All these are factors for angklung’s wide acceptance and popularity in the Philippines.Written by Pacita Narzo

text:
Chamber music is instrumental music for a small ensemble in which one performer plays each part. This differentiates it from orchestral music where several players are assigned to one part. Generally, the number of parts is between three to eight, thus there are trios, quartets, sextets, septets, and octets. The instrumentation of these ensembles varies. Sometimes the ensemble is made up of one category of instruments, such as a string quartet (four strings) or a wind quintet (five winds). The instrumentation may be mixed, the most common combination being a piano trio (piano, violin, and cello). Chamber music places emphasis on the ensemble and not on the individual players, thus differing it from sonatas for one instrument and piano.

In the Philippines, early chamber compositions were represented in the works of the first generation of composers who received training abroad. Francisco Santiago, the first University of the Philippines (UP) fellow sent to the American Conservatory of Music in Chicago, presented his String Quartet in G as his graduation thesis for his master of music degree in 1924. Previous to this, his Remembrance for violin, cello, and piano, written in 1922, won third prize at an international contest sponsored by the Chicago Daily News in 1923. During studies at the same conservatory in Chicago, Nicanor S. Abelardo wrote his most enduring chamber music: The Flower and the Bird for flute, violin, and piano, A Summer Idyll for violin, clarinet, and piano, and Panoramas for violin, viola, celesta, and piano, all in 1931, and Sonata for String Quartet, 1932.

Antonio J. Molina, a noted cellist during his student years at the UP Conservatory of Music, counted among his chamber works string quartets like the Pandangguhan and String Quartet, both 1925; piano trios like Trio in F and Luna no. 1, both 1931; and a string quintet called Quintetto en Do Mayor, 1929. The early chamber works of Antonino Buenaventura (namely, Love’s Embrace, 1928; Children’s Quartet, 1935; and Igorot Love Song and Piano Quintet, both 1938) and Felipe Padilla de Leon (namely, Night Dreams, 1939) were in a style very similar to that of their teachers. Often these chamber works used folk song material or bore programmatic titles.

The founding of the League of Filipino Composers (LFC) in 1955 further nurtured the growth of chamber music literature. The LFC organized annual festivals of Philippine music featuring the new works of its members. Commissions subsidized by the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines and, after 1969, by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) encouraged the writing of chamber works because, with the exception of the works cited previously, the chamber music repertoire of Filipino composers up until that time was sparse. In addition, from 1976, the LFC, in coordination with the CCP, sponsored nationwide annual competitions for young composers. These incentives brought forth a number of chamber works that showed influences of the prevailing American and European styles of the first half of the 20th century—namely, impressionism, expressionism, neoclassicism, atonality, and some aspects of the avant-garde.

Conventional instrumentation was used by Eliseo M. Pajaro in his Joy for Soprano and String Quartet, 1952, String Quartet No. 1, 1957, String Quartet No. 2, 1958, and Trio, 1967, for piano, violin, and cello; by Angel Peña in his Prelude and Fugue for Brass Quartet, 1958, Three Pieces for String Quartet, 1971, Divertissement for Brass Quintet, 1986, EDSA String Quintet, 1987, Philippine Music Collection for String Quintet, 1987, and Movement for Wind Quintet, 1992; by Antonino Buenaventura in his Suite No. 1, 1969, for string quartet, and Suite No. 2, 1971, for string quartet; by Lucio D. San Pedro in his Brass Quintet, 1984; by Rosendo Santos in his Wind Quartet, 1961; by Amada Santos-Ocampo in her Woodwind Quintet and String Quartet, 1961; by Hilarion F. Rubio in his Maligayang Araw (Joyful Day), 1967, for violin, cello, and piano; and by Lucrecia R. Kasilag in her Fanfare and Rondo, 1987, for brass quintet, and Kleine Suite (Small Suite), 1989, sextet.

Unusual combinations of Western instruments, as well as Western and ethnic instruments, were given experimental treatment in the compositions of Jerry A. Dadap, such as in Short Pieces nos. 1, 2, 3, and 4, 1970-74, Mangamuyo (Beg) I, 1976, and II, 1977; Bayani M. de Leon in Okir, 1980, Pagdidiwata and Ulalim, both 1982, and Atmosphere and Pandangguhan, both 1983; Lucrecia R. Kasilag in Toccata for Percussion and Winds, 1958, Introduction and Frolic on a Tone Row, 1966, Whims and Repartee, 1967, Improvisations 2, 1970, Ekologie I-X, 1972-89, Munting Principe (Little Prince), 1988, for voice, piano, and synthesizer, and In Memoriam: A Tribute to J. William Fulbright, 1996, for soprano, piano, trumpet and percussions; Manuel P. Maramba, OSB, in Transfigurations I, 1983, and II, 1987; and Angel Peña in Petit Recueil, 1965, for three double basses, Variations on Bahay Kubo, 1973, for viola and violin, Prelude and Fugue for Ukelele and String Quartet, 1974, Suite for Three Double Basses, 1983, For Louise Emery, 1996, a trio for violin, cello and piano, and Little Things, 1997, for bass, fiddle and piano.

The Filipino composer who introduced a new sound mass with innovative utilization of mostly native instruments, while maintaining the conventional western instrumental combinations in some of his compositions, was Jose Maceda. His works would later influence the next generations of Filipino composers, mostly his students at the UP College of Music. His compositions include Strata, 1988, for 10 buzzers, 10 sticks, 5 tamtam, 5 celli, and 5 guitars; Dissemination, 1990, for five flutes, five violins, five oboes, five horns, three celli, two contrabass, one gong, and two whistles; Distemperament, 1992, for three of each instrument—violin, flute, oboe, trumpet, clarinet, viola, horn, celli, bass clarinet, trombone, bassoon, and contrabass; Music for Five Pianos, 1993; Two Pianos and Four Winds, 1996; Music for Gongs and Bamboo, 1997; and Udlot-udlot for Six Performers, 1997. Among those Maceda influenced was Ruben Federizon who wrote Ritmos, 1974, for percussion; Sonis Ostinatis, 1975; Ritmos Tabulare, 1977; and Sonis Ostinatis Dos, 1978.

Francisco F. Feliciano and Ramon P. Santos, both of whom were named National Artists for music in 2014, contributed many compositions to the growing repertoire of chamber music. Feliciano composed Salimbayan and Stueck feur Neun Instrumenten, 1975; String Quartet no. 1, 1977; Piece for Six Percussion Players, 1980; Eighth Character Pieces, Village Drummers, and Trio for Soprano, Clarinet, and Viola, 1980; Isostasie III, 1981; Siya-Kuno (They Say It’s Him), 1990, for woodwind quintet; Voices and Images, 1992, for string and percussion; Perpetuum Immobile, 1996, for guitar, flute and violoncello; Kochi, 2002, for flute, clarinet, violoncello, and piano; Batawa, 2003, for bamboo instruments; and Five Songs for Rainer Maria Rilke, 2004, for baritone, clarinet, and string orchestra.

Santos’s contribution include Suite for Flute, Clarinet, Viola, Cello, and Piano, Pied Beauty, and Music for Nine Instruments, all in 1968; Time Improvisations, 1970, for percussion; Quartet, 1976, Singaw (Seep of Air), 1977, for mouth harp, bamboo flute, zithers, gongs, and violins; Balat-Kayo (Disguise) for voice and wind sextet, and Panaghoy (Lament) for voices, gongs, bass drum, guitars, and poet, both 1983; Takumbo, 1992, for tambi, 20 gongs, and vibraphones; S’Geypo, 1993, for 16 flutes and drums; Kilos (Motion), 1997, for clarinet, French horn, bassoon, trombone, three violins, and piano, Simoy (Breeze); 2001, for accordion and percussion; Galluda Pallotgot, 2002, for flute, oboe, clarinet, percussion, mandolin, guitar, harp, piano, viola, cello, violin, and contrabass; Bu-Ka, 2004, for mandolin, guitar, and harpsichord, with percussion; and Dw’gey, 2006, for violin, viola, voice, and percussion.

Chino Toledo’s works for this genre include Tatluhan (By Threes), Taghoy ng Kalikasan (Nature’s Lament) for ethnic instrument, and Ug-og for strings, 1979; Tula-li for two flutes and Lima (Five), 1984; Ug-og for wind and percussion, Uboy for oboe and tape, and For Edwin Thumboo and All of Us Who Suffer through English in Asia, 1986; Trenodya ke Lean at sa Iba Pang Pinapaslang, Pinaslang at Papaslangin Dahil sa Dahilang Walang Kadahilanan (Threnody for Lean and Those Who Have Been Slain, Are Being Slain, and Will Be Slain for Reasons That Have No Reason), 1988; Sigaw (Shout), for chamber ensemble, Hinga (Breath), for flutes and nose flute, Dasal (Prayer) for alto flute, cello and marimba, and Salita-an (Conversations), for guitar, viola, cello and marimba, all in 1997; Hoy! (Hey!), 2004, for flute and percussion; and Mga Sulyap sa Simbahan ng Quiapo mula sa Kalye Echague (Glances at the Quiapo Church from Echague Street), 2004, revised in 2012, for chamber ensemble.

Chamber music compositions of Jonas Baes include Yayeyunan (Melody), 1987, for 5 female voices, 4 batiwtiw, and 16 tagutok; Daluy (Flow), 2000, for five percussion and audience; Patangis-Buwaya (And the Crocodile Wept), 2003, for four bass recorders or any four indigenous blown instruments from any culture; Ti’awag Kasi (Love Called), 2005, for four saxophones; Ripieno, 2009, for English horn, bass clarinet, French horn, two violins, viola, cello, double bass, claves, woodblock, and temple blocks; Gandhing-Ni-Napi, 2011, for suspended gandingan, five trombones, five large tam-tams, audience, and iron-nail chimes; Sine Nomine (No Name), 2013, a string quartet; and Tmesis, 2014, for flute, soprano saxophone, baritone saxophone, piano, and percussion.

Other composers and their works are Verne de la Peña with his Siklos, 1984, for 12 violins, N(y)uma, 1989, for two cellos, and Yahyah, 1989, for Ifugao whistle flutes and various Asian instruments; Arlene Chongson with her Luduyan I and II, and Ching, 1987; Conrado del Rosario with his Yugto fur Kammer Ensemble and Twilight Temples, 1987, for flute, saxophone, cello, percussion, and piano, and Chants, 1989, for 11 players; and Christine Muyco’s Ball and Gravity, 1992, for clarinet and bassoon, Cho No Hentai (Metamorphosis), 1993, for four Japanese kotos, At sa Mata Ko’y … Anino (And in My Eyes … a Shadow), 1994, for large choir, cello, and piano, Pagdiwata (Palawan’s Healing Ritual), 1994, for chamber ensemble, Tunog Tanaga I (Sound Poem I), 2001, for soprano and multi-percussions, Tunog Tanaga II (Sound Poem II), 2002, for tenor and multi-percussions, Tunog Tanaga III (Sound Poem III), 2003, for alto and multi-percussions, PagbaBagtasbagtas (Affixations), 2006, for string quintet and percussion, and Agit-it (Squeaking), 2009, for multi-percussion and voice.

From his base in Europe, Jeffrey Ching contributed to the chamber music repertoire with his Souvenir des Tang, 1997 revised in 2009, for violin and prepared piano; Kunstkabinett Part I, 2008, for modern art sextet with soprano; Concerto da Camera, for solo guitar, solo violoncello, soprano, and 20 strings, Kundiman ni Schumann (Schumann’s Love Song), for soprano, viola or violoncello, and piano, and Spohr’s Last Thoughts, for clarinet/bass clarinet, violin, violoncello, and piano, all 2009; Bombyx Mori, 2010; Raven Mantra, for soprano, cello and, piano, and Wesendonck Sonata, for soprano, viola, and piano, both 2013; and A Chamber Requiem, 2014, for mezzo-soprano, bass baritone, and sextet.

The younger composers use open-ended structures of time and space, colors and timbres from local sound sources, non-Western structural elements such as drone and melody, expansion of nuclear cells, and other experimental innovations. Aside from the incentives provided by commissions and competitions, more chamber works are now being written, perhaps because public performance is more probable when only a small number of musicians are involved.Written by Corazon C. Dioquino Updated by Arwin Q. Tan

text:
A chant refers to vocal music that is generally characterized by melodies with flexible rhythms—that is, no meter and tempo. Chant is found in the indigenous or ethnic traditions, specifically in the epic song, the salidummay, tud-om, and the bayok. Chant is also used in acculturated folk religious music in Christianized areas, such as the lectio and the pabasa.

Chants in indigenous cultures are commonly associated with rituals for curing or thanksgiving, and agricultural and life-cycle ceremonies where one or more religious specialists and/or mediums officiate and try to appease different spirits with offerings of food and other valuable items. In other ritual contexts, chants are the spirits’ voices themselves and are taken as a physical sign of the spirits providing guidance and assistance. These rites are often characterized by the medium going into a state of trance or “possession” as seen in the Kalinga anito, the Bataan Aeta kagum, the Tagalog sanghiyang, and Manobo yana-an. In many indigenous communities, elaborate versions of possession ceremonies entail animal sacrifices whose meat is eaten by both spirits and humans as an act of communion at the end of the rituals. Chants, however, may also be used in non-spiritual community gatherings, such as in the Maranao bayok or the Kalinga ading, dango, and oggayam.

Chant as a specie of verbal art is closely related to the performance of the epic, which is a long narrative about culture heroes. This narrative embodies indigenous cultural knowledge and mythology—as history would in literate societies—in the sense that it explains to culture bearers the origins of the cosmos, the natural order of things, and social values and beliefs. Philippine epics vary greatly in melody, rhythm, and performance practice so that they can be said to lie in a continuum between speech and song. A chant that is more speechlike would be governed more by the rhythm and intonation of the words, while a chant that is more songlike would emphasize sustained tones, constituting a melody that dominates the expression. Chants are principally learned and transmitted through an oral-formulaic process where a stock of textual verses or lines, normatively within the range of seven to eight syllables, are spontaneously fitted to preexisting musical contours of the tunes. With very few exceptions, such as the Ifugao hudhud and alim, Philippine epics are usually unaccompanied and can be either syllabic (one syllable per note) or melismatic (one syllable to two or more notes). Most renditions of the epic are in free rhythm, thus warranting its chant status, such as the Kalinga Ullalim and Gasumbi, the Kinaray-a Hinilawod, and certain sections in the Maguindanao Diwata Kaslipan and Rajah Indarapatra, Bukidnon Manobo Ulahingan, Tboli Tudbulol, and the Sama Kata-kata. There are tunes, however, that are metered. In such cases, it becomes a chant or a song, depending on the text or the music governing the musical flow.

A vocal genre that is very popular in the Cordillera region of northern Philippines is the salidummay or dewas. Its text features seven-syllable verses. The first and second lines of the stanza are changing verses while the third and fourth lines feature fixed formulaic words, such as “dangdang-ay sidong-ilay” and “insinalidumma-ay.” This is why the salidummay is also referred to as dangdang-ay (or dongdong-ay). Heard in social gatherings such as weddings and peace pacts, the salidummay has a repertoire of melodies usually in pentatonic scale. It may be rendered solo or in a chorus, often utilizing simple harmonization. A recent study implies that this genre may have been appropriated from the Western school and church songs that the Americans introduced to the peoples of the Cordillera region. In recent times, the salidummay has been sung with instrumental accompaniment, particularly with the guitar.

Bayok is a general term for “song” among the Maguindanao and Maranao people and is referred to as a love song among the Subanon of Zamboanga. The Maranao bayok deals with various topics, such as praising important people in bayok kapamodi, narrating adventures of epic hero Bantugan in bayok kandurangun, expressing personal experiences in bayok kapranon, and disclosing about one’s lost love in bayok kaparongis. Rendered solo and unaccompanied, the Maranao bayok features melismatic singing in loose meter and is performed by a professional singer called onor or pabubayok. Usually, a female bayok singer covers her mouth with a beautifully decorated fan when singing while a male performer places a fan on his chest. The onor or pabubayok is frequently invited to sing during festive gatherings called kalilang, and on other special occasions. The Maguindanao bayok, on the other hand, features a relatively syllabic singing style with limited vocal range. It is used to express, through metaphor, the singer’s feelings and opinion on various topics, particularly about love and marriage. Like the Maranao bayok, the Maguindanao bayok is sung solo and unaccompanied. In the Maguindanao bayok, the performer’s hand is placed on one cheek. The Subanon bayok generally features pairs of seven-syllable verses rendered in syllabic style.

People in Mindanao and Sulu who profess a belief in Islam, like the Tausug, Maranao, and Maguindanao, render chanted prayers and religious songs in syllabic and melismatic styles. Among the Tausug, for example, the lugu maulud is a song cycle with an Arabic text in prose called janitla and poetry called jikil about the birth and life of Muhammad. The lugu maulud is performed in a highly melismatic style by professional singers during celebrations of the Prophet’s birthday. Another chant is the Tausug tarasul, which comments on some verses of the Quran and is used to express various aspects of Islam. The tarasul is also sung in memory of the dead and during the pagtammat or oral examination in Quran reading. Regular Friday noon service at a mosque is marked by a call to prayer called bang by the Maguindanao. The Islamic rite consists of a set of prayers that is accompanied by stereotyped body postures and hand gestures as main part of the service, which is closed by lasib, rendered in largely sustained ornamented high tones. An important chant during Ramadan or the month of fasting called puwasa by the Maguindanao is the talawi, which is sung in syllabic style on reciting tones and performed by a solo leader and answered by a chorus at the end of phrases with the word “Muhammad.”

In Western music, chant may refer to vocal music, which uses reciting tones in the rendering of texts as heard in church plainsongs of Christian liturgies. The Gregorian chant codified by Pope Gregory I (590-604) is one type of plainsong introduced in the Philippines by religious orders of the Roman Catholic Church. These chants, called pasyon and lectio, are sung in parallel harmony of thirds and are accompanied by a cinco-cinco (small five-stringed guitar). The most popular chant in lowland Christian cultures is the chant used for reading the pasyon, the verse narrative on the life and sufferings of Jesus Christ, which is read during the Lenten season—specifically, on Ash Wednesday, the Sundays of Lent, and Holy Week. In front of an altar of santos (saints), two or more chanters sing pasyon solo or antiphonally, using different styles called punto, among which are the tres caidas and deretso. Related present-day practice is evidenced in Cagayan Valley during the Holy Week and in connection with death or the prevention of sickness, as seen in some Ibanag and Itawes plainsongs in neumatic notations copied by hand from the Processionarium Sacri Ordinis Predicatorum, 1861. Other times, a six-stringed Western-type guitar called sista among the Ibanag or siesta among the Itawes is used.Written by Felicidad A. Prudente u pdated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

text:
Choral arrangements serve many purposes—from stage entertainment and religious worship services, to civic, school, and other secular events. Types of song arrangement vary according to the combination of vocal types—that is, soprano (S), alto (A), tenor (T), bass (B)—for which the arrangement is done. Combinations could include SAB, SB, SSAA, SSA, SA, TTBB, and TB. SSAA, SSA, and SA could refer to either adult or children’s choir. The limits on highest and lowest notes, the timbre or vocal color (dark and bright sounds), the flexibility to sing with a full voice and running passages, and the competency of the choir (amateur, professional, church, civic, school, etc.) are important factors in song arrangement.

The textbook The Progressive Music Series, first published in 1915 and many times thereafter, the Philippine National Chorus Collection, 1930, and Mga Tinipong Panabayang Awiting Pilipino (Collected Philippine Songs for Chorus), 1969, are some of the pioneering collections of Filipino choral music arrangements. Many of the published materials in the Philippines were commissioned pieces. The songs in the Filipino Series published by the Madrigal Singers in the 1960s and 1970s were arranged specifically for the University of the Philippines (UP) Madrigal Singers. The National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) also printed song arrangements gathered from particular choirs. Two collections in the series were from the UP Madrigal Singers (hence NAMCYA-Madrigals) and the UP Cherubim & Seraphim (hence NAMCYA-UP Cherubim & Seraphim).

The NAMCYA-Madrigals, Series I, edited by Andrea Veneracion, contains the following songs: “No Duaduaem Pay” (If You Still Doubt), arranged by Noel Velasco; “Con Harapit Na an Adlaw” (When the Day Is about to End), arr. Ruben Federizon; Ilocano folk songs “Ti Ayat ti Meysa nga Ubing” (The Love of a Young Maiden) and “Pong Pong Guinapong,” arr. Fabian Obispo; Gines Tan’s “Magsimula Ka” (Take the First Step), arr. Ed Nepomuceno; Rodolfo de Leon’s “Neneng”; Nicanor Abelardo’s “Kenkoy,” arr. Ruben Federizon; “Mamayog Akun,” arr. Fabian Obispo; Nitoy Gonzales’s “Usahay” (Sometimes), arr. Ramon Acoymo; and Antonino Buenventura’s “Digdigwi.”

The NAMCYA-UP Cherubim & Seraphim, Series I contains the following songs: Ramon P. Santos’s “Batang Magalang” (Respectful Child) and “Dal’wang Sawikaing Filipino” (Two Filipino Proverbs); Lucio D. San Pedro’s “Mga Awiting Pamasko” (Christmas Songs); “Sa Araw ng Pasko” (On Christmas Day), arranged by Antonio Regalario; “May Isang Bulaklak” (There’s a Flower), arr. Antonio Regalario; Constancio de Guzman’s “Pamaypay ng Maynila” (Manila’s Folding Fan), arr. Antonio Regalario; and “Dagiti Bibitwen” (The Stars), arr. Ruben Federizon.

Other collections are devoted to a particular age range, like children and youth choirs. The NAMCYA Children’s Choir Collection, Series I is an example of an anthology for these groups. The following are titles from the said collection: Antonio Molina’s “Isang Gabing Mapanglaw” (A Dark Night); Alfredo Buenventura’s “Gising Na Anak Ko” (Arise, My Child); Lucio D. San Pedro’s “Pahatid Awit” (Farewell Song), “Sa Kabukiran” (By the Countryside), “Mahal ng Bayan” (Love of Country), and “Aleluya”; Ruben Federizon’s “Maharlika” (The Nobility); Ramon Santos’s “He-Le”; Jerry Dadap’s “Lawiswis Kawayan” (Swishing Bamboo), “May Isang Bulaklak” (There’s a Flower), and “Si Nanay, Si Tatay” (Mother and Father); and Felipe P. de Leon’s “Bagong Lipunan” (New Society). Although many of the songs in the collection were composed, some of the songs are traditional folk songs, like “Si Nanay, Si Tatay” and “May Isang Bulaklak.”

More recent choral arrangements are circulated through manuscripts by composers and/or their copyists or are mechanically reproduced photocopies. Only a limited number of collections have been published locally, and even less sheet music or collections have been published internationally. Most choral arrangements have been originally for the solo voice in genres like kundiman (love song), pop, Original Pilipino Music (OPM), and Broadway. Examples of these are Nicanor Abelardo’s “Mutya ng Pasig” (Muse of Pasig) arranged for mixed chorus by Lucio San Pedro, and his “Ultimo Adios” (Last Farewell) arranged by Liwanag Cruz also for mixed chorus. OPM was quickly transformed in the 1980s and the 1990s. Ryan Cayabyab’s “Umiikot Sumisirko” (Turn and Somersault) from Hibang sa Awit (Crazy for Songs) was arranged for the SATB choir by Robert Delgado. Cayabyab transformed his Metro Manila Popular Music Festival-winning piece, “Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika” (How Beautiful Is Our Music), by rearranging it for mixed chorus. Gary Granada’s “Bahay” (Home), also a prizewinner in the Metro Pop Music Festival, was adapted for a cappella choir in the UP Madrigal Singers’ version and with piano accompaniment in the UP Concert Chorus version by Delgado. The songs “Mabuti Pa Sila” (They’re Lucky) by Granada and “Isang Dugo, Isang Lahi, Isang Musika” (One Blood, One Race, One Music) by Dodjie Simon, both winners in the Metro Pop Music Festival, were set for chorus by Deogracias Cruz and Delgado, respectively. The latter became part of standard Filipino choral repertoire in the 1990s.

Previous to this, it was common for folk songs to be remade into choral arrangements. Francisco Santiago, Lucrecia Kasilag, Lucio San Pedro, Eliseo Pajaro, and Resti Umali were the main proponents of setting Filipino folk songs for choirs of mixed and equal voices. Santiago harmonized the earliest attempts at organized collection of Filipino folk songs. Kasilag wrote “Dandansoy” (Unfaithful) for both equal and mixed voices. She also based her Republic Cultural Heritage-winning piece Misang Tagalog (Tagalog Mass) for chorus on Mindanao and Cordillera folk tunes. San Pedro has a published collection of folk melodies arranged for chorus, titled Mga Katutubong Awitin, Isinaayos para sa Koro (Folk Songs Arranged for Chorus).

Indeed, through the decades, the need to enrich the repertories of choirs in the country created a distinguished pool of Filipino choral arrangers. With more Filipino choirs participating in international festivals and competitions that require choral setting of folk songs from home countries, Filipino choral works are gaining exposure outside the Philippines. Some of the favorite works among local groups that have permeated the international choral scene are Delarmente’s “Ilay Gandangan” and “Dumbele,” Francisco Feliciano’s “Pokpok Alimpako” and “Pamugun,” Eudenice Palaruan’s “Gapas” (Harvest), George Hernandez’s “Rosas Pandan” (Rose of Pandan), and Elmo Makil’s “Iddem-dem Mallida.” The Tagalog folk song “Paruparong Bukid” (Country Butterfly) has such charm that, at different times, Noli Laureola, George Hernandez, and Robin Estrada arranged it for chorus. All three arrangements have gained a popular following on both sides of the Atlantic, and both local and foreign choirs have their noteworthy performances posted on YouTube. Also very popular among foreign groups are Obispo’s choral setting of “Dahil sa Iyo” (Because of You) and Hernandez’s “Rosas Pandan.”

Some of the individually published choral arrangements are “Telebong,” arr. Obispo, 1970; “Da-Ba-Da” [on “Manang Biday”], arr. Reynaldo Paguio, 1969; “Dayo Dayo Kupita,” arr. Santos, 1971; and “Dahil sa Iyo” (Because of You), arr. Obispo, 1969. The aforementioned arrangements were part of the Filipino series publication by the UP Madrigal Singers. The group also published a collection of songs from their repertoire, titled Mga Awiting Bayan (Folk Songs). Madrigal Singers choirmaster Andrea Veneracion edited both the series and the book. Some of the songs in the book are “Waway,” arr. Palaruan; “Pamulinawen,” arr. Feliciano; “Manang Biday,” arr. Pajaro; “No Du’duaem Pay,” arr. Velasco; “Salidum-ay,” arr. Paguio; “Chua-ay,” arr. Obispo; “Atin Cu Pung Singsing,” arr. Kasilag; “Malinac Lay Labi,” arr. J. Nilo; “Ang Aking Bituin,” arr. San Pedro; “Tuksuhan” (Teasing) arr. Santos; “Con Harapit Na an Adlaw” (When the Day Is about to End) arr. Federizon; and “Pokpok Alimpako,” arr. Feliciano. These songs have become part of the standard repertoire of Filipino choirs.

The UP Concert Chorus also published San Pedro’s choral works, titled the Choral Works of Lucio San Pedro. It includes the classic “Sa Mahal Kong Bayan” (For My Beloved Country), “Simbanggabi” (Dawn Mass), and the choral setting of Suite Pastorale in four parts: “Abot Tanaw” (Horizon), “Dapithapon” (Dusk), “Sa Ugoy ng Duyan” (In the Cradle’s Rocking), and “Pistahan sa Nayon” (Barrio Fiesta).

San Pedro’s collection of choral arrangements, Mga Katutubong Awitin: Isinaayos para sa Koro, published by Antonina Siapuatco, includes well-loved folk songs from the Tagalog, Visayas, and Ilocos regions, such as “Aking Bituin” (My Star), “Pandangguhan,” “Atin Cu Pung Singsing” (I Have a Ring), “Lulay,” “Ay Kalisud!” (How Difficult!), “Ili, Ili, Tulog Anay” (Hush, Hush, My Baby), “Magtanim Hindi Biro” (Planting Rice Is Not Easy), “Rosas Pandan,” “Ti Ayat ti Meysa nga Ubing,” and “Walang Kalungkutan” or “No Dua-Duaem Pay” (If You Still Doubt My Love).

Another important publication of local and foreign songs was made, this time by Imelda Ongsiako, editor of the Sundry Choral Series. Volumes 1-3 of the series cover songs from the folk to the popular, among them “Ili, Ili, Tulog Anay,” “Chichiritchit,” “Dandansoy,” “Tilibum,” “Tzena Tzena,” Malaysian lullaby “Riqui, Riquiran,” “You Can Tell the World,” “To Fill the World With Love,” “Brother Sun, Sister Moon,” “One Hand, One Heart,” “Color My World,” “Awit ng Mundo” (Song of the World), and “Diwa ng Pasko” (Meaning of Christmas).

In 2003, the NAMCYA Secretariat published a two-volume collection of commissioned choral works used as contest pieces in its earlier choral singing competitions. The collection is titled The NAMCYA Anthology of Philippine Choral Music. Volume 1 contains the following works: “Awit ng Buhay” (Song of Life) by San Pedro; “Buhay, Bahay ng Isang Bata” (Life, Home of a Child) by Heber Bartolome; “Buligi” (Help Me) by Cayabyab; “Create in Me a Clean Heart, Oh God” by Pajaro; “Ina Naming Lahat” (Mother of Us All) by V. Villanueva; “Isang Kabataang Alamat” (A Legend for the Youth) by Palaruan; “Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas” (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow) by Kasilag; “Kay Ganda ng Buhay” (How Beautiful Is Life) by De Leon; “Naku! Kenkoy” (Hey! Kenkoy) by Abelardo, arr. N. Pacis; “Pagkakaisa, Choral Trilogy” (Unity, Choral Trilogy) by Umali; “Panaghoy ng Kalikasan” (Nature’s Murmur) by R. Pangan; “Purihin Ninyo ang Panginoon” (Praise the Lord) by Kasilag; and “Sa Kabataang Pilipino” (To the Filipino Youth) by Federizon.

Volume 2 of the collection contains the following songs: “Ambo Hato” (A Singing Game [of Spanish origin]) by A. Espino; “Ang Aking Bayan” (My Country) by Abelardo, arr. Santos; “Bansang Ito Ay Akin” (This Nation Is Mine) by E. Parungao; “Gloria” by D. Yap; “Halina’t Umawit” (Let’s Gather to Sing) by Santos; “Isang Matandang Panalangin” (An Old Prayer) by Verne de la Peña; “Kung Maaari Sana” (Should It Be Possible) by Kasilag; “La Paz Batchoy” (La Paz Noodle Soup) by Pangan; “Lupang Tinubuan” (Land of One’s Root) by Christine Muyco; “Psalm 27” by De la Peña; “Sanctus et Benedictus” by Antonino Buenaventura; “Si Yahweh ang Aking Pastol” (The Lord Is My Shepherd ) by San Pedro; “Sigaw ng Bayan” (Nation’s Cry) by Regalario; “Tanong Po Lamang” (Only a Question) by Josefino Toledo; and “Tatlong Alay sa Pasko” (Three Offerings in Christmas) by Arlene Chongson.

More recent publications are The Choral Works of Robert Delgado, 2000; Father Zamora’s Blessed Be God, A Cappella, 1999; Mga Awiting Bayan para sa Korong Pilipino (Songs of the Motherland for the Filipino Choir), 2007, edited by De la Peña and published by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA); the two-volume work Mga Awit ng Himagsikan, 1896-1898 (Songs of the Revolution, 1896-1898), compiled by Evelyn Cabanban and edited by Raul Sunico; and Stephen Q. Lagarde’s Koro Leyteño: Choral Arrangements of Selected Traditional Songs of Leyte, 2004.

In the past years, several Filipino choral works were published by international publishers. Three of Agripino Diestro’s recent works—“Allelujah, Ave Maria,” “Kyrie,” and Missa—were published by Carus-Verlag. Alejandro Consolacion’s “Pater Noster” was published by Hinshaw Music, Inc. For lack of music publishers in the Philippines, local choral music writers have also published their own works. Delgado came out with a collection titled The Choral Works of Robert Delgado, which is actually a compilation of the author’s choral arrangements. The group Kompositor published its members’ choral music in a compilation titled Pagbubunyi: Original Works for Unaccompanied Mixed Chorus. Notable in this collection are Joy Nilo’s “Umawit Kayo sa Panginoon” (Sing to the Lord), Joed Balsamo’s “Amahan Namo” (Our Father), and Alejandro Consolacion II’s “Veni, Creator Spiritus” (Come, Created Spirit). Online publication is also becoming an option for young composers of new music. Balsamo’s “Angeli Dei” (Angels of God), “Lumen Christi” (Light of Christ), “Gloria, Laus, et Honor” (Glory, Praise and Honor), and “An Apocalyptic Alleluia” are all published online.

Two of the country’s leading composers, Chino Toledo and Ryan Cayabyab, are among those who have contributed the most to the choral repertory. Toledo’s works include “KorDei,” 2014, for chorus and small percussion; “Panginoon Eleison” (Merciful God), 2014, for chorus and small percussion; “Kredo” (Creed), 2013, for chorus and small percussion; “Te Deum” (You Are God), 2013, for chorus; “Gloriya” (Glory), 2012, for chorus and small percussion; “Santo Sanctus” (Holy Saint), 2012, for chorus and small percussion; “Sitsit Digidong” (nonsense words, onomatopoeic syllables), 2007, for chorus; “Ako ang Daigdig” (I Am the World), 2006, for chorus and small percussion; “Dignum et Iustum Est” (Worthy and Just It Is), 2000, for chorus piano or orchestra; “Sitsit Digidak,” 1999, for chamber choir; “Soundstream,” 1999, for male chorus; “Mga Awit ng Paglingap” (Songs of Compassion), 1998, for 16 voices and bamboo percussion; “Tanong Po Lamang” (Just a Question, Please), 1998, for children’s choir; “Auit” (Song), 1997, for 12 voices, guitar and 2 percussion instruments; and “Alitaptap” (Butterfly), 1995, for chorus and Filipino indigenous instruments. Cayabyab’s fairly recent works for chorus include “Aba Po Santa Mariang Reyna” (Salve Regina), “Aquesta Me Guiaba” (That Which Guided Me), Mass for Peace, “Mi Ultimo Adios” (My Last Farewell), Misa 2000 (Mass 2000), St. Michael Mass, and Trinity Mass.

Two events in the Philippine choral scene featured outstanding new works for the choir. The first was Philippine Madrigal Singers’ concert titled Premiere held in 2013 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo. The group presented works of both foreign and local origin. Those written by Filipinos were Nilo’s “Ayat, Asi Ken Kinalinteng” (Love, Mercy and Righteousness), Palaruan’s “A Musician’s Prayer,” Alejandro Consolacion’s “Signore, Fa di Me Uno Strumento della Tua Pace” (Lord, Make Me an Instrument of Your Peace), Ily Matthew Maniano’s “Euphonos,” and Nilo Alcala’s “Ceremonial Burning.” The other event was called Likhawit: First Contemporary Choral Festival, 2014, a UP College of Music co-production with the Asian Composers League and the Philippine Choral Directors Association. The concert’s repertoire included Muyco’s “Tinala” (Imaging Stars), De la Peña’s “Kalo-ob” (Offering of One Spirit), Felice Macahis’s “Nuageux” (Cloudy), Balsamo’s “Dakop-Dakop” (Catch Me If You Can), Robin Estrada’s “Paghahandog” (Offering), Toledo’s “Sitsit Digudak” and “Kredo,” Jonas Baes’s “Banal-Pasakit” (Holy Sacrifice), and Katherine Tranco’s “Salitaan” (Saying).

Organizations that have encouraged the production of music arrangements are the NAMCYA, NCCA, UP Madrigal Singers, UP Concert Chorus, and UP Cherubim & Seraphim. Many new choirs are joining the ranks, with the UP Singing Ambassadors and the UST Singers leading the pack. The University of the East Chorale, Ateneo
College Glee Club, Manila Chamber Singers, and many other groups follow the established groups in commissioning new choral works and arrangements as required by their participation in international festivals and competitions. The Children’s Museum and Library, Inc’s (CMLI) annual high schools choral competition Voices in Harmony, the Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corporation’s (PAGCOR) Christmas Choral Competition, and the Philippine Civil Service Commission’s (CSC) annual Government Choral Competition also require newly arranged music. The CMLI leans toward the popular genre since it caters to high school choirs from both private and public institutions. The PAGCOR competition enriches the Christmas choral repertoire for the season-themed songs it requires. The CSC government choral competition emphasizes civic-themed or patriotic songs that are arranged for chorus.Written by Mauricia D. Borromeo u pdated by Raul Navarro

text:
The concerto is a work for solo instrument, or a group of solo instruments and an orchestral ensemble. It is patterned after the sonata form, although with some distinguishing features. Instead of the four-movement sonata structure, the concerto is normally set in three movements (fast-slow-fast), omitting the minuet or scherzo. The first movement is cast in a modified sonata-allegro form called concerto-allegro. The three main parts of a sonata-allegro (exposition-development-recapitulation) are retained. However, in the concerto-allegro, the repeat sign for the exposition is dispensed with and instead, the exposition is written out twice, the first time for orchestra and the second time for soloist and orchestra. The last movement is almost always cast in rondo form. Brilliant cadenza passages, designed to showcase the soloists’ technical skills, appear in the first movement just before the recapitulation and occasionally in the other movements.

The standard three-movement concerto form was crystallized in the 18th century with Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and Franz Joseph Haydn. In the 19th century, one-movement concertos became fashionable. On a less ambitious scale than the concerto, the single movement featured sections with changing speeds and characters. They were called concertino or konzertstück. The repertory of concertos by Filipino composers consisted mainly of concertos for piano or violin, with a few written for other instruments.

Before the 1950s, only about 10 works were written in this genre. The majority of these works exhibited nationalist sentiments in their use of folklike melodies as thematic material. Nicanor S. Abelardo’s Concerto in B-Flat Minor for Piano and Orchestra, Opus 12 was the first large work by a Filipino to utilize folk melodies. It was premiered in an all-Filipino concert in Sep 1923, together with works by Tereso Zapata, Cayetano Jacobe, and Juan S. Hernandez, all colleagues at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music. In 1924, Francisco Santiago presented his Piano Concerto in B- Flat Minor for his doctoral dissertation at the Chicago Musical College. Its three movements used folk tunes: “Moderato e Maestoso” used the Cebuano balitaw (love verses), “Andante Amoroso” the kundiman (love song) and awit (metrical romance), and “Allegro Scherzando” the San Roque “Leron-Leron Sinta” (Leron-Leron Beloved) and “Dandansoy” (Unfaithful). At the same school, Rodolfo S. Cornejo performed Piano Concerto in D Minor, his master’s thesis at the commencement concert. Other works by Cornejo, also for piano and orchestra in the konzertstück form, were Philippine Rhapsodies nos. 1, 1939, 2, 1942, and 3, 1947. A previous work in the konzertstück genre was composed by Antonino Buenaventura, Rhapsodietta for Piano and Orchestra, 1937, based on a Manobo theme collected during his research in the south when he was with the UP President’s Committee on Folk Songs and Dance. Juan S. Hernandez, a graduate and later faculty member of the UP Conservatory during director Santiago’s incumbency in the 1930s, wrote the Piano Concerto in D Minor. It was cast in the traditional three-movement concerto structure. Though no folk tunes were quoted, the thematic material was folklike, supported by rich chromatic harmonies.

From this same period, concertos for violin and orchestra included violin virtuoso Conrado de la Cruz’s Concerto in D Major, Jose Estella’s Concerto in F Major, and Nicanor S. Abelardo’s Concerto for Violin and Orchestra in one movement. The scores of these works, however, are no longer extant.

Concertos composed in the 1940s were those by Francisco Buencamino, Lucio D. San Pedro, and Rosendo Santos. Buencamino’s opus was programmatic in nature. Titled Mayon Concerto, 1942, its three movements portrayed the gaiety of a fiesta in the Bicol countryside that had been interrupted by a violent eruption of the volcano, followed by the return of peace and calm, and ending with a hymn of thanksgiving. The first movement was premiered by pianist Corazon Langcauon at St. Scholastica’s College in 1943. The first performance of the complete work was on 5 Feb 1950 at the graduation recital of the composer’s daughter, Rosario Buencamino, at Holy Ghost College.

Lucio D. San Pedro’s only work in the concerto medium, Concerto for Violin and Orchestra, was composed in 1948. Its three movements used folklike themes. The basis of the final movement was a motif derived from an Igorot tune, “Naantoay.” Celia Sucgang played the concerto for the first time in 1958 with the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra conducted by Luis Valencia.

Rosendo Santos’s Piano Concerto no. 1 in G Major, 1948, and Piano Concerto no. 2 in A Major, 1956, and Amada Santos-Ocampo’s Piano Concerto in A Minor, 1957, were written before they left for further studies abroad. The works were conventional in tonality and form.

For a long time after the 1950s, composers continued to express their nationalist sentiments by writing works based on folk songs, as seen in Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Konzertstück for Violin and Orchestra, 1952, and Antonino Buenaventura’s Divertimento for Piano and Orchestra, 1965, based on a Cordillera theme.

Others, opting for the romantic programmatic style of the West in vogue at the turn of the century, gave their works more general descriptive titles, adding impressionistic touches and dissonances to a traditionally chromatic harmonic idiom. Particularly noted for his compositions in this mode is Alfredo S. Buenaventura, whose four concertos all bore descriptive titles: Celebration piano concerto, 1977, Exultation piano concerto, 1978, Determination piano concerto, 1980, and Lakambini (Muse) violin concerto, 1983. Lucino T. Sacramento also gave graphic, evocative titles to his piano concertos: Cradle Concerto, 1959, Ang Maharlika (The Nobility), 1974, and Ang Bituin (The Star), 1975. His Cradle Concerto for piano was commissioned by the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines (MPFP) in 1959. The first movement conveyed the composer’s exhilaration with the arrival of a first grandchild. The languid middle movement was reminiscent of a Philippine lullaby, “Hili Na” (Hush Now), while the finale expressed the joy of a fulfilled grandparent. Sacramento’s violin concertos, E Minor, 1969, and D Minor, 1976, though untitled, were nevertheless descriptive. In the second movement of his first violin concerto, the composer painted a picture of a reposeful sea caressed by the afternoon wind as it caught the last drops of sunset. Also in the programmatic, romantic vein were Hilarion F. Rubio’s Panamin Concerto, 1970, for cello, and San Abel Concerto, 1984, for B-flat clarinet, as well as Rosalina Abejo’s Aeolian Piano Concerto, 1954; Imelda, 1957, for marimba; and Jubilee, 1978, for piano.

After their studies in the United States, composers Rodolfo S. Cornejo, Eliseo M. Pajaro, and Lucrecia R. Kasilag returned home with new compositional techniques. Cornejo produced three concertos after earning his doctor’s degree in composition: Second Piano Concerto in G Minor, 1950, Third Piano Concerto, 1968, and Concerto for Violin and Orchestra, 1972. The Third Piano Concerto had a clear-cut classical structure. In the second movement, a Tagalog pabasa chant was used as the main theme.

More significant contributions to the concerto genre were made by Eliseo M. Pajaro, whose works introduced new sounds strongly influenced by the neoclassic style of Paul Hindemith and a type of counterpoint based on pandiatonic harmonic structures. The first of four concertos, the Violin Concerto no. 1 in three movements, was commissioned by the MPFP. It was written in 1960 while the composer was in New York on a Guggenheim fellowship. Premiered in 1964 with Divinagracia Montalban as soloist, the work won for Pajaro his first Republic Cultural Heritage Award in 1964. Typically neoclassic in style, the first movement was in the traditional concerto-allegro form, followed by the slow movement in modified third rondo form. The last movement was a series of eight variations with the theme making a final appearance before the last variation. His Concerto for Piano and Orchestra, 1964, was premiered at a festival of Philippine music sponsored by the League of Filipino Composers (LFC). Soloist was Regalado Jose. In May 1965, cellist Herminia Atienza Ilano played the Concerto for Cello and Orchestra at a festival of Philippine music held at the UP. The composer himself conducted the UP Symphony Orchestra at this performance. Pajaro’s last concerto, Violin Concerto no. 2, was jointly commissioned in 1974 by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and the LFC, and performed at the annual Festival of Philippine Music.

Lucrecia R. Kasilag is known for her blending of Eastern and Western elements in her music. She was influenced by the neoclassicism prevailing in the United States during her studies there. Upon her return, her exposure to Philippine indigenous music led her to combine the Asian elements with her newly acquired techniques. Her three-movement Divertissement for Piano and Orchestra, 1960, was a whimsy on Muslim folk rhythms and themes with a neomodal flavor. The first movement employed the singkil rhythm as ground bass over a simple melody that used only the white keys of the piano. The second movement was a variation on a Muslim chant dende-o-dende, with an underlying syncopated ostinato. The last movement was in form featuring a rhythm juxtaposing twos and threes. Her Violin Concerto, 1983, also followed the traditional classic three-movement structure. The canonic treatment of the second movement contrasted with the freer form of the finale, which utilizes changing tempi—allegro, andante, vivace. It was premiered by Carmencita Lozada on 26 Feb 1983, with Francisco F. Feliciano as conductor. Kasilag composed Violin Concerto no. 2 in 1994, premiered by the Russian violinist Grigori Zhislin in a tribute concert in her honor at the CCP in August 2000.

The composers whose works dominated the creative musical scene in the 1970s and 1980s include Ramon P. Santos, Francisco F. Feliciano, Bayani M. de Leon, Manuel P. Maramba, OSB, and Jerry A. Dadap. Their works that bear the impact of the New Music movement did not include the concerto genre. Feliciano, Dadap, and de Leon’s contributions to this genre were written before they had been abroad. These include Dadap’s Violin Concerto, 1965-66, de Leon’s Vertigo: Concertino for Clarinet and Orchestra, 1970, and Feliciano’s Violin Concerto, 1972. Manuel P. Maramba, OSB, received his musical training in piano, organ, and composition in the United States and Europe. His works showed a preference for serialism. Unlike his contemporaries who chose not to write concertos, he wrote a Concerto for Piano, 1983, which featured an unusual mix of kulintang sounds with an alliterated running passage for the piano.

The yearly commissions and festivals of Philippine works conducted by the LFC and the CCP encouraged its members to write works for orchestra. Thus, in the 1980s, the older generation of composers wrote concertos, which departed in style from the conventional harmonic traditions they previously employed. New tonal combinations and textures surfaced in Felipe Padilla de Leon’s one-movement Concerto for Flute and Orchestra, 1980, dedicated to flutist Santiago Yangco, who was the featured soloist at its premiere. Antonino Buenaventura wrote his works in the concerto form Parangal (Tribute), a three-movement concerto for piano and symphonic band, 1982, Concerto for Trumpet, 1985, and Concerto for French Horn, 1987. Angel M. Peña, a jazz bassist, carefully integrated jazz idioms with modern harmonic techniques in his Concerto for Jazz Quartet and Orchestra, 1981. Earlier, he composed Concerto for Double Bass and Orchestra, 1969, which was followed by Concerto no. 2 for Double Bass, 1991.

The very few recent additions to the concerto repertoire include Chino Toledo’s Ekontra: Kongruo: Lunctum, 2004, for piano and orchestra; and Jeffrey Ching’s Concerto da Camara, 2009, which was actually a work for solo guitar, solo violoncello, soprano, and 20 strings.

In retrospect, the more than 50 compositions written in the multi-movement concerto and single movement or konzertstück genre by Filipino composers are widely divergent in style. From the first concerto, written in 1923, to those written in the past decade, the repertory testifies to the growth and development of Philippine art music.Written by Corazon C. Dioquino u pdated by Arwin Q. Tan
