text:
The kundiman is a song written in triple time and usually begins in the minor key. It sings about a love that is faithful and true but carries a sad tone, highlighting the sacrifices the lover does for his or her beloved. There are three theories regarding the origin of the term kundiman. First, it was believed to be a contraction of the phrase kung hindi man (would it not be so). The second was that it might have been derived from the verse “Hele hele nang kandungan / Hele hele ng kundiman” (Hush, hush, the cradle / Hush, hush, the kundiman). Third, Norberto Romualdez and Consejo Cauayani (1954) opined that kundiman could refer to the red cloth worn by male dancers or men in the countryside. This theory is supported by the folk song popular in General Trias, Cavite, in 1873, “Mula Nang Mauso, Damit na Kundiman” (Ever since the Cloth Kundiman Became a Fad):

Mula nang mauso, damit na kundiman

Ang babae’t lalaki ay nagpupulahan

Lalong namumula ang kadalagahan,

Siyang pag-aalsa ng katagalugan.

(Ever since the cloth kundiman became a fad

Women and men all turned red

Especially the young girls

When the Tagalog region rose in revolt.)

Composer and music historian Antonio J. Molina said that the kundiman is closely related to its predecessors: the kumintang and awit (metrical romance). The accent is similar to that of the second beat of the second bar of the kumintang and the second beat of the sixth bar of the awit. Musically and textually, though, the kundiman represents some of the more significant facts of the Filipino psyche brought about by history and culture—sentimentality, sense of submissiveness, self-pity, yearning for freedom from want and deprivation, and the aspiration for a better future.

The evolution of the kundiman as a literary musical form and as an art song could be traced to three or four stages of development. The first was its purely functional phase—an expression of love through extemporized text with the insertion of certain phrase formulae, such as “kung hindi man.” The music was taken from preexisting tunes identified as awit and/or kumintang. The next stage was the semi-stylization of the musical formulae in which metric pulses of Western dances (valse, danza, fandango, etc.) were integrated into the singing style. Another stage would be the elevation of the previously extemporized text to a literary-poetic verse format by schooled writers, such as Patricio Mariano, Deogracias A. Rosario, Manuel Bernabe, and Jesus Balmori. While no longer relying on stock phrases, they nevertheless incorporated the principal thematic element in their texts—that is, the expression of unrequited and undying love, together with resignation to one’s final fate.

The final stage was the composition of the music to suit the structural and aesthetic demands of the poetic text. As developed by formally trained composers, such as Bonifacio Abdon, Francisco Santiago, and Nicanor S. Abelardo, the classical kundiman assumed the standard three-part form where the first two sections were in minor and related tonal areas and the final part was in the parallel major. The melodies were characterized by certain motivic formulae, such as the opening phrase starting on the upbeat, accenting on the second beat. Harmonically, the kundiman’s expression of uncertainty was portrayed through the various incomplete resolutions employed by composers such as Abelardo in the application of the chromatic harmony.

The era of the kundiman has been generally placed between 1800 to 1930. The year 1800 was alluded to in the folk song “Kundiman de 1800” (Kundiman of 1800) composed by Francisco Santiago, now popular among schoolchildren. The song’s serious mood was allegedly countered by its jocose lyrics when the printer of Emilia S. Reysio-Cruz’s collection of folk songs, which Santiago harmonized, pressured him to rush this particular piece. The three quatrains of this kundiman run as follows:

Doon po sa aming maralitang bayan

Nagpatay ng hayop “nik-nik” ang pangalan;

Ang taba po nito ay pinatunaw,

Lumabas na langis, siyam na tapayan.

Doon po sa aming bayan ng Malabon,

May nakita akong nagsaing ng apoy;

Palayok ay papel gayon din ang tuntong,

Tubig na malamig ang iginatong.

Doon po sa aming bayan ng San Roque

May nagkatuwaan apat na pulubi;

Nagsayaw ang pilay, kumanta ang pipi

Nanood ang bulag, nakinig ang bingi.

(In our poor town

An animal named “nik-nik” was killed;

Its fat was extracted

And the oil that poured out filled nine jars.

In our town of Malabon,

I saw someone cooking fire;

The pot was made of paper, so was the stand,

Cold water was used as fuel.

In our town of San Roque

Four beggars had some fun

The lame danced, the mute sang

The blind watched, the deaf listened.)

However, Molina stated that what could have been the true lyrics of this kundiman “as recalled by some older persons” were the following:

Sa dalampasigan ng dagat Maynila,

Luneta ang tawag ng mga Kastila,

Ay doon binaril ang kaawa-awa

Pobreng Pilipino, martir nitong lupa.

Naramay sa dusa ang ating tanggulan,

Panganay na Burgos at bunsong si Rizal,

Sa inggit at takot ng prayleng sukaban

Pinatay at sukat walang kasalanan.

(On the shores of Manila Bay,

Called Luneta by the Spaniards

There the tormented was shot

Poor Filipino, martyr of this land.

Our defenders fell into agony

Burgos, the eldest, and the youngest, Rizal

Wicked friars consumed by envy and fear

Had them killed, though they were innocent.)

Contemporary composer and critic Felipe de Leon Jr speculated that the pathos in the kundiman could be due to the Spanish practice of disallowing Filipinos from speaking about their love for country, and so they used the kundiman as a subtler medium for their nationalistic expressions. Hence the kundiman not only expresses the lofty sentiment of love but also of heroism. The kundiman “Jocelynang Baliwag” (Jocelyna of Baliwag), for example, originally dedicated to Jocelyna (Pepita) Tiongson of Baliuag, Bulacan, really addressed a bigger muse—Mother Country. It inspired many a Katipunero (Filipino revolutionary) to fight for freedom from Spain, and was called the “Kundiman ng Himagsikan” (Kundiman of the Revolution). The lyrics of this kundiman run as follows:

Pinopoong sinta,

Niring kaluluwa,

Nakakawangis mo,

Mabangong sampaga.

Dalisay sa linis,

Dakila sa ganda

Matimyas na bukal

Ng madlang ligaya.

Edeng maligayang

Kinaluluklukan

Ng galak at tuwang

Katamis-tamisan

Ada kang maningning

Na ang matunghaya’y

Masamyong bulaklak

Agad sumisikal.

(Beloved goddess

Of my soul,

You are like

The fragrant sampaga

Pure and clean,

Of noble beauty,

The genuine spring

From which flows complete joy.

Happy Eden

The throne

Of the sweetest

Joy and happiness.

You are the dazzling nymph

Whose gaze makes

The fragrant flower

Grow instantly.)

In the early decades of the 20th century, Francisco Santiago stylized the kundiman, elevating it to a higher creative plane as he fashioned a simple folk song into an appealing art song. He developed the kundiman song into national classics whose melody, text, and harmony were intertwined.

Santiago is credited with giving the kundiman a ternary or three-part form, taking it beyond its simple unitary song form. His first kundiman was “Kundiman,” also known as “Anak-Dalita” (Child of Woe), 1917, with Tagalog lyrics by Deogracias A. Rosario and Spanish text by Jesus Balmori. Other important kundiman of Santiago were “Pakiusap” (Plea) and “Madaling-Araw” (Dawn).

The kundiman that were later written by Nicanor S. Abelardo were believed to have been inspired by Santiago’s. Abelardo created some of the most famous artistic kundiman—among them, “Mutya ng Pasig” (Muse of Pasig), “Nasaan Ka Irog?” (Where Are You My Love?), and “Kundiman ng Luha” (Kundiman of Tears). In 1920 Bonifacio Abdon composed “Kundiman,” also known as “Kundiman ni Abdon” (Abdon’s Kundiman). Abdon was then the director of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, which sponsored the concert of Russian cellist Boguomil Sykora, who wanted to conduct a native composition. Abdon wrote the kundiman, with text by his brother-in-law, Patricio Mariano. It was sung for the first time by a choir. Other famous kundiman were Francisco Buencamino’s “Ang Una Kong Pag-ibig” (My First Love) and Constancio de Guzman’s “Bayan Ko” (My Country) with lyrics by Jose Corazon de Jesus. “Bayan Ko,” originally a song protesting American colonization, became the anthem of the parliament of the streets during the Marcos dictatorship.

In the pre-World War II era, the kundiman was composed to honor heroes on their birth or death anniversaries, to congratulate women on their birthdays and graduations as professionals, and as theme songs for films and organizations. Actively composing kundiman during this period were composers Castro Emiliano, Pedro Santos Gatmaitan, Gerardo Enriquez, Saturnino E. Villanueva, Facundo Perez, Dominador Rivera, Cornelio Lacsamana, Francisco Perez, Ariston Avelino, Lucino Sacramento, and Liberato Esguerra. The lyrics of these songs were provided by the composers themselves or by collaborating lyricists, among whom were Jose Katindig, Pio Ramirez, Maria M. Villanueva, Deogracias Rod. Gonzales, Florentino Ballecer, Juan Hernandez, Leoncio Reyes, Filomeno Alcaraz, and Jose Dal’ Estrella.

In the 1920s and 1930s the kundiman was used by sarsuwela composers for their love songs. Leon Ignacio created the “Kundiman ni Angelita” (Kundiman of Angelita) for Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden). In the late 1930s and in the decades after World War II, Filipino film musicals, which were really filmed sarsuwela, either used famous kundiman as title and theme songs—for example, Pakiusap, 1940—or commissioned composers to create new kundiman for the movies. Composers for the movies include Constancio de Guzman, Santiago Suarez, and Juan Silos Jr.

In the postwar era, the term kundiman has been used to mean not only a specific musico-literary form but also a style and a particular musical sentiment. As late as the 1960s, the classical kundiman formats were still employed by such composers as Lucio D. San Pedro in his “Sa Simula Ako’y Labong” (In the Beginning I Was a Bamboo Shoot), Felipe Padilla de Leon in his “Ganyan ang Pagsimba” (That Is How to Go to Church), Rosendo Santos in his “Kundiman ng Puso” (Kundiman of the Heart) and “Pighati” (Grief), and Alfredo S. Buenaventura in his “Huling Hibik ng Pilipinas” (Last Cry of the Philippines). In the second half of the 20th century, kundiman sentiment was felt in the romantic ballads of George Canseco, Leopoldo Silos, Ernani Cuenco, and Restie Umali. Current additions to the kundiman repertoire include Angel Peña’s “Sa Batis ng Ligaya” (In the Stream of Happiness), Noel Velasco’s “Mutya ng Mayon” (Muse of Mayon), Michael Dadap’s “Walang Paalam” (No Goodbye), and Joey Ayala’s “Walang Hanggang Paalam” (Never Ending Goodbye).

There has been a proliferation of recordings of kundiman in different forms in the Philippines and abroad in the 21st century. Raul Sunico’s multivolume Classic Philippine Sentiments: A Keyboard Treasury of Love Songs and Folksongs contains many kundiman arranged for solo piano. The series is made up of several albums, which include Katakataka (Surpising), Cavatina, Lambingan (Romance), Balikbayan (Filipino Returnee), and Pahimakas (Farewell). In Alaala (Memories), Sunico also devoted a complete album to the kundiman of Nicanor Abelardo. The centennial album Mga Awit ng Himagsikan 1896-1898 (Songs of the Revolution 1896-1898), 1998, was a special recording of songs of the 1896-98 Philippine Revolution, many of which have been considered written in the kundiman form. The songs were arranged by Raul Sunico and sung by the Philippine Madrigal Singers, with Lester D. Demetillo on guitar and Antonio R. Maigue on flute. In 2007, the Berlin-based duo made up of baritone Jonathan de la Paz Zaens and pianist Abelardo Galang II recorded and released an album titled Kundiman: Philippine Art Songs in Germany, the land where the genre flourished in the 19th century. Joey Ayala’s two modern kundiman, “Kundiman sa Ulap” (Kundiman in the Clouds) and “Walang Hanggang Paalam” (100">Sublime Farewell) were part of his album 16 Love Songs. Basil Valdez released The Filipino Classics, 2006, a collection of classic Filipino songs from the 1920s to the 1960s arranged by Ryan Cayabyab. The album featured the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra, which was conducted by Cayabyab.

In 1991, in an effort to generate a broader appreciation of kundiman, Hotel Nikko Manila Garden in Makati initiated the singing competition called “Kundiman Fiesta” to revive the singing of the Filipino kundiman and popularize this singing tradition among the youth. The first five years produced the following top kundiman singers: Francisco Batomalaque, 1991; Alexis Sumicat, 1992; Nolito Gregorio, 1993; Joel Saavedra, 1994; and Cherry Batalla, 1995. Due to a change in the hotel’s ownership in 1996, the annual fiesta faced an uncertain fate. The National Commission for Culture and the Arts eventually took over, and the 1996 edition was held on 4 Dec at the Folk Arts Theater, with Marya Deeda Barreto emerging as the winner. In 1995, another kundiman singing competition was started, this time by the Makati Coliseum and Cultural Affairs Office, to celebrate “Buwan ng Wika” (National Language Month) in the city. The competition, initially called “Kampeon ng Kundiman” (Kundiman Champion) and later renamed “Kundiman sa Makati” (Kundiman in Makati), has been held annually since.Written byAntonio C. Hila and Ramon P. Santos, u pdated by Arwin Q. Tan

text:
The word “liturgical” comes from the Greek “litos,” meaning people, and “ergon,” meaning work. Liturgical music accompanies the official rites of the Christian churches, and this practice is rooted in the Jewish tradition of chanting a psalm from the Old Testament as a meditative interlude between readings from the works of the prophets.

Early Christian chants were derived from Jewish chants. The codification of chanting, also called plainsong, plainchant or cantus planus (to distinguish it from measured singing or cantus mensuratus), is attributed by tradition to Pope Gregory the Great who had also reformed the entire liturgy during the sixth century. What is now known as the Gregorian chant received its final form under Pepin the Short and Charlemagne mainly at Metz. Elsewhere, other repertories developed: Roman chant (Rome), Ambrosian chant (Milan), Mozarabic chant (Spain), Gallican chant (Gaul), and Byzantine chant (Byzantium). It was, however, the Gregorian chant that superseded these chants when it was adopted as the official chant of the Catholic Church.

Gregorian chant is an enormous body of music composed of about 3,000 chants, all monophonic, with free rhythm, and sung partly by the soloist or cantor and the choir. Each chant consists of a single melody, sung either by the soloist or by the choir. It is sung without accompaniment, and the choir sings in unison. The music is in free rhythm, with no bar lines and time signatures. Instead, the music follows the rhythm of the words. The words themselves are mostly taken from the Bible, especially from the Book of Psalms. Until the 1980s, when the church began to permit translations, the chant was always sung in Latin. The music of the chants is based on the medieval church modes, rather than on the modern major and minor scales. It has its own notation written on neumes (a four-line staff with notes).

The early Christian church saw the distinction between high and low masses, and the ember days. Ember days were occasions for penance and prayer during which the lengthy “Litany of the Saints” was chanted. These were also times for priestly ordination—perhaps the most elaborate of the Catholic rites. Rites celebrating the administering of some sacraments did not require a specific music but used those appropriate to the day.

The development of liturgical music in the Philippines was said to have begun with the coming of the Spanish colonizers and the establishment of Catholicism. The Spanish educational system, established in 1596, required the Filipinos to learn how to play musical instruments, such as the organ, flute, violin, harp, and guitar. But history relates that the Filipinos’ first encounter with Christian religious music was during the Easter Sunday Mass on 31 Mar 1521, when the natives heard the chants of the Spanish priest and congregation. Priests of the different religious orders introduced European church music forms and styles. They built monasteries and churches, which became the prime centers of religious musical activities. Missionaries even used native chants to which they composed poems that explained catechism.

The Augustinians, the first missionaries to arrive, set up the first orchestra in the Philippines in 1601 in the Convent of Guadalupe in present-day Rizal province. They provided young boys with a musical education that enabled the latter eventually to teach music. Among the early Filipino music teachers were Fray Marcelo de San Agustin, an organist, singer, and composer, and Fray Juan de Alfaro, resident organist of the San Agustin Church. The Spanish curates who came to teach music in the Philippines include Juan de Bolivar, a prominent cantor who composed liturgical settings and Christmas carols aside from teaching the harp, organ, violin and flute; Lorenzo Castelo, “el Orfeo Agustiniano,” an accomplished singer-composer; Tenacio de Jesus, who wrote the convent choir books; Nicolas Sernanit, organist-teacher; and Manuel Arostegui, who promoted Filipino church music, especially the music of Marcelo Adonay, in Madrid.

Adonay, known as the “Palestrina of the Philippines,” best represents the golden age of church music in the Philippines. A gifted musician, Adonay entered the San Agustin Convent in Intramuros in 1856 and swiftly rose in rank from choirboy to composer, orchestra director, and official church organist. Among his important works were “Liberame” (Rescue Me), 1869, “Benedictus” (Blessed), 1895, “Hosana” (Praise), 1899, “Te Deum” (You Are God), and a grand mass. Adonay wrote in a pure, simple style devoid of histrionics. Other noted Filipino musicians who studied under the Augustinians include Jose Valledo, David Jamena, Pedro Navarro, and Tomas Mellaren.

The Franciscans also contributed greatly to the development of Filipino church music. Like the Augustinians before them, the Franciscans provided the natives with a musical education that eventually helped them find jobs as music teachers in Catholic schools. Among the prominent Franciscan music mentors were San Pedro Bautista, who taught music to the natives before being executed with Japanese Christians in Japan in 1597; Fr Geronimo de Aguilar, founder and director of the music school in the Franciscan Convent of Manila; Fr Juan de Santa Marta, who taught singing and the playing and making of instruments; and Fr Jose de la Virgen, who wrote Arte de Canto Gregoriano (Art of Gregorian Chant), 1727, in Manila.

The Dominicans ran a music school in the Santo Domingo Church in Manila. The organization was not as large as that of the Manila Cathedral’s. However, it was reputed to have the finest organ in the city. Liturgical music was played on the famous and unique bamboo organ of Las Piñas built by Fr Diego Cera. The organ, begun in 1816 and finished in 1824 during his stint as curate of Las Piñas, contains 950 bamboo pipes, 22 stops, 43 pipes to each register, and 12 pedals.

In 1742 the Colegio de Niños Tiples de la Santa Iglesia Catedral was founded in honor of the Blessed Trinity. It later developed a curriculum patterned after that of the Conservatory of Madrid. The faculty of the Colegio, initially staffed by priests and later by laymen, taught solfeggio, vocalization, and the playing of the organ and string instruments. Among the well-known products of the institution were Antonio Garcia, pianist-violoncellist; Simplicio Solis, composer; Salvador Piñon, violinist-flutist; Fulgencio Tolentino, pianist-composer; and Manuel Lopez, pianist-composer.

It was not uncommon then for parishes to have their own choirs, usually composed of young boys or tiples, who were taught Gregorian chant and other traditional Latin hymns in accordance with the reformed rites of the Council of Trent. Aside from the aforementioned Augustinian orchestra of Rizal, also noteworthy were the Manila Orchestra assembled by Fr Juan de Torres in 1643, and the orchestra assembled by Fr Toribio Varas in 1870, which was led by Adonay and later by Fr Arostegui. Unique in a predominantly non-Filipino repertoire was the singing of a European melody underlaid with Tagalog text, which was discovered as being part of a manuscript collection of prayers and songs in San Juan del Monte’s Dominican church, dating from the second half of the 17th century. The sheet music was titled “Letra en Tagalo” (Letters in Tagalog), presumably sung by a choir. The choir was often accompanied by a string and flute ensemble, sometimes by an orchestra, and during the 19th century, by a pipe organ.

Bohol, prior to the great earthquake of 2013, was home to seven pipe organs housed in the churches of Baclayon, Dimiao, Garcia Hernandez, Loay, Loboc, Loon, and Maribojoc. The Baclayon Church, particularly its ecclesiastical museum, was also where various cantorales (choir books) were located, including the Kirial de esta Yglesia de Baclayon Año 1826 (Sacred Music of Baclayon Church 1826), the Antifonario de esta Iglesia de Baclayon (Antiphonary of Baclayon Church), the Salterio de esta Iglesia de Baclayon (Psalms of Baclayon Church), and the Misal o Yntroitos de esta Iglesia de Baclayon Año 1827 (Missal of Baclayon Church 1827). The Kirial contained 26 musical settings of the Ordinary Mass, among which were Misa Baclayana, Misa Imperial, Misa Provincial, and Misa de Sales. These choir books with neumatic notations written in five-line staves were similar to an extant music book printed in Manila in 1872 titled Manual-Cantoral para el Uso de las Religiosas de Santa Clara de la Ciudad Manila (Songbook for the Use of the Religious of Santa Clara, Manila).

Tunes from popular and secular songs found their way into the Mass, often at communion or when there was a lull in the service, which was actually a violation of the Council of Trent’s prohibition. These tunes were apparently used at the misas de aguinaldo or simbang gabi (dawn Masses) so that around 1630, these Masses were temporarily banned. The dawn Masses were also occasions for the singing of villancicos and Christmas carols. The Misa Pastorela, accompanied by organ, strings, castanets, and tambourines, was usually sung at the midnight Mass on Christmas eve or on Christmas day itself. Aside from the rites celebrated within the church, processions outside the church were a common feature of Catholic liturgy. For the Feast of Corpus Christi, temporary wayside chapels were built along the processional path to serve as stopping points for benediction and the singing of motets during the procession. Fiestas were also important occasions for performing liturgical music. The annual Quiapo fiesta is perhaps the most pompous and spectacular of all fiestas in Manila, culminating with a High Mass and a magnificent procession in the evening. Quiapo Church services generally feature excellent organists and singers. Natalio Mata, the church’s organist, is remembered for his lamentative Siete Dolores de la Virgen (Seven Sorrows of the Virgin) often played on Good Friday services. His son, Manuel, a talented composer, succeeded him as church organist. The Carrion family—Balbino and sons Juan, Jose, and Victorino—were noted church singers. Others were Hilarion Angeles, Agapito Enriquez, Valeriano del Rosario, and Juan Salvador. The Circulo Musical, organized in 1893 by Fr Cipriano Gonzales in Pandacan, had as its goals the promotion of European music and the creation of a stimulating atmosphere for musical activity. Prominent Pandacan-born musicians include church singer Pantaleon Lopez and instrumentalist Ladislao Bonus.

In 1902, the Iglesia Filipina Independiente (IFI) was established, declaring itself free of the Vatican. A few prominent musicians of the time became members of the church and wrote masses for the new church, like Bonifacio Abdon, who wrote the Tagalog mass Misa Balintawak, 1910, and Lorenzo Ilustre, who wrote a mass for Easter with no specific title. Masses included in the 2010 compilation of the IFI titled Mga Awit sa Pagsamba para sa Diyos at Bayan (Songs of Worship for God and Country) were Misa Rizalina (Rizal Mass) by Antonio Buencamino, Misa Porvenir (Mass of the Future) by an unknown author, and Misa Bantay Kilang (Mass of Bantay Kilang) by Brigido Pablo. An earlier compilation of IFI songs was the Imnaryong Pilipino (Filipino Hymnal), 1990.

The Filipino composers of the late 19th and early 20th centuries experimented with short forms such as the “Ave Maria,” wedding songs, and short hymns. Among these were Nicanor S. Abelardo’s “Ave Maria” (Hail Mary), “Stabat Mater” (Mother Standing), “Hymn to Santa Cecilia,” and works in the vernacular, “Pananampalataya” (Faith) and “Pananalig at Pag-ibig” (Faith and Love); Manuel Velez’s “Ave Maria”; Alejo Carluen’s “Cantico a Santa Teresita del Niño Jesus” (Hymn to Saint Therese of the Child Jesus); Paulino Cadsawan’s “Ave Maria” and “Tantum Ergo”; Hipolito Rivera’s “Jaculatorios a San Jose” (Emotional Prayer to St. John); Amanda Cabrera’s “Song to Our Lady Mediatrix of All Graces”; Francisco Santiago’s “Ave Maria,” “A Nuptial Prayer,” and “O Salutaris” (Help Us); and Francisco Buencamino’s “Ave Maria.”

On his first year as pope in 1903, Pius X issued an encyclical, the “Motu Propio,” which discouraged the use of orchestras and brass bands to accompany masses and which sought to restore the solemnity and devoutness of liturgical music through the revival of the Gregorian chant. The encyclical came in the wake of a proliferation of masses that were characterized as frivolous, excessive, profane, sentimental, and lengthy. The appeal went unheeded for half a century, although considerable enthusiasm was noted among some church musicians to promote the chant. Today, the Gregorian chant is kept alive in some churches and monasteries such as the Manila Cathedral and the Benedictine Abbey.

Toward the end of the 19th century, reform-minded liturgists urged the adaptation of the Catholic Church rites to modern times. Pius X urged frequent communion and encouraged the convocation of Eucharistic congresses. These were held well into the 20th century. In 1937 an international eucharistic congress was convened in the Philippines. These congresses were occasions for the composition of vernacular hymns, which were based on extra-liturgical songs such as “Flores de Mayo” (Flowers of May), “Despedidas” (Goodbyes), “Himno al Sagrado Corazon de Jesus” (Hymn to the Sacred Heart of Jesus), and “No Mas Amor que el Tuyo” (No Greater Love than Yours), which was composed for the 1937 congress.

This was also the era of anthologies and hymnals that collected Gregorian chants, Latin hymns, and music in other languages. One of the famous collections was the Pius X Hymnal. A Philippine compilation was also published to meet the demands of reformists who urged the use of the vernacular, arguing that Latin was a barrier to understanding the rites. However, the move toward a vernacular liturgy took more than a decade to materialize. In 1965, Vatican Council II decreed the reformation and vernacularization of the liturgy through the decree Sacrosanctum Concilium (the Constitution on the Sacred Liturgy of the Second Vatican Council). As the rites had to be translated from Latin, the use of the vernacular was not substantially implemented until the 1970s.

Liturgical reform meant the simplification of rites. Gone were the ember days and the distinctions between Low and High Masses. All masses had congregational or community singing. Vernacularization spurred the growth of liturgical music in the Philippines. This followed two tracks: local composition with English lyrics and compositions in Philippine languages. The example of the African Misa Luba, which set Greek and Latin texts to African music, the experiments of Clarence Rivers with Negro spirituals, and the examples of the medical missionaries reached the Philippines and demonstrated the viability of using new tunes for worship. In the 1960s, the guitar, previously banned from worship, began to be used at guitar or folk masses. Examples of these are Sunday Mass of Kristina Benitez, 1966, some portions of which have been translated and incorporated into Cebuano hymnals; Misang Antipona, first accompanied by organ and later by guitar; and the popular Tagalog Mass by Eduardo P. Hontiveros, SJ, 1968.

Experiments using Philippine materials began by adapting folk tunes to sacred texts. Latin texts for Gregorian chants were translated into English and other languages. These early experiments produced a whole corpus of liturgical music within less than a decade. On the forefront of such composition were priests and nuns, among them Hontiveros, Ruben Habito, Nemesio Que, Fruto Ramirez, and Manuel Francisco. Masses were composed in the different languages of the region, spearheaded by groups such as the Daughters of St. Paul and the San Jose Seminary. Narcisa Fernandez and R. Villanueva composed Cebuano masses, while Pablito C. Maghari composed masses for the dioceses of Antique.

A more radical move came with the publication of Misa ng Bayang Pilipino (Mass of the Filipino Nation), which incorporated Filipino practices, like the lighting of many candles and the use of the mano po (kissing of the hand), into the Mass. It also adapted the pasyon chants. The Misa concertized Sacrosanctum Concilium’s decree that rites be adapted to the customs of a particular country. It was intended as a prototype for the further Filipinization and vernacularization of rites; however, due to bureaucratic inertia, it is now considered a historic curiosity.

In the 20th century, more contemporary and innovative forms and styles were applied to the composition of church music. At the Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music (AILM), Francisco F. Feliciano composed masses in the modern idiom and encouraged his students to compose liturgical musics that were Asian- and indigenous-inspired. Some composers, like Lucrecia R. Kasilag, Manuel P. Maramba, OSB, and Antonino Buenaventura, wrote masses based on indigenous themes. Ryan Cayabyab’s rhythmically and harmonically colorful Misa was based on structural elements of some Philippine indigenous music. Cayabyab wrote another mass with full orchestral accompaniment titled Misa 2000. This won the second prize at the quadrennial Onassis International Cultural Competitions in 2001. He completed three other masses: Mass for Peace, St. Michael’s Mass, and the Blessed Trinity Mass.

Parish church music was handled by parish choirs. The Venerable Orden Tecera (VOT) Church of San Antonio de Padua in Sampaloc, Manila, boasted of an excellent choir—the Coro Antoniano, composed of professionals and directed by Antonio J. Molina, composer of Misa Antoniana. One outstanding mass for mixed chorus was Lucio D. San Pedro’s Misa Santo Niño.

Prior to Vatican Council II, existing choirs were the Metropolitan Cathedral Choir composed of the San Carlos Seminary Choir; the boys’ choirs of Paco Catholic School, Manila Cathedral School, and Makati Catholic School; and the glee clubs of St. Scholastica’s College, St. Paul College, St. Theresa’s College, Holy Spirit College, Maryknoll College, Santa Isabel College, and San Beda College. The last decades of the 20th century witnessed the growth in the number of church choirs all over the country where a parish normally kept several groups for their numerous services on Sundays. Many of these choirs also ventured into concertizing outside of the confines of their home churches, as far as Europe and the Americas. Among the prominent church-based choirs who have become world renowned are the Hail Mary the Queen Children’s Choir, Loboc Children’s Choir, Ateneo Chamber Singers, Chorus Paulinus, Imusicapella, Kammerchor Manila, and Novo Concertante Manila.

Publishing groups and audio tapes have facilitated the diffusion of Catholic liturgical music. Among the more prominent publishing groups were the East Asian Pastoral Institute, the Society of Saint Paul, Claretian Publications, SJB (St. John Bosco) Music Company, MCB (Manila Cathedral Basilica) Music, and the Jesuit Music Ministry. Many of the popular mass songs being sung at the turn of the 21st century came from the numerous publications of the Jesuit Music Ministry, which include Himig Heswita (Jesuit Melody), 1982; Himig Heswita 2 (Jesuit Melody 2), 1994, which contained choral arrangements and a segment titled “Parangal kay Honti” (Tribute to Honti), featuring the unpublished works of Fr Eddie Hontiveros, SJ; Alay Kapwa Huwag Limutin (Brotherly Offering, Do Not Forget), 1996; Hangad: Himig at Titik (Desire: Melody and Lyrics), 1998; and Bayan Umawit (Sing, People), 2003. Following the Jesuit Music Ministry’s publications, SJB Music Company printed Lester Delgado’s Misa Delgado Book Series beginning 2008, which has eight volumes to date: Narito Ako (Here I Am), Pag-aalay (Offering), Sa Kanyang Pagdating (On His Arrival), Paglalakbay (Journey), Liwanag ng Pasko (Light of Christmas), Jesus, My Savior, Cross of Christ, and Sing to the Lord. Claretian Publications released Tinnah dela Rosa’s Gaudium Mass (Mass of Rejoicing), 2012, specifically for the new English translation of the Roman Missal, which was initiated by Pope Benedict XVI in 2010. MCB Music published Alejandro Consolacion II’s Misa Inmaculada Concepcion (Mass of the Immaculate Conception), 2007, and his Mass of St. Therese of the Child Jesus, 2013.

The mainline Protestant churches, like the Baptists, Methodists, and Episcopalians, did not gain a foothold in the Philippines until the 20th century when mission boards began sending personnel to the Philippines. More inclined toward traditional part-singing and the use of the organ, whether in choral or congregational singing, the Protestant churches enjoyed excellent sacred music. Among the more prominent Protestant choirs were the New Covenant Singers, the AILM Chorale, His Sounds, and the Ellinwood Chancel Choir.

The Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music, as an institution, actively propagated the use of indigenous musical materials and ideas in worship. It graduated many Asian church musicians who became active in their respective countries, invigorating worship by the inclusion of cultural elements in their rites, particularly music. Among the institution’s projects was the compilation of hymnals of world music gathered from the various Christian churches of Asia, Sound the Bamboo CCA Hymnal, published by GIA Publications Inc, 2000. The institution also published its AILM Collection: Hymns, Psalms, and Songs for Worship in 2005.

The rise of charismatic groups and Pentecostal churches characterized the religious atmosphere of the 1980s. These groups used simple repetitive songs for the unstructured prayer meeting. The more complex Gospel music was sung for meditative interludes. The term “Gospel” encompassed a variety of contemporary musical idioms, such as jazz, rock, disco, ballads, and rap with biblical or religious lyrics. All these were also called inspirational music. A whole industry of Gospel music grew with the spread of these groups. Gospel music was also performed in concert halls. Although such performances might have appeared to be pure entertainment, they had a noble purpose and were seen as extensions of worship.

These concerts were a form of evangelism, which counteracted widespread secular music considered to be destructive of Christian values. Prominent performers of Gospel music include Ray-an Fuentes, Carlo Orosa, Pinky Marquez, Carla Martinez, Joanne Lorenzana, Edward Granadosin, Tricia Amper-Jimenez, Steve Cadd, Joel Navarro, Gary Granada, and Gary Valenciano. Praise Inc became one of the more established producers of Gospel music.Written by Rene B. Javellana and Maria Patricia Brillantes, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

Sources:

Bañas 1975; Chua 2010; “Gregorian Chant” 1964; “History of Sacred Music” 1967; Irving 2010; Molina 1961; Raymundo 1972; Tan 2014a.

text:
The marcha or march is music with simple, strongly marked rhythm (4/4) and regular phrases, designed to accompany marching groups or some dances. Marches vary in tempo, ranging from the slow and stately, such as those for funerals, to the very brisk, like the marches of John Philip Sousa. Some folk dances, like the chotis lallo or chotis vintarina, use march music in moderate tempo. Plays like the komedya and the sinakulo utilize different kinds of marcha. In the komedya, major entrances and exits necessitate marches. Christians, kings, and queens are accompanied by a slow marcha. Fast exits and entrances are done to the beat of the paso doble, a double-time march. The punebre or funeral march accompanies the mournful wailings of a widowed queen or a princess in anguish. In the sinakulo, entrances of the hudyo (jews) are accompanied by the lively paso doble, while entrances of the banal (holy) are accompanied by the punebre. The resurrection and ascension of Christ are sometimes accompanied by the Philippine National Anthem.

The numerous military and town bands that proliferated during the Spanish colonial period included marches from Europe and the United States in their repertoires. The bands played serenatas or open-air concerts in the calzada and Luneta in Manila as well as town plazas everywhere. They were integral parts of the town fiesta celebrations and religious processions.

Marches were composed at various times in Philippine history to support certain political aims. In the revolution against Spain, the “Alerta Katipunan” (Katipunan, Alert) rallied many a Katipunero (Philippine revolutionary) toward battle, while the “Marcha Magdalo” (Magdalo March), originally composed by Julian Felipe for Emilio Aguinaldo, became the Philippine National Anthem. Under the American colonial government, a few marches were written, including Antonino Buenaventura’s “Triumphal March,” 1930, and Lucio San Pedro’s “Mabuhay ang Kasarinlan” (Hail to Independence), 1938. To support Filipino-owned companies threatened by American monopoly interests, composers were commissioned to write promotional music, such as the “Germinales” march composed by Jose A. Estella for the Germinal Tobacco Factory.

During the Japanese occupation, Felipe Padilla de Leon’s “Awit sa Paglikha ng Bagong Pilipinas” (Song for the Creation of a New Philippines), with text by Catalino Dionisio, virtually replaced the national anthem. Other marches of the period were Padilla de Leon’s “Dai-itiw ng Kalibapi,” Lucio D. San Pedro’s “Martsa ng Bagong Pilipinas” (March of the New Philippines) and “President Laurel March,” and Francisco Santiago’s “Magkakapitbahay-Martsa” (Neighborhood March).

The march was also used by anti-Japanese forces, particularly the Hukbo ng Bayan Laban sa Hapon (People’s Army against the Japanese) or Hukbalahap. Marches called people to assemble for a meeting or a performance. Among the more popular marches then were “Hukbalahap ng Bayan” (Hukbalahap of the People) of Nueva Ecija and “Pamisan Metung a Panig Mitatag Ya” (A United Front Let Us Establish) of Pampanga. The Hukbalahap also did their own version of “Awit sa Paglikha ng Bagong Pilipinas” (Song for the Creation of a New Philippines), which denounced Filipino collaborators.

After World War II, many band musicians composed marches. These were Antonino Buenaventura’s “Defenders of Democracy March,” 1948, “National Defense March,” 1953, “President Magsaysay March,” 1954, and “Brown Brothers March,” 1955; Hilarion F. Rubio’s “Silahis March” (New Day March), 1980; Felipe Padilla de Leon’s “Bagong Pagsilang March” (New Birth March), 1972; and Lucio San Pedro’s “Festival March,” 1969, “Golden Heart March,” 1971, “Angononian March,” 1972, and “Maharlika March” (Nobility March), 1979.

A march not intended for the brass band but for the chorus and piano was composed by Angel Peña in 1989, titled “Awit ng mga Sakada” (Song of the Seasonal Cane Workers). It was funded by the US Philippine General Consulate, and it won the first prize in the Pagdiriwang ’96 Centennial Commission composition contest. Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

Sources:

Apel 1974; Cruz 1971; The National Artists of the Philippines 1998; Peña 2007; Samson 1976; Tiongson 1975.

text:
A novelty song is a song that is created primarily for its humorous, lighthearted lyrics and characterized by unusual musical styles and techniques. The term originates from the American music industry and, though it may not be widely used among Philippine audiences, such music has always been enjoyed by many Filipinos. Locally, musicians or listeners alike would simply refer to such songs as kantang nakakatawa (funny song).

Novelty songs may take the form of a parody. Fred Panopio created several songs in the American “cowboy” style (country music), a good example of which was “Ang Kawawang Cowboy” (The Pitiful Cowboy), which parodied Glen Campbell’s “Rhinestone Cowboy.” Dyords Javier recorded what inadvertently became the first Filipino rap recording, “Na Onseng Delight” (Duped Delight), which got its inspiration from Sugarhill Gang’s “Rapper’s Delight.” Certainly, the borrowing of an existing melody or any musical element and their reinsertion in another culture became a source of humor.

American pop music, being a primary influence, is a rich source for Philippine novelty music. In the borrowing, it is often the cultural reception that gives a comical element to the music, which may not be present in the original. The yodeling in American country music, for example, was not perceived to be a novelty or a funny way of using the voice by the American audiences, but it became both in Philippine novelty songs. When rap music became popular, its lack of melody and greater focus on rhythm was perceived to be a new way of making music. It was this novelty that led to people labeling Philippine rap as novelty songs.

Novelty songs are also inspired by fads or current events. In 1966, talk of aswang (ghoul) menacing Manila inspired the Big Three Sullivans to record “Aswang,” whose melody was based on Antonino Buenaventura’s “Pandangguhan.” In the 1980s, radio announcer Johnny Midnight became a sensation and created a controversy with his “toning” therapy. Inspired by this, the group Tatlong Pinoy sang “Toning,” which borrowed the melody from “Banana Boat.” Later in the same decade, political tensions in the Middle East, which directly concerned many overseas contract workers, inspired Lady Diane to sing the rap novelty song “Sa-Sa-Saddam.”

Several novelty songs became a celebration or a lamentation of day-to-day predicaments or concerns. Rapasia’s song “Hoy! Tsismosa” (Hey! Gossip Girl) complained of a gossipy girl. Champion bike racer Jesus “Jess” Garcia Jr recorded “Buhay Siklista” (A Cyclist’s Life), relating the ups and downs of such a life. Bobby Gonzales sang about the confusions and difficulties in courtship in “Hahabol-Habol” (Chasing After). Novelty songs also served as a mild form of protest about a controversial issue in society. The Big Three Sullivans sang “Nagbomba si Candida” (Candida Goes Nude), a song asking a sweetheart why she went nude on film. Yoyoy Villame’s “Likas Yaman” (Natural Resources) complained of the exploitation of natural resources. The male vocal Pop trio APO Hiking Society’s “American Junk” was a song protesting pervasive American cultural influence. Interestingly, most of the songs were in English.

Some novelty songs gave the listener advice, such as Andrew E.’s “Humanap Ka ng Panget” (Look for an Ugly One) and Yoyoy Villame’s “Mag-Exercise Tayo Tuwing Umaga” (Let’s Exercise Every Morning). Most certainly, sexual humor also was well represented. Pacing and Tacing’s “Ipasok Mo Na” (Put It In) and the Big Three Sullivans’ “Pagbigyan Mo Ako” (Give In to Me) were illustrations. Novelty songs may even be of a totally nonsensical nature as in Yoyoy Villame’s “Butsikik” and “Motokoy.”

Novelty songs have surely been around even before the term was adopted, what with the Filipino’s penchant for humor. Sylvia La Torre sang them in the 1950s and 1960s in addition to her repertoire as the “Kundiman Queen” and as a popular folk, pop, and classical musician. She recorded “Waray Waray,” “Bahala Na” (Come What May), “Puting Texas” (White Fighting Cock), “Galawgaw” (Impish Girl), “Golpe de Gulat” (Kick of Surprise), “No Money, No Honey,” and many others, all with a folk instrumental background of chamber string group composed of violins or rondalla instruments.

Later on, the influence of rock and roll started to filter through. For example, “Hello Party Line” by Bobby Gonzales had a heavier use of horns and included a drum set and electric guitar. Still later, a heavier rock and roll flavor was used in his “Hahabol-Habol.” Other comic artists who recorded during this period were Apeng Daldal with “Sa Loob ng Sine” (Inside the Movie House), Elizabeth Ramsey with “Magapatuka Na Lang Ako sa Ahas” (I’d Rather Be Bitten by a Snake), and the ReyCard Duet with “Katabi Ko’y Mamaw / Alis Diyan” (A Ghoul’s Beside Me / Get Out) which was inspired by The Rivingtons’ “Papa-Oom-Mow-Mow.” Even balladeer Pilita Corrales, dubbed “Asia’s Queen of Songs,” made a contribution to the novelty song tradition with “Ako ang Nagbayo” (I Pounded [the Unhusked Rice]).

The 1970s brought in the “teenage idol” craze and Nora Aunor recorded “Pearly Shells,” a local hit that prompted the Big Three Sullivans to parody it with “Kanin Baboy” (Pig Slop). Winnie Santos, aspiring young star and sister of then teen star Vilma Santos, made a contribution to the novelty song list with “Split na Tayo” (Let’s Part Ways). Tarzan and Baby Jane, a father and daughter duo, specialized in the genre and recorded several songs, among them “Sari-saring Kapit Bahay” (All Sorts of Neighbors), “Tayo’y Maglaro” (Let’s Play), “Baby Ko” (My Baby), “Tipitinpitin,” and “Babay Na sa Daddy” (Say Goodbye to Daddy). Bebeng Samson specialized in songs with a gay or homosexual theme, such as “Hoy Mestiso!” (Hey, Mestizo), “Manuela,” and “Luha sa Luneta” (Tears in Luneta), which was sourced from Eddie Peregrina’s “Memories of Our Dreams.” The Hotdog Band, a popular pop-rock combo of that time, recorded “Ikaw ang Miss Universe ng Buhay Ko” (You Are the Miss Universe of My Life), which, although clearly a love song, may be considered a novelty since it expressed love in an unusual way. The folk singer Cinderella recorded a song along similar lines in “T.L. Ako sa Yo” (I’m Truly in Love with You) when she expressed love heavily using the slang of the times. This decade also heralded the start of Tito, Vic, and Joey’s (Sotto, Sotto, and de Leon, respectively) Tough Hits album series. They eventually produced a total of 12 albums.

Disco music was at its height in the 1970s and 1980s. This inspired several Filipino artists to create new material in the genre or to parody disco hits. The male singing group Hagibis was partly inspired by the American group Village People. Hagibis recorded such novelty-disco hits as “Katawan” (Body), “Legs,” and “Nanggigigil” (Irresistible Urge). Yoyoy Villame’s “Mr. Robot-bot” was another disco-inspired novelty song.

The 1980s and 1990s brought on a surging interest in rap music. The new aesthetics of this musical style provided fertile ground from which the novelty song could sprout. Rapper Andrew E. (Andrew Espiritu in real life) is best known for his hit “Humanap Ka ng Panget” (Look for an Ugly One), and other rap pieces like “Banyo Queen” (Bathroom Queen), “Wag Kang Gamol” (Don’t Be an Ass), “Bastos Daw” (Rude, They Say), and “Binibirocha.” Michael V. (Beethoven del Valle Bunagan in real life but also known as Bitoy) started his comic career by releasing “Ang Ganda-Ganda Niya” (She’s So Beautiful), a rap piece that served as a retort to Andrew E.’s “Humanap Ka ng Panget.” Still another example of novelty rap would be the Rap trio Salbakuta’s “Stupid Love” and “Jumboday.” Later on in this period, rock combo ensembles gained popularity, and the group Parokya ni Edgar created a string of originals in the novelty tradition, such as “Mr. Suave” (Mr. Smooth), “Picha Pie,” “The Yes, Yes Show,” “Silvertoes,” “Don’t Touch My Birdie,” “Maniwala Ka Sana” (Hopefully, You Believe), and “Mang Jose” (Mister Jose).

The coming of the new century saw an explosion of novelty songs and artists. Representative of this period were Michael V’s non-rap “Hindi Ako Bakla” (I’m Not Gay); Blakdyak’s “Bikining Itim” (Black Bikini), a remake of Bert Dominic’s 1970s novelty song, and “Modelong Charing” (Gay Model); Tuesday Vargas’s “Babae Po Ako” (I’m a Girl); Bayani Agbayani’s “Otso-otso” (Eight-Eight), “Si Misis” (The Missus), and “Atras Abante” (Backward Forward); Gladys and the Boxer’s “Sasakyan Kita” (I’ll Indulge You); and Vhong Navarro’s “Totoy Bibo” (Smart-aleck Totoy), “Don Romantiko” (Master Romantic) “Pamela One,” “Cha Cha Cha,” and “Kanta Tayo” (Let’s Sing). Also of note were female and male singing groups that produced novelty songs with a heavily suggestive sexual flavor: the Sexbomb Girls’ “Spaghetti Song” and “’Di Ko Na Mapipigilan” (I Can’t Contol It Any Longer); Masculados’ “Jumbo Hotdog,” “Nakaka …” (Inducing …), and “Sana Mama” (Hopefully, Mama); and Viva Hot Babes’ “Bulaklak” (Flower), “Kikay” (Crazy Girl), “Basketbol” (Basketball), and “Batuta ng Pulis” (Policeman’s Nightstick).

The performers themselves composed many of the songs mentioned. But there were also those who specialized in composing music for others. Mar Lopez, founder of the Big Three Sullivans, also composed music for several novelty singers from the 1960s onward, such as Bebeng Samson, and Tarzan and Baby Jane. Another prolific novelty song composer, Lito Camo began to be heard in the late 1990s through such performers as Sexbomb Dancers, Bayani Agbayani, Viva Hotbabes, Masculados, April Boy, Angelica Jones, and Ai-Ai de las Alas.

It must be noted that if there is a great body of novelty song material produced in the national language, there are also songs of this genre in other Philippine languages. The most vibrant representation would be in the Visayan language, with Yoyoy Villame (who interestingly also composed songs in Ilocano) and his associate Max Surban being most prolific contributors. Villame’s “Kinilao” (Raw Food) and “Islahanon” (Islander) and Surban’s “Kolokoy” (Jester), “Tilawan Ta” (I’ll Taste), “Silhig Airline” (Broomstick Airline), and “Albularyong Buta” (Blind Quack Doctor) exemplify novelty songs in Visayan. Indeed, the richness of the Philippine novelty song tradition speaks of the lighthearted manner in which Filipinos take on the joys and trials that cross their paths.Written byJose Valenciano

text:
The opera, which means “work” in Italian and “works” in Latin, is a sung drama primarily accompanied by instruments. It consists of an instrumental overture, arias (solo songs), duets, trios, quartets, quintets, sextets, choruses, and other vocal combinations, and instrumental interludes. Its creation demands a librettist, composer, and often a choreographer; its staging requires a soloist, choristers, instrumentalists, dancers, conductor, stage director, set, costume and lighting designers, and other components of a theatrical production.

 

An opera usually consists of one to several major divisions or acts, which are sometimes divided into scenes. The first act is usually preceded by an overture, the instrumental prologue that introduces the work, and consists of principal themes to be developed in the opera. Arias are elaborate solo songs expressing a character’s reaction to an emotional situation, while recitatives are half-spoken and half-sung passages, which carry the action to the next aria. Vocal duos, trios, quartets, quintets, sextets, as well as choral, ballet, or intermezzo (additional instrumental numbers), provide variety and fuse drama and theater with the most dominant element—music.

 

Introduced by European opera companies that visited the Philippines periodically since the late 1860s, opera was a major attraction in Manila in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. For its inauguration in 1860, the Teatro del Principe Alfonso featured a French opera company directed by Maugard. In 1868, an opera company directed by Stefani first performed in the same theater. The Assi-Panades Italian opera company performed at the Circo Teatro de Bilibid in 1874. Other performances followed: Faust at Teatro Variedades, 1882; Lucia di Lammermoor at Teatro de Tondo, 1886 and 1888; and Carmen, Ernani, and Aida at Teatro Zorrilla, 1894. In some of these performances, such as the one circa 1877, local orchestras were conducted by European conductors.

 

 

The Filipino Opera Company, founded in 1887 by Ladislao Bonus, presented Fra Diavolo, Lucrezia Borgia, Linda di Chamounix, Lucia di Lammermoor, and La Traviata. Based in the Pandacan Theater, it was the first company to feature an all-Filipino lineup of soloists, chorus, and orchestra conducted by Bonus himself.

 

The theaters were always crowded, particularly on Sunday nights. One theater held about 15,000 people paid the government a revenue of 5,000 pesos a year. Operas were very popular, and plays with plenty of villains or plots that had touches of immorality would run for weeks. As plays progressed, boys went about selling cigars and sweet meats. Smoking was permitted, and clouds of smoke toward the close of performance often obscured a view of the stage. The audiences, while critical, were also exceedingly enthusiastic. Firefighters with hoses in hand were visibly present in the theater, ever ready to put out any accidental fire that might be ignited by oil lamps. Frequently the opera lasted until two o’clock in the morning, as the audience was given time between acts to obtain refreshments at the numerous restaurants in the vicinity of the theater.

 

After a brief interruption caused by the 1896 Revolution and the Philippine-American War, opera presentations resumed in 1902. In four months, about 40 operas were presented at the Teatro Zorrilla, including Il Trovatore, Cavalleria Rusticana, Lucia di Lammermoor, Aida, and Carmen. An Italian company arrived in Nov 1906, and in a four-month season presented 30 operas at the Manila Grand Opera House, including I Puritani, La Sonnambula, Norma, Tosca, Ernani, L’Africana, Manon, La Gioconda, Aida, Il Guarany, and Les Huguenots. In the next season, 22 operas were staged in 48 subscription shows and 18 special performances at the Manila Grand Opera House. The works include Aida, Lucia di Lammermoor, Il Trovatore, La Traviata, Rigoletto, La Favorita, Un Ballo in Maschera, Faust, La Boheme, Il Barbiere di Siviglia, La Sonnambula, Tosca, La Gioconda, and Fedora. Conductor Jose Estella was cited for his outstanding performance in some of these operas.

 

In 1933, opera performed by Filipinos was revived by maestro de canto Victorino Carrion, conductor Bonifacio Abdon, and impresario Juan Javier. Under the auspices of the Manila Chamber Music Society, Aida was staged on 2 Feb at the Manila Grand Opera House, followed by La Traviata on 2 May, Cavalleria Rusticana on 2 Aug, and Lucia di Lammermoor on 5 Sep, all in 1933. Madame Butterfly was presented on 17 Sep 1933, featuring the celebrated diva Jovita Fuentes as Cio Cio San, as well as May Jewett, Adolfo Belloti (a visiting Italian tenor), and Jose Corominas.

 

From the 1950s to the 1990s, a few foreign operas continued to be staged in their original form, but the majority that were produced were already either Philippine adaptations or translations of foreign operas or, more significantly, original Filipino operas. Among the foreign operas produced in this half century were Die Fledermaus (The Bat), 1954; Die Entführung aus dem Serail (The Abduction from the Seraglio), 1964; The Unicorn, The Gorgon, and the Manticore, 1965; Cavalleria Rusticana and I Pagliacci, 1966; L’Amico Fritz, 1967; La Traviata, 1970; Le Nozze di Figaro, 1983; and L’Enfant Prodigue, 1989 and 1991.

 

At the turn of the 21st century, many western operas were staged, through the concerted efforts of various institutions: CCP, UP College of Music, UST Conservatory of Music, and the Philippine Opera Company. These included Der Schauspieldirektor and Pagliacci, 2006; Eugene Onegin, 2006; La Serva Padrona and Dido and Aeneas, 2007; Die Fledermaus and La Boheme, 2008; Hansel and Gretel, 2008; La Traviata, 2012; Madama Butterfly, 2012; and Rusalka, 2014.

 

Many foreign opera libretti were also translated into Tagalog. Patricio Mariano translated Lucia di Lammermoor in 1933 and act 3 of La Traviata in 1934; Florentino Ballecer, La Traviata in 1958 and Cavalleria Rusticana in 1959; Iñigo Ed. Regalado, Lucia di Lammermoor in 1964 and Rigoletto in 1965; Jose P. Santos, Mignon in 1966 and Un Ballo in Maschera in 1967; and Manuel Car Santiago, Carmen in 1956, which was adapted to a 19th century Philippine setting. La Traviata and La Boheme were adapted to a Manila setting by Rolando Tinio in 1991 and 1992, respectively, for CCP.

 

 

Original Filipino operas were created in the early 1900s—among them, Sangdugong Panaguinip (Dreamed Alliance), libretto in one act with five scenes, translated into Tagalog by Roman Reyes from the original Spanish by Pedro Paterno, music by Ladislao Bonus, and staged at Teatro Zorrilla in Aug 1902; Magdapio, libretto in four acts by Paterno, translated by Reyes, music by Alejo Carluen, and staged at Teatro Zorrilla in 1902; Gayuma (Love Potion), libretto in three acts by Paterno, translated by Reyes, music by Alejo Carluen, and staged at Teatro Zorrilla; Lakambini (Muse), libretto in three acts by Patricio Mariano with introduction by Jose Estella, and staged at Metropolitan Theater on 19 Dec 1933; Rizal y los Dioses (Rizal and the Gods), libretto in three acts by Aurelio Tolentino, music by Simplicio Solis, and staged in 1903; Mi Futuro Esposo (My Fiancé), libretto in three acts, music by Tereso Zapata; El Talisman (The Talisman), libretto in three acts, music by Tereso Zapata; and Veni, Vidi, Vici (I Came, I Saw, I Conquered), libretto in one act by Jose Estella.

 

Sangdugong Panaguinip, set in the 16th century on the banks of the Pasig River, is about the conflict between the people of Pasig, Cainta, and Antipolo, and the Muslim pirates who claimed young maidens from the area as tribute. Lapu, in a dream, sees an alliance between the Philippines and America that will help rescue the maidens. The incorporation of the “Spanish March,” the “Star-Spangled Banner,” and the Philippine National Anthem underscored the pro-American message of the opera. Lakambini, on the other hand, is a story of the ill-fated lovers Gat Balagtas and Lakambini whose union is aborted by Balagtas’s conscription and death in a war against foreign invaders. Lakambini asks to die rather than suffer a life without her beloved in a country ruled by aliens.

 

There were two significant unfinished operas on record: Sa Mayumo (In Mayumo), libretto in two acts by Patricio Mariano, with music by Francisco Santiago; and Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), with music by Nicanor S. Abelardo. Both works pointed the way, though, for future operas with their Filipino libretti originally in the vernacular and based on local themes and stories.

 

As opera gained a wider audience, organizations supporting the art were formed, including the Manila Chamber Music Society, Islanders Choral Society, National Opera Company, Artists Guild of the Philippines, Opera Guild of the Philippines, Music Theater Foundation of the Philippines, Zarzuela Foundation, and Philippine Opera Company, as well as the government’s Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines (MPFP) and Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

 

In the post-World War II era, a number of composers created operas inspired by the life and works of Jose Rizal. The first was Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), based on Rizal’s novel. The three-act work on the libretto by Guillermo Tolentino was premiered at the Far Eastern University (FEU) Auditorium on 5 Feb 1957 by the MPFP. Written in the style of the verismo opera composers (Puccini, Mascagni, Leoncavallo), Padilla de Leon’s opera featured a music that was inspired by the dramatic and highly emotional events of the story. Maria Clara’s beautiful aria for soprano, “Kay Tamis ng Buhay” (How Sweet Is Life), Sisa’s coloratura aria “Awit ni Sisa” (Sisa’s Song), and the duets “Idilio sa Azotea” (Idyll in the Azotea) and “Sa Lupang Pangako” (In the Promised Land) for the lovers Maria Clara and Ibarra were fine examples of the intensely dramatic portions of the work.

 

Felipe Padilla de Leon’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion), based on Rizal’s second novel, was premiered on 8 Nov 1970 at the CCP, jointly sponsored by the CCP and the MPFP. Anthony Morli wrote the libretto with Tagalog-language consultant Eduardo P. de Leon. More intense, tragic, and revolutionary, Fili had less of Noli’s humor, idealism, or romance. Its music featured elaborate treatment of the rhythms of the balitaw, danza, kundiman, kumintang, and awit (metrical romance).

 

Another Rizal-inspired opera was Binhi ng Kalayaan (Seeds of Freedom) by Eliseo M. Pajaro, in three acts with a prologue and libretto by Ricardo R. Pascual. Commissioned by the Rizal Centennial Commission, it was premiered on 30 Dec 1962 at the FEU Auditorium. The work focused on Rizal’s thoughts from the time of his exile to his imminent martyrdom. A musical breakthrough, Binhi (Seed) was the first Filipino opera written in the 20th-century neoclassic idiom. The use of the Philippine and Spanish national anthems projected the conflict between the ardent desire of the Filipinos to be free from the tyrannical rule of Spain.

 

Composers also based works on the lives of other historical figures. Pajaro’s second opera, the three-act Balagtas at Selya (Balagtas and Selya) with libretto by Dionisio Salazar, premiered at the CCP on 21 Jul 1978, with the composer conducting. The opera tells the tragic love story of Balagtas and Selya. Through the machinations of a rival, Balagtas is sent to jail where he composes “Kay Selya” (To Celia) and most of Florante at Laura. Selya marries the jailer against her will. “Bakit?” (Why?) for soprano and “Huling Paalam” (Last Farewell) for baritone were well-known arias from this opera.

 

Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s three-act Diego Silang was commissioned by the MPFP and premiered on 14 Mar 1968 at the FEU Auditorium. Diego Silang, leader of the Ilocano, revolted against the Spaniards and was killed by the traitor Miguel Vicos. To avenge his death, his wife Gabriela continued the struggle. Buenaventura wrote four other operas: Maria Makiling, 1963, libretto in three acts by Iñigo Ed. Regalado; Alamat ng Pinya (Legend of the Pineapple), 1970, libretto in two acts by Felicitas Reyes; Princesa Urduja (Princess Urduja), 1970, libretto in three acts by Regalado; and Hinilawod, 1973, libretto in three acts with prologue by Regalado. Maria Makiling is about a maiden, variously referred to as a fairy, a goddess, or half-nymph, whose acts of kindness are recounted in the legends about her. Alamat ng Pinya concerns the origin of the pineapple according to a Mindanao myth. Princesa Urduja is about a legendary pre-Spanish princess-warrior in Pangasinan. Hinilawod is based on a Panay epic of the same name as recorded by F. Landa Jocano. Buenaventura’s musical style combined the conventional and contemporary with clear, melodic fines supported by contemporary harmonies and rhythmic organization.

Lucino T. Sacramento’s three-act Florante at Laura, 1973, with libretto by Servando de los Angeles, was commissioned by the MPFP and presented in cooperation with the CCP. Based on the awit by Francisco Balagtas, the opera showed traces of Abelardo’s lyricism, which matched the eloquence of Balagtas’s verses. Sacramento’s other opera, the one-act Pagmamahalan (Loving), 1969, with libretto by Regalado, extolled Philippine rural life and values. It was commissioned by Centro Escolar University.

 

Lucrecia R. Kasilag wrote the one-act opera Si Pagong at si Matsing (The Turtle and the Monkey), 1984, with libretto by Rene O. Villanueva. It was based on the folktale “The Monkey and the Tortoise” narrated by Jose Rizal in his Two Eastern Fables. Why Flowers Bloom in May, Kasilag’s last major work that she finished in early 2007, tells the story of the sun king Rayo and his devotion to his beloved earth maiden, Mara, who tends to her flowers. The libretto was written by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio.

 

Francisco F. Feliciano’s three-act La Loba Negra (The Black She-Wolf), 1984, with libretto by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, was commissioned and premiered by the Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines at the CCP. Based on the novel wrongly attributed to Fr Jose Burgos, the work tells of the assassination of the reformist Spanish governor-general Don Fernando Bustamante and the revenge taken by his wife Luisa aka La Loba Negra. Feliciano’s expressionistic writing identified with the early atonalists, and the use of pasyon chants and dark orchestral colors complemented the intensely dramatic plot. Another opera written by Feliciano was Sikhay sa Kabila ng Paalam (Zeal despite Goodbye), with libretto by Sedfrey Ordoñez and Beth Puyot, and direction by Anton Juan. A music drama based on Jose Rizal’s “Mi Ultimo Adios” (My Last Farewell), it was premiered in Dec 1993 at the Rizal Park. His third opera, Ashen Wings, was composed in 1995, with libretto by Anton Juan Jr and Beth Puyot. It was first performed at the Samba Likhaan Open Air Theater in 1995, and was staged later that year in New York. The opera tackled the problems of land grabbing, the imposition of alien cultural and political values on the indigenous psyche, consumerism and capital materialism, and the issue of power, set in a changing space and time that alternated between the present and the past. Feliciano’s last opera, Dangal ng Lahi (Honor of the Race), with libretto by Beth Puyot, tells the story of the life and martyrdom of former chief justice Jose Abad Santos and was premiered in 2000.

 

In 1996, Jeffrey Ching composed Rendezvous in Venice, with Daniel Huang as his co-librettist. It was a rewriting of his own Masquerade produced in 1978 with Noel Velasco and Tessie Agana Santos. The three-act opera was premiered on 30 Jun 1996 at the CCP Main Theater with Andion Fernandez and Nolyn Cabahug in the lead roles. Another theatrical work by Jeffrey Ching was the dramatic cantata Rizal, which focuses on the significant events in Rizal’s life and the sufferings endured by his family. The playwright was Leonor Orosa Goquinco. It was staged on 30-31 May 1997 in Makati. Das Waisenkind (The Orphan) by Jeffrey Ching was commissioned by Theater Erfurt Germany, and had its premiere in Nov 2009. It was a multicultural music theater with libretto in seven languages, a large orchestra that combined traditional symphonic and electronic instruments, and a huge case of opera singers, speaker, mimes, chorus, and dancers. It was an opera in two acts. The opera was awarded by the Theater Erfurt Audience Prize as the best opera production of its 2009-10 season. Ching’s fourth work for theater, Before Brabant, 2014, was a chamber opera commissioned by the Hong Kong Arts Festival, and inspired by Robert Copland’s The Knyght of the Swanne, written in 1512, one of the many sources of Wagner’s “Lohengrin,” which was set in Brabant. It was premiered on 18 Mar 2014 at the Hong Kong Ampitheater as part of the 2014 Hong Kong Arts Festival, which commissioned Ching for the work.

 

Based on Luna’s masterpiece, the opera Spoliarium, with music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, who was inspired to write the libretto after reading Santiago Pilar’s book Juan Luna: The Filipino as Painter, debuted at the CCP Main Theater under the direction of Alex Cortez in Feb 2003. Jerry Dadap’s Lorenzo Ruiz, Escribano (Lorenzo Ruiz, Court Clerk), with libretto by Ophelia Dimalanta, translated into Filipino by Florentino Hornedo, is about the life of the first Filipino saint, Lorenzo Ruiz. Its premiere production was presented by the University of Santo Tomas in Feb 1994 under the direction of Isagani Cruz. Another full-length opera on Rizal was Rizal: Mga Huling Araw, composed by Ed Parungao, with libretto by Frank Gomez, and direction by Tony Espejo. It was staged at the CCP Main Theater on 29 and 30 Dec 1995. Lapu-Lapu the Opera, a neoclassic work with a fusion of ethnic and rock music on the story of the country’s first hero, was staged at the CCP Main Theater in Jan 1997. Its music was composed by Jose Gentica V, with libretto by Henry Tejero, and choreography by Denisa Reyes. In Nov 1997, Mayo, Bisperas ng Liwanag (May, The Eve of Light), composed by Reynaldo Paguio, with libretto by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, had its premiere at the AFP Theater in Camp Aguinaldo. The story was an adaptation of Nick Joaquin’s “May Day Eve.” A story on a Japanese lord, Justus Takayama, who was exiled to the Philippines for professing his Catholic faith in the 16th century, was the inspiration for the opera The Venerable Lord Takayama Okun. The libretto was by Edward Tuazon-Ishita, and the music was composed by Manuel Maramba, OSB. It was staged at the Philamlife Auditorium on 29-31 Aug 2003. Chino Toledo’s San Andres B., with libretto by Virgilio Almario and direction by Floy Quintos, premiered on 29 Nov 2013 at the CCP Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino.

 

Several Filipino operas, including the pioneering works, were cast in a Western musical mold and language, whether romantic, neoromantic, modern, or a combination of these. Although opera was not fully Filipinized, the composers’ nationalism was expressed in allusions to or quotations of folk themes and folk styles. Their sentiments were also reflected in the use of Tagalog libretti based on Philippine literature, myths, legends, epics, peasant life, and episodes from national history.

As operas in the early 1930s began to feature an all-Filipino cast, many opera singers achieved prominence and recognition. Besides Jovita Fuentes, pre-World War II opera singers of note include Mercedes Matias, Isang Tapales, Montserrat Iglesias, Enya Gonzales, Tinay Arellano, Dalisay Aldaba, Salvacion Oppus, Fely Vallejo, Vicente Villanueva, and Enrique Gonzales. Operas presented during the Japanese occupation featured Nenita Farias, Carmen Bernabe, Lourdes Corrales, Nelia Legazpi, Jose Corominas, Aristeo Velasco, Camilo Cristobal, Soledad Abdon, Vicente Vera, and Octavio Cruz.

 

After World War II, notable opera singers who dominated the opera stage from the 1950s to the 1970s were Conchita Gaston, Aurelio Estanislao, Irma Potenciano, Armida Siguion-Reyna, Conching Rosal, Constantino Bernardez, Remedios Bosch-Jimenez, Mitos Sison, Juanita Javier Torres, Dolly Buencamino-Francia, Catalina Zandueta, Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, Rosie Farol, Evelyn Mandac, Eleanor Calbes, Gamaliel Viray, Don David, Vicente Antiporda, Rodolfo Reyno, Reynaldo Fuentes, Emmanuel Gregorio, and Noel Velasco.

 

From the 1970s to the early decades of the 21st century, another generation of singers emerged, among them Andion Fernandez, Nanette Moscardon-Maigue, Josephine Roces, Rachelle Gerodias, Josie Garlit Bailen, Johanna Cabili, Jai Sabas-Aracama, Alegria Ferrer, Anna Feleo, Clarissa Ocampo, Margarita Gomez, Camille Lopez Molina, Thea Perez, Aileen Cura, Cynthia Culig, Rina Saporsantos, Bianca Camille Lopez, Gerphil Flores, Sal’My Neo Malaki, Pablo Molina, Nolyn Cabahug, Nomer Son, Elmo Makil, Leo Mascarinas, Roy Tolentino, Jun Francis Maravilla, Jonathan Zaens, Andrew Fernando, Leodigario del Rosario, Randy Gilongo, Ramon Acoymo, Noel Azcona, Lionel Guico, Greg de Leon, Jonathan Badon, Conrado Ong, Jeremiah Calisang, and Raymond Leslie Diaz. Many of them were also cast in the various opera productions of the Singapore Lyric Opera in Singapore. Also noteworthy is the collaboration with opera companies from Korea, such as the Daejeon Opera Company.

 

Conductors of opera over the decades include Ladislao Bonus, Jose Estella, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio J. Molina, Hilarion F. Rubio, Luis Valencia, Alfredo S. Buenaventura, Regalado Jose, Ryan Cayabyab, and Chino Toledo.Written by Mauricia D. Borromeo, u pdated by Arwin Q. Tan

 

 

Sources:

Aldaba 1971; Ashen Wings 1995; Bañas 1975; Ching 2014; Eugenio 1982; Dangal ng Lahi 2000; de Leon 1978b; Dioquino 1978; Guevarra 1970; Laureola 1971; Maceda 1972; Manuel 1955, 1970, 1986; Molina 1951; Randel 1986; Samson 1976; Sikhay sa Kabila ng Paalam 1994; Sotto 1992.

Couple performing the pandanggo sa paño in Tanauan, Leyte, 1963

(Francisca Reyes-Aquino Collection)

text:
The Philippine pandanggo is a dance in moderately fast triple time adapted from the Spanish fandango. It was already popular in the Philippines before the 1850s. The people, especially the elite in Manila, were fond of holding bailes (dances) in connection with life-cycle events like birth anniversaries, weddings, and baptisms, and other important occasions, like the arrival of the galleons. Writing in 1844, Lafond, a French writer, mentioned that the Spaniards did very little dancing but paid local dancers to dance the fandango, bolero, and cachucha, which all share a common feature: triple time.

The fandango, along with the other aforementioned dances, was popular in the country from the late 18th to the first half of the 19th century, as suggested by the many versions of the dance found across the country, even in remote areas like the riverine Agusan Valley where the Manobo had already incorporated the dance rhythm pinandanggo into their traditional dance repertoire.

In Mindoro, the pandanggo is called pandanggo sa ilaw (Fandango of Light) because it is said to represent fishermen’s families guiding back fishermen to the shore in candlelight. In this type of pandanggo, dancers have oil lamps or small glasses with candlelight placed on each of their hands, which they later transfer to their heads. Despite the difficulty required in balancing the glass on the dancers’ heads, it has remained a favorite among dance troupes. Antonino Buenaventura composed an original music for this specific dance, which was printed along with the dance patterns in the public school textbook Philippine National Dances, 1946, edited by Francisca Reyes Tolentino.

The subject of fishing that the Mindoro pandanggo represents is similar to the pandanggo oasiwas from Pangasinan, which cultivated the tradition of fishermen drinking wine and dancing after a good catch. The word oasiwas in Pangasinense means swinging, and this refers to the dancers swinging oil lamps, loosely enclosed in scarves knotted at the ends, with their hands. In 1995, the University of the Philippines (UP) Concert Chorus staged a pandanggo oasiwas as part of a choral arrangement of “Hatinggabi” in the group’s restaging of Antonio Molina’s sarsuwela Ana Maria at the UP Abelardo Hall Auditorium.

Regional variations of the pandanggo include the pandanggo Ivatan of Batanes, pandanggo arikenken of Ilocos, sayaw sa Obando of Bulacan, pandanggo rinconada of Camarines Sur, pandanggo sa paño of Leyte, and pandanguiado buraweño of Samar and Leyte.

Despite these differences, most versions have an introduction and the saludo. All versions share melodies that are characterized by conjunct pitch contour and movement. In a dance music version transcribed in Manuel Merino Walls’s Musica Popular de Filipinas, 1892, Walls’s music accompanied an amorous couple from an unknown place dancing, using a salacot. The music had two sections repeated. Other pandanggo versions could have as much as seven sections. The music is played faster after each repetition, the meter sometimes shifting from 3/4 to 2/4. This hemiola effect is probably what makes the pandanggo rhythm distinctive. One can see this in Diego Perez’s piano medley, Recuerdos de Filipinas (Memories of the Philippines), 1886, in which the primary triple rhythm of the left hand is displaced by the two-beat groupings on the right. The influence of this piano piece can be seen in later arrangements by Jose Estella and Restie Umali.

The pandanggo music is used for songs as well. In the Tagalog region, there is a form of entertainment called pandangguhan, which is performed during Lent. In this sung pandanggo, singers exchange verses among themselves using popular tunes, outdoing each other in their knowledge of the pasyon and the Bible. Clearly, in such mixing one sees the indigenous tradition duplo and karagatan being merged with the already acculturated form of pandanggo.

Pandanggo is also used, again perhaps with different tunes, during weddings when the elders advise the newlyweds. Singers are called pandanggeros and pandanggeras, and they sing and dance in slow sway-balance steps. The term also refers to a type of song used to entertain the workers in the rice field.Written by Jeanna B. Malabuyoc, updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo and James C. Diaz

Sources:

Buenconsejo 2008; Tolentino 1946; Walls 1892.
