(Photo courtesy of Ateneo de Manila University Press)

text:
The pasyon refers to the verse narrative on the life and sufferings of Jesus Christ. The pasyon text may be written in Tagalog or in other major Philippine languages, like Kapampangan, Ilocano, Pangasinan, Bicol, Ilonggo, Cebuano, and Waray. There are also pasyon narratives among the Ibanag and Itawes of Cagayan, the Gaddang of Nueva Vizcaya, and the Cuyunon of Palawan. Pasyon among the Ibanag and Itawes is rendered with a lectio whose text, together with neumatic musical notations, is copied in handwritten form from the Processionarium Sacri Ordinis Predicatorum (Sacred Chants of The Orders of Preachers) of 1861. Among the Tagalog, the first published pasyon text was Gaspar Aquino de Belen’s Mahal na Passion ni Jesu Christong P. Natin na Tola (The Sacred Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ in Poetry), 1703. It was so popular that it had a fifth printing by 1760. However, the most commonly used pasyon text was Casaysayan ng Pasiong Mahal ni Jesucristong Panginoon Natin na Sucat Ipag-alab ng Puso ng Sinumang Babasa (An Account of the Sacred Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ Which Should Inflame the Heart of Anyone Who Reads It) by an unknown writer, first published in 1814. This version has also been referred to as Pasiong Mahal; Pasyong Genesis, because it begins with the account of the creation of the world; and Pasyong Pilapil, after the priest who made corrections on the later edition of the text. No form of musical notation accompanies the Tagalog pasyon text. The Pasiong Mahal contains more than 2,500 stanzas in octosyllabic quintilla featuring five eight-syllable lines per stanza. Another Tagalog version but not as popular is Aniceto de la Merced’s El libro de la Vida (The Book of Life), also known as Pasyong Candaba.

The pasyon is usually chanted during Lent by Catholics and Aglipayans alike in the socioreligious occasion called the pabasa (reading) in private homes, chapels, or in more public places like the parish church and town plaza. Chanted nonstop during Holy Week before Good Friday, the pasyon takes about 18-30 hours of straight singing. Continuous singing of this length is not practiced in the Spanish and Mexican Lenten traditions. It relates to the Philippine cultural practice connected with epic singing during important celebrations of the community. The pasyon may also be chanted, though rarely now, during wakes and death anniversaries, as well as during the reenactment of Christ’s Last Supper called huling hapunan or la ultima cena on Maundy Thursday evening. In many towns of Rizal and Bulacan, the pabasa led to the dramatization of the pasyon episodes in the passion play called sinakulo.

There are various melodies and musical styles in the rendering of the pasyon. Heard among the Tagalog is a whole range of tunes, from old chant-like melodies to those borrowed from folk songs, popular songs, and even operas. In the province of Rizal, for example, istilong panawagan is characterized by a very slow tempo, which contrasts with the metrically fast istilong pahudyo. Istilong tagulaylay is also slow paced and is used especially to express grief and lament. Pasyon in many towns of Rizal is closely linked with the sinakulo theater tradition. Specific melodies are identified with characters of the play, such as the above-mentioned istilong pahudyo, istilong Birhen, and istilong Hesus. The Cuyunon of Palawan, who use a Tagalog text, have a repertoire of melodies called by various names, like punto Nasareno, punto responso, and punto tres kaida. When pasyon singers wish to hurry along the singing to complete the pabasa, certain melodies are used that will allow them to render the text in a continuous and brisk manner. This practice has been noted in Cavite, Rizal, and Pampanga where the term pasalsal is specific to the hurried rendering of the text to finish the pasyon.

Because the text is in five-line stanzas while melodic phrases tend to be symmetrical, various techniques are employed to reconcile the difference. In a widely used, old Tagalog punto, the first musical phrase encompasses lines 1 and 2, while the second musical phrase covers lines 3, 4, and 5. In adapting folk song melodies or similar tunes, a four-phrase melody is first sung for lines 1 to 4, which is repeated to render lines 2 to 5. Another formula makes a four-phrase melody coincide with lines 1 to 4 and appends a stock melody or standard melodic ending for line 5.

Generally, pasyon chanting is done a cappella. But among the Ibanag and Itawes, the use of a small five-stringed guitar called cinco-cinco is a traditional practice. Many innovations in pasyon singing have been introduced, like the use of the guitar or rondalla (ensemble of stringed instruments) for accompaniment first noted in Pampanga in the 1970s, and the use of the accordion by a traveling group of pasyon singers from Cainta, Rizal, in the early 1980s.

The chanting of the pasyon is performed in two basic group formations. In the first, two people or groups of people sing alternately. In the second formation, each of the singers take turns in singing a stanza of text. A leader-chorus style is practiced by the Cuyunon where the leader begins and is later followed by the chorus in harmony. Sometimes, it is sung solo. The performance of the pasyon in most urban cities is evidenced by informality: instructions are provided while the chanting is already ongoing, or the succeeding melodic line to be used is hummed, or cues are given on its intended rendition. At times, conversations in between the chanting of the lines are also tolerated. Another important feature of the pasyon is the element of play, which is injected in its performance. Although the general structure of the text is formal, the chanting is marked by the heightening or lowering of pitch level, and the unexpected change and choice of amusing melody, usually contemporary popular tunes. This relaxed informality in the chanting of the pasyon is crucial to its performance as it fits the temperament that is called for by the social occasion.

The pasyon chanting tradition is seen by many of its practitioners as a panata (vow) made by an individual or family, which in many cases has been passed on from one to two generations back. Like many indigenous rituals, the pabasa is held by sponsors, usually a family, to ask the divinity for good health, children, or good luck in a job or exam, and to give thanks for favors received. The process of sponsorship is represented by the possession of the poon (statue), which is handed down from one generation to the next. Due to financial constraints, many modern-day practices of the pabasa in urban locations, outside of the dedicated traditionalists in the provinces, are no longer sponsored by families but by the kapatiran (brotherhood/sisterhood), usually bound by their common business interests or active participation in church-based organizations, and groups like this take turns as the hermano/hermana (brother/sister) for a given year. Carrying this tradition among collective groups enhances their relationships, marked by the passing of the statue from one host to another, and establishes group solidarity. The socioreligious function of the pabasa in the communities of present-day Philippines, as well as the adaptability of the ritual to changing times, will ensure the dynamism, relevance, and continuity of this tradition.Written by Felicidad A. Prudente and Kristina Benitez, u pdated by Arwin Q. Tan

Sources:

Chongson 2000; Investigacion Folklorica en Mexico: Materiales 1962; Javellana 1988; Mendoza 1956; Olmedo 1975; Prudente 1977; Rivera Mirano 1997.

text:
The polka is a Philippine dance in quick duple meter. Originally a Bohemian dance, it was popular in Europe and the United States in the early 19th century. The polka also became a great favorite at Philippine soirees and balls. It eventually faded from the ballroom scene, but polka variants appeared in many local folk dances.

Polka music is always in quick 2/4 time. It is characterized by lively melodic figurations combining 8th and 16th notes over an accompaniment figure of continuous 8th notes or one broken by a quarter or combinations of both. Utilizing the Western tonal system, the melodies are supported by simple tonic, subdominant, and dominant harmonies. The music is frequently in two or three sections made up of double periods of 16 measures each. The sections are variously repeated. In the polkabal of Quezon, it is ABABABAB. The polka sala of Calapan, Mindoro, is ABAC. Polka rhythms are found in many folk songs such as the Tagalog “Leron-Leron Sinta” (Leron-Leron Beloved) and “Magtanim Ay Di Biro” (Planting Rice Is Never Easy), and the Ilocano “Pamulinawen” (Stonehearted).Written by Corazon C. Dioquino

text:
The term pop music is usually interchanged with popular music. But the definition of “popular” and “pop” has evolved since the 1920s, and these terms are now differentiated in some books and encyclopedia. “Popular” may be a description of music that has been widely distributed or highly patronized by the masses. “Pop” on the other hand is used as a genre whose various styles have evolved from the 1950s rock and roll music and is considered an industry product. As developed in the United States (US), pop music would include varied types such as blues, ragtime, jazz, vaudeville music, swing, rhythm and blues, country and folk music, skiffle, ballad, protest songs, rock and roll, bebop, different kinds of rock, soul, Latin American beat, disco, and rap.

Although many types of pop music have roots in the musical traditions of communities, pop music is called such not because it necessarily emanates from the populace but more because of its great accessibility to the public. From the middle of the 20th century to the early 21st century, records, cassettes and compact discs have been mass-produced by the music industry. These have been circulated through mass media—that is, through radio, television, and, recently and more powerfully, the Internet—and are marketed to capture a large segment of the listening public. Popular acceptance by the public sometimes has nothing to do with the quality of the song or the brilliance of the performer. It can as well be engineered by disc jockeys, media hype, promotional gimmicks of recording companies, and online networks, which thus define the state of the genre at a particular time.

Until 1973, pop music in the Philippines only meant Western pop music. The musicindustry that flourished in the country depended largely on importations of current US hits or local record productions of foreign labels. Generations of Filipinos thus grew up singing songs by Frank Sinatra, Bing Crosby, Elvis Presley, Dave Clark Five, Timi Yuro, Paul Anka, The Cascades, The Beatles, Simon and Garfunkel, Bob Dylan, Rolling Stones, Cat Stevens, Don MacLean, and Stevie Wonder. Because of the dominance of the American Top 40 hits in local airwaves, it was the American teenage pop stars who were idolized by the Filipino youth. Original Filipino songs, mostly kundiman and other folksongs, comprised but a tiny percentage of local record production and sales.

Historical Background

In the early years of American colonial rule, popular music in the Philippine consisted of the kundiman, danza, balitaw, and other traditional forms, some of which were adaptations of foreign forms. The pop stars at the turn of the century were sarsuwela singers like Maria Carpena and AtangdelaRama. By the 1920s, American recording companies, like Victor Records and Columbia Records, were attracted enough to local music to record popular kundiman and sarsuwela songs such as Francisco Santiago’s “Anak-Dalita” (Child of Woe), 1917; Nicanor S. Abelardo’s “MutyangPasig” (Muse of Pasig), 1924, and “Nasaan Ka Irog?” (Where Are You, Love?), 1926; and Constancio de Guzman’s “BayanKo” (My Country), 1928. In 1928, JovitaFuentes, who had gained international fame for her performance as Cio Cio San in the opera Madame Butterfly, recorded “Ay Kalisud” (Ah, Misery) and other Filipino folk songs for Odeon Records in Germany. This was followed by another Filipino opera singer, MercedesMatias, who recorded “Madaling-Araw” (Dawn) and “MutyangPasig” for the same German company.

Vaudeville, the moving pictures, and the radio opened the floodgates to American popularmusic. Filipino musicians quickly adopted the new music styles, creating their own versions of jazz, as shown in the naughty “Balut” (Duck Egg) popularized by Filipino “Jazz Queen” KatydelaCruz in the 1920s; fox-trot, like Pedro Bermechea’s “Magandang Juaning” (Beautiful Juaning), circa 1920, which was revived in the 1970s by YoyoyVillame as “Mag-Eksersays Tayo Tuwing Umaga” (Let Us Exercise Every Morning); and boogie and rock and roll, as exemplified by the compositions of Fred Panopio like “O ang Babae” (Oh, Women). By the 1950s, American popularmusic had become so pervasive that Filipino performers were being gauged by how good a copycat they were of American originals. Contests were launched for the “Elvis Presley of the Philippines” (EddieMesa), the “Doris Day of the Philippines” (Anita Valenzuela), the “Perry Como of the Philippines” (DiomedesMaturan), and the “Timi Yuro of the Philippines” (NoraAunor).

The desire of Filipino popmusicians to produce music they could call their own and which they hoped would find support among the youth first found expression in Joey “Pepe” Smith and the Juan de la Cruz Band’s experimentation with hard rock, which used plaintive Filipino lyrics. “AngHimigNatin” (Our Music), performed extemporaneously by the band in 1973, may be considered the first Pinoy (slang for Filipino) rock piece. The song bewailed the lonely struggle of Filipino musicians to have their music accepted by an audience attuned and addicted to foreign music. But it likewise voiced the conviction that the Filipino people would find unity only when they learn to appreciate and sing their own songs.

Ang himig natin

Ang inyong awitin

Upang tayo’y magsama-sama

Sa langit ng pag-asa

(Sing

Our own song

So that we’ll all be together

In the heaven of hope.)

“AngHimigNatin” paved the way for other rock musicians, like Maria Cafra, Sampaguita, and Mike Hanopol (originally of the Juan de la Cruz Band), to enter the music industry. In 1974, the year when the Miss Universe international beauty contest was held in Manila, a group that called themselves Hotdog was able to make a dent in the Manila music scene with their first hit “Ikaw ang Miss Universe ng Buhay Ko” (You Are the Miss Universe of My Life). This was immediately followed by another hit, “Pers Lab” (First Love). In a way, Hotdog softened the initial shock of the audience in hearing the seemingly jarring combination of Western pop sound and Filipino lyrics. Led by the Garcia brothers, Dennis and Rene, Hotdog pioneered what became labeled as Manila sound, a teenybopper kind of music reminiscent of the American pop songs of the 1950s. Their other more popular and relevant hits include “Annie Batungbakal,” “Manila,” and “Bongga Ka Day” (You’re Fabulous, Girl), with the latter two remade and recorded by artists of a later generation.

Manila Sound was clearly music the young could identify with. The tone was irreverent. Composers used chord progressions and song structures that were easily identifiable with the Western sound that the audience had been used to. But the language was colloquial or Taglish, a combination of Tagalog and English, as in Cinderella’s “T.L. Ako sa ’Yo” (I’m Truly in Love with You) and “Ang Boyfriend Kong Baduy” (My Gaudy Boyfriend). The theme mostly revolved around young love, like ApoHikingSociety’s “Syota” (slang for girlfriend). Other groups such as VST & Co. became known for their disco tunes, like “Awitin Mo, Isasayaw Ko” (Sing and I Will Dance), “Rock Baby Rock,” and “Tayo’y Magsayawan” (Let’s Dance). Following this trend of dance music was The Boyfriends with their hit “Sumayaw, Sumunod” (Dance, Follow).

Several factors helped to create a climate conducive to the development of Pinoy popmusic. In 1975 the Broadcast Media Council (BMC) issued Memorandum Order 75-31 requiring all radio stations to play at least one Filipino composition every hour. This was later expanded to two per hour, and finally to three per hour in 1977. The BMC ruling and the subsequent support of the Kapisananngmga BrodkastersaPilipinas gave more exposure to local musicians and encouraged recording companies to pay attention to local talents.

Similarly, Rolando S. Tinio’s translations of Cole Porter, Burt Bacharach, and Jim Webb songs, among others, showed the wide range of experiences and emotions the Filipino language could express, and the flexibility of Filipino to be accommodated in modern musical form. The poetry that was Tinio’s translations as performed by CelesteLegaspi in front of a jampacked Little Theater (now Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino) at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines(CCP) encouraged other musicians and poets to use popmusic as a vehicle for their creativity. In 1977, another CCP musical event,Tales ofthe Manuvu, with libretto by literary critic and poet BienvenidoLumbera, pointed to the possibility of using indigenous tales as material for rock. The rock opera, which was composed by Nonong Pedero, produced hits like “Noong Unang Panahon” (Once upon a Time) and launched Leah Navarro as a pop singer.

The first Metro Manila PopularMusic Festival or Metropop was held at the Folk Arts Theater in 1978. The festival was an annual competition in song composition aimed at encouraging the production of original Filipino popmusic. The best song was chosen, however, not on the basis of a distinctive Filipino quality or sound but on how well it approximated what recording companies perceived to be international popmusic standards. The fact, though, that losers like Freddie Aguilar’s “Anak” (Child) and Heber Bartolome’s “Tayo’ymgaPinoy” (We’re Filipinos) won in terms of record sales over that of Ryan Cayabyab’s “KayGandangAtingMusika ” (How Beautiful Is Our Music) was a telling commentary on the supposed international criteria of the Metropop Festival. The festival ran until 1985, producing original songs that would shape the development of the local music industry. It was revived from 1996 to 2003 by GMA Network. Consequently, the competition influenced several organizations to put up more avenues for producing original songs in the new millennium—namely, the Himig Handog and Philpop songwriting competitions.

On the first day of its release in 1978, Aguilar’s “Anak” sold an unprecedented 30,000 copies. It became an instant hit even in Japan and has since been translated into several foreign languages. Philippine music scholar Felipe de Leon Jr asserted that even if the song was in Western folk form, its pasyon-like quality and the familiar Filipino theme of the ill fate that befalls children who do not heed their parents’ advice endeared “Anak” to million of Filipinos. On the other hand, the radical content of Heber Bartolome’s “Tayo’ymgaPinoy” became easy to digest because of the chiding tone employed and the humorous way he assailed those who continue to ape American ways. Through the medium of rock, Heber successfully called attention to the need for Filipinos to take pride in their own Filipino-ness:

Tayo’y mga Pinoy

Tayo’y hindi Kano

Huwag kang mahihiya

Kung ang ilong mo ay pango

(We’re Filipinos

We’re not Americans

Don’t be ashamed

If you are pug-nosed.)

The jubilation of local musicians at being accepted by an audience they had thought impossible to reach resulted in greatly increased productivity and, most importantly, a greater variety of songs. During this period, many important albums were released, such as Florante’s Mga Tula at Awitin ni Florante (The Poems and Songs of Florante), Mike Hanopol’s Awiting Pilipino (Filipino Songs), Celeste Legaspi’s Ako at si Celeste (Celeste and I), and Basil Valdez’s NgayonatKailanman (Now and Forever). A variety of hit songs emerged, such as Nonoy Gallardo’s “SaranggolaniPepe” (Pepe’s Kite), which in metaphoric language was Philippine history in song, and the 1978 love song “Nakapagtataka” (How Puzzling) performed by HajjiAlejandro and revived by her daughter Rachel Alejandro. This explosion in record production proved that local records were marketable and could compete with foreign labels.

Pinoy Pop Forms

Although Pinoy pop musicians create their own compositions, the musical forms they write in are almost always derived from or inspired by American popmusic. Pinoy rock, for instance, ranges from rock and roll (typified by Sampaguita), to Beatle-type music (Heber Bartolome and his Banyuhay), to Alice Cooper’s kind of heavy rock (Juan de la Cruz Band, Maria Cafra, Mike Hanopol, Wally Gonzalez). All make use of the amplified sounds of electric guitars, drums, synthesizers, and other electronic instruments. On the other hand, many Pinoypop songs have also been created in the mold of the safe, “middle-of-the-road” type of music, the best example being the compositions of the ApoHikingSociety and JoseMariChan in the late 1970s.

Contrary to the term “folk,” Pinoy folk music is not rooted in the folk traditions of Filipinos but draws mainly from the repetitive, simple folk tunes popularized by Western folk groups like Peter, Paul, and Mary, and folk singers such as Joan Baez, and Bob Dylan. Folk singers FreddieAguilar, Florante, Coritha, and the folk group Asin, for example, who began their careers in folk houses that proliferated in the 1970s, accompanied their songs with the same plucking of classical or acoustic guitar strings as their Western counterparts. And like their Western counterpart, their songs were vehicles for social commentaries.

An encouraging development in Pinoy folk music came with ethnic fusion, which uses the ethnic instruments and musical patterns and rhythms from the folk traditions of the lumad (indigenous cultural communities). The group Baleleng, for example, derived their name from the popular Tausug folksong form baleleng and draws materials and rhythms from the song traditions of the Tausug and Sama of Sulu. JoeyAyala and his group Ang Bagong Lumad fused the ethnic rhythms of Mindanao cultural communities with Western pop forms. The sounds emanating from the hagelong (two-stringed lute) and the kubing (mouthharp) were not just embellishments but are integral parts to Ayala’s music. The ethnic music patterns have become so naturalized that in the song “Mirasol,” for example, Joey Ayala succeeded in making his guitar sound like a kulintang, the eight-brass gongs of graduated sizes found in Mindanao. Versatile RyanCayabyab also dabbled in this ethno-pop form to produce the successful Pop Cola commercial in which the rhythmic patterns of the singkil were used. Pinoy jazz musicians, like BoyKatindig and Eddie Munji, have been particularly successful in transforming folk tunes to jazz, and in experimenting with a variety of ethnic instrumentation. The use of ethnic instruments, lumad music patterns, and rhythms for contemporary modern expression may just pave the way for creating what can truly be called Pinoypop music.

When disco music became a fad in the United States, Pinoy pop musicians also produced their own version of Pinoy disco music. The Hagibis, which became known as the local version of the Village People in the late 1970s and early 1980s, produced Pinoy disco music reeking with machismo. Even Hotdog created songs in the regularized disco 4/4 beat, sometimes spicing the song with social comments as in their hit song “Annie Batungbakal,” which recounted the sad story of a girl who hid behind the anonymity of her daytime job as a salesgirl, but who reigned at night as disco queen of Manila’s Coco Banana, a popular discotheque in the late 1970s for both gay and straight crowds.

Rap, which became a craze in America in the late 1980s, is actually an old musical form popular with black singers. It is a fast-paced rhythmic narration aided by electronic music instruments and performed with dancing. Pinoy rap was initiated by Francis Magalona. In his hands, rap became a call for patriotism, as seen in his immensely popular “MgaKababayanKo” (My Countrymen), or as a chastisement of drug addicts, as in “Praning” (colloquialism for paranoid). Other rappers have since emerged to deal with a variety of Pinoy experiences, like Andrew E., who recorded “Humanap Ka ng Panget” (Look for an Ugly One) and Gloc 9, who became widely recognized in the following decade with hits such as “Hari ng Tondo” (King of Tondo), “Sirena” (Mermaid), and “Magda.”

The 1990s saw the rise of alternative bands rooted in the 1980s underground music scene. The Eraserheads became the standard for mainstreaming alternative rock songs. Formed in 1989, the band, whose members were Ely Buendia, Marcus Adoro, Buddy Zabala, and Raimund Marasigan, began playing their original songs on campus at the University of the Philippines Diliman. They released their first commercial album with BMG Records in 1993 titled Ultraelectromagneticpop! and from there, hits followed one after the other, including “Pare Ko” (Brod), “Ligaya” (Happiness), “Magasin” (Magazine), “Alapaap” (Clouds), “With a Smile,” and “Ang Huling El Bimbo” (The Last Airhead). The group was able to record seven studio albums. The use of distortion, power chords, and ringing riffs on the guitar, the poetic lyrics about daily encounters, emotions, and social concerns, and the unpretentious vocals all created a soundscape that captured a sometimes murky, sometimes rock and roll, sometimes drum-heavy style. This was also the style adopted later on by other popular alternative bands, such as Rivermaya, Yano, Parokya ni Edgar, Chicosci, Sandwich, Moonstar88, and 6CycleMind.

The alternative rock style in mainstream continued toward the beginning of the 21st century, but the music noticeably evolved due to developments in sound recording. Bands like Sugarfree, Kamikazee, Urbandub, Bamboo, Kjwan, Rocksteddy, Itchyworms, and Peryodiko also developed a newer style which was a fusion of other styles, such as punk, electronic, progressive rock, heavy metal, ska punk, and grunge. And they learned to employ various media such as music video productions, TV shows, and new radio stations that featured alternative and rock music, such as Jam 88.3 and NU 107 Rock, to tap into the large audience of college students and young working class.

It is significant to note how the independent music has become linked to the pop music as a result of the move of major recording labels to sign up underground alternative bands. Genres known only in the indie scene began to emerge and gain a greater following, thus creating new tastes in popular music. A successful independent band that crossed over to mainstream was Up Dharma Down. With the use of keyboards, synthesizers, drum samplers, experimentation with electronic and various sounds and instrumentation, and the distinct vocal quality of female lead Armi Millare, the band produced songs that were not only popular in the country but also recognized internationally. Indie bands (aside from those with alternative rock style) that proceeded to invade the pop music scene include Orange and Lemons, which had a retro style influenced by The Beatles and The Cure. Radioactive Sago Project, which first signed up with major label Viva Records then resorted to the indie scene after their first album, became more popular after the release of their second album under an independent label. The band brought together spoken word poetry, humor, irony, jazz, punk, soul, Afro-Latin, and a lot of other sporadically mixed styles that conveyed novelty and appealed to critical audiences. Fronted by four-time Palanca award-winning writer Lourd de Veyra, the band’s popular hits include “Ayoko ng Baboy” (I Don’t Like Pig) and “Astro.” All these three bands were under Terno Recordings, an independent label that sought to popularize music with unique-sounding characteristics, which may include jazz, indie rock, house, techno, fusions, to name a few.

On the other side of the spectrum, movies and television drama began using theme songs to create mass appeal. The songs became popular simultaneously with the movie or show or became the main component for a movie or TV show’s audience recall. In 1991, pop singer Sharon Cuneta popularized the Rey Valera song “Maging Sino Ka Man” (Whoever You May Be) for the movie of the same title where she was also the lead actress. Other movies that utilized the mass popularity of songs were “Nandito Ako” (I Am Here), 1994, music by Aaron Paul del Rosario, and “Sana Maulit Muli” (I Hope It Happens Again), 1995, music by Gary Valenciano. This trend even extended in the 2000s: “Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw” (What I Need Is You) and “Kailangan Kita” (I Need You), both in 2000 and both by Ogie Alcasid, and “My First Romance,” 2003, music by Jose Mari Chan. Drama series on TV networks ABS-CBN and GMA became more memorable because of the pop hits associated with them, such as “Pangako sa ’Yo” (I Promise You), composed by Rey Valera; “Bituing Walang Ningning” (Star without Sparkle), composed by Willy Cruz; “Forevermore,” composed by Joey Benin; and “Mula sa Puso” (From the Heart), composed by Vehnee Saturno. These songs were performed by popular solo artists, usually female, who have successfully released pop records. A singer would be deemed truly popular after she (or he) has crossed show business platforms—that is, from singing, to acting, to hosting, and sometimes to dancing. These qualities have been achieved by “popular female idols” such as Sharon Cuneta, Regine Velasquez, Sarah Geronimo, and Rachelle Ann Go.

Filipino show bands, included in entertainment acts in bars, hotels, cruise ships, and event functions around the country and even around the world, and primarily reaching Shanghai audiences, have been around since the early 20th century. They usually perform versions of popular songs of various genres and would usually consist of one or two lead singers with a versatile singing quality and range, a keyboardist, a guitarist, a bass player, and a drummer. From the mid-1990s to the early 2000s, some of these bands began to compose original songs that later gave them access to the pop music industry. The band Side A, whose members included their main composers Joey Benin, Joey Generoso, and Naldy Gonzales, released their first album in 1989 and succeeded with their hit songs “Hold On” and “Forevermore.” Their musical style may be described as R&B with pop jazz nuances. This style was very similar to the bands that later on became popular. Southborder, formed in 1996, became widely known for their hits such as “May Pag-ibig Pa Kaya” (Can Love Still Be There), “Kahit Kailan” (Ever), and “Rainbow,” all composed by keyboardist and vocalist Jay Durias. Freestyle, originally from Davao, also became popular beginning 1999 through their hit songs “Before I Let You Go,” “So Slow,” and the remake of “Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang” (Why Did You Come Just Now). Bands such as these are still active in the 21st century, but are less prominent in the mainstream industry as newer acts have persisted. Acoustic artists came into popularity in the early 2000s, making music that was mostly cover versions with guitar or keyboard and vocal arrangement. MYMPled in this style, but Jimmy Bondoc was able to utilize it, together with his keyboard and his voice, in his composition “Let Me Be the One” in 2003. Nyoy Volante also composed and recorded original hits with his band, himself on the guitar: “Nasaan” (Where) in 2005 and “What Do I Do?” in 2009.

Pinoy Pop Lyrics and Themes

On the surface, it would indeed seem that Pinoypopmusic was simply the local version of whatever music was popular in America. But musical form is only half the song. The language of the song has its own rhythm, too, and expresses feelings or captures experiences unmistakably and originally Pinoy.

Traditional views about love, a carryover from the kundiman, continued to dominate Pinoy love songs, even if these were in the pop forms of Bacharach, Jim Webb, or Paul Williams. George Canseco’s “NgayonatKailanman” (Now and Forever) and his “Hanggang sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan” (Till the End of Infinity) were typical expressions of the age-old Filipino hope that love will last forever. But the language was more controlled, the lines more poetic. In JoelNavarro and Rolando Tinio’s “Pagsinta’y Pang-araw at Gabi” (Love Is for Every Day and Night), the different stages of a love relationship unfolded beautifully in the images of nature (i.e., rice grains and clouds) and the passing of time. Such a song clearly captured the rhythm and poetry in the native language. There were some love songs, however, that seemed to be imbued with a modern temper, depicting the modern Filipina as no longer the shy or coy type, as shown in “Lumapit Ka” (Come Near). Songs of this type, however, were few and did not really advocate significant changes in the traditional man-woman relationship.

In the hands of younger songwriters, more varied Filipino experiences were explored. Deriving from the music of The Beatles, Simon and Garfunkel, and Bob Dylan, singers like Mike Hanopol, Freddie Aguilar, HeberBartolome, and Florante used the medium of rock or Western folk music to gain insights into their own social condition.

Mike Hanopol and Freddie Aguilar focused on the attitudes and social mores of Filipinos that impede their personal growth. They criticized Filipinos for their pride, their love for show, and their laziness—for example, Freddie Aguilar’s “Katamaran” (Laziness). They chided Filipinos for their hypocrisy and insincerity, as in Mike Hanopol’s rock piece “Mr. Kengkoy” (Mr Funny Man). They assailed those reared with all the comforts of life for not making positive contributions to society. In “LakisaLayaw” (Spoiled Brat), his most popular rock composition, Mike Hanopol offered the image of a jeproks (Filipino slang for a spoiled, idle person who dresses the part) with all the vices in the world. The music made noisy proclamation of the message of the song—that the only fate for such people was jail. Though modern and Western in form, these songs had a didactic strain that may account for their popularity among the masses, since native literature, from proverbs and folktales, to popular dramasand novels, has always claimed the function of teaching.

Rising above didacticism, the Apo Hiking Society portrayed in “Pumapatak ang Ulan” (Rain Falls) the tragedy of idle youth in a fast-changing urban society. In a jazzy, melancholic beat heightened by a flute in the background, the drabness of city life was expressed in the meaningless activities forced on a person by poverty and the continual rain. The ApoHikingSociety, composed of JimParedes, DannyJavier, and Boboy Garovillo, was one of the most versatile groups in the country, and has had the longest staying power in the popmusic scene. The group’s songs ranged from the romantic to the sardonic, the most radical being their innovative “AmericanJunk,” 1986, which satirized the Americanization of the Filipino.

In 1983, they were among the few Pinoy pop musicians who joined the millions of Filipinos who protested the slaying of Ninoy Aquino. Immediately after the assassination, they composed a song based on the popular protest slogan “Hindi Ka Nag-iisa” (You Are Not Alone), which did the rounds among street parliamentarians but never made it to the airwaves. Jim Paredes recalled that no radio station was willing to play the song because it was too politically charged. Protest, he discovered, had to thrive outside the industry. Freddie Aguilar suffered a similar fate when his interpretation of the popular 1928 protest kundiman “BayanKo” (My Country), which he interspersed with strains of “Philippines, My Philippines,” could not, ironically, be aired over mainstream radio but only rang out from loudspeakers mounted atop jeepneys during rallies and demonstrations.

The problems of poverty were most successfully explored in the songs of Heber Bartolome, who used his songs to raise his listeners’ social consciousness about the gravity of their poverty. His images included beggars lining the streets with hands outstretched, as in “Buhay Pinoy” (Filipino Life); starving, skeletal, and ailing children seeking relief from their suffering, as in “Awit sa mga Magulang” (Song to Parents); and girls who become prostitutes because they are poor, as in “Nena.” Bartolome made all these accessible for public consumption with Beatle-influenced instrumentation. He traced the problems of the Philippines to it being, in reality, an enslaved nation despite its supposed independence. In his stirring and powerful “Awit Ko” (My Song), Bartolome summoned the image of babies born with fists clenched, their protest against their nation beholden to foreigners beginning too early.

Pinoypop protest music would not be complete without the mention of the group Asin. Even before environmental issues came to the fore, Asin was already lamenting the pollution and destruction of the environment in their song “Masdan ang Kapaligiran” (Look at the Environment). Only later did other music artists like the ApoHikingSociety and rapper Francis Magalona pick up on issues such as protection of the ozone layer, global warming, and forest denudation. Another significant group that contributed socially relevant songs was the young vocal group Smokey Mountain. The first group was formed in 1989 by composer and producer Ryan Cayabyab with singers Geneva Cruz, James Coronel, Tony Lambino, and Jeffrey Hidalgo, who all continued to be part of the music industry after the group disbanded. Their hit songs include “Paraiso” (Paradise), a song of hope despite the depreciating environment; “Better World,” a call to recover the beauty of the world; and “Mama,” a song about a child narrating about her mother living in another country as a domestic helper. Their other popular love songs include “Kailan” (When) and “Can This Be Love.”

What gave Pinoypopmusic its Filipino character was essentially the poetry in its lyrics and the Filipino-ness of the experience it sought to capture. Folk singer Florante de Leon perhaps best articulated the meaning of Pinoypop music. In his song “Laya” (Freedom), he explained that the sound of Pinoy music may be something most listeners were familiar with, but the lyrics spelled the difference and identified the music as Filipino. He further called attention to the important role songs with Filipino lyrics played in helping the Filipinos free themselves from the enslaving force of colonial mentality:

Kung pakikinggan ang inaawit ko ngayon

Sasabihing narinig n’yo na ito noon

Ngunit ngayon ang titik ay iba

Mapapansing ito’y Tagalog na.

Dati rati ang isipan ko’y alipin lang

Isip ng banyaga ang aking kinagisnan;

Aking pinutol ang tanikala

Upang ang isip ko ay lumaya

(If you listen to what I am singing now

You will say you’ve heard this before,

But now the words are different

You’ll notice they’re already in Tagalog.

Once, my mind was a slave

I wakened first to foreign thoughts,

But I broke the chain

So that my mind would be free.)

Pinoy Pop Today

In 1981, BMC was dissolved. Radio stations went back to the old practice of airing mostly American Top 40 hits. This development and the popularity of disco music and minus-one tapes effectively shut out Pinoypopmusic from the airwaves. For a time, groups like Baleleng from Mindanao were confined only to provincial radio stations. Manila-based pop musicians and performers thus formed the Organisasyon ng mga Pilipinong Mang-aawit (OPM, which also refers to Original Pilipino Music), to rally support for Pinoypop music and to help secure more protection for songwriters, performers, and musicians in their contracts with recording companies. Though some asserted that the audience was never lost and that Pinoypopmusic continued to be created, local recording companies were not too keen on producing Pinoypop songs, thus accounting for the relatively few productions during the early part of the 1980s.

In 1987, however, President Corazon C. Aquino issued Executive Order 255, restoring the order for all radio stations to play Filipino songs, this time four per hour. Once again the climate became conducive to Pinoypopmusic production. Pop musicians responded by producing new hits, using new forms such as rap. Under the new dispensation, the Philippine pop music industry also became hospitable to the compositions of protest songwriters, such as InangLaya, Susan Fernandez-Magno, JessSantiago, and Joey Ayala at ang Bagong Lumad. Of these protest song artists, the music industry was kindest to Joey Ayala at ang Bagong Lumad, seeing great commercial promise in the ethnic instrumentation that the group had naturalized into their music, and Universal (formerly Wea) Records spent a considerable amount of funds to promote the group.

Today the struggle of the Pinoy pop musician against the dominance of American popular music in the local music industry continues. But there are many encouraging signs. Individuals and organizations continue to strive to maintain and promote Original Pilipino Music. Songwriting competitions, such as Metropop Song Festival, Himig Handog, and Philpop, endeavor to do this. Societies and organizations that work to ensure that artists are protected are spirited about their important responsibility. Music industry groups—such as the Filipino Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers; Asosasyon ng Musikong Pilipino; and OPM—work seriously for the rights of their artist members. Nationwide workshops and camps on songwriting are more active in the second decade of the 21st century. The organization 7101 Music Nation, for example, has pioneered the Elements Songwriting Camp. There are also web programs and sites dedicated to promoting OPM, such as radiorepublic.com, amplify.ph, opmtunes.com, and philippinemusicregistry.com. Websites such as Soundcloud and YouTube have given way for amateur, independent, and even signed Filipino artists to post and share their talents and songwriting products online and to a wider audience. But more importantly, Filipino musicians continue to write songs in their native language, and the very rhythm of the language may well be transforming their music and creating sounds that are original, modern, and distinctly Filipino.Written by Teresita Gimenez-Maceda, u pdated by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab

text:
Protest songs are songs created—sometimes by individual artists but most often by anonymous mem­bers of social movements—to call attention to issues or to sufferings and privations; to encourage defiance against a perceived unjust social order; to express views of a more just, free, and equitable society; and to inspire nationalism, bravery, and heroism. Set to tradi­tional song forms like the kundiman, danza, and composo, or to agitational martial beat, or, as in current times, to Western folk and rock tunes, protest songs in the Philippines have always been part of rallies and strikes, efforts to unite a sector or a people under a common cause, and the people’s struggles for independence. Indirectly they have also served to mir­ror and record the history of a people’s struggle for liberation.

The Revolution of 1896

One of the Philippine song forms that have been used to stir deep patriotic sentiments throughout various phases of the Filipino people’s struggle for independence and freedom is the kundiman. Associated almost always with the theme of sincere but unrequited love, the melodic patterns of the kundiman were already close to the hearts of Filipi­nos at least a hundred years before the 1896 Revolution.

The music of the kundiman is characterized by extreme lyricism delineated by a highly moving melo­dic contour. Expressive of pain, suffering, sadness, loss, and tears, it became, during the period of revolt against Spanish colonial rule, the language not only of the suffering lover who pledges undying love to his beloved even as his love is unreciprocated, but also of the suffering revolutionary who willingly lays down his life for Inang Bayan or the Motherland.

In the hands of the Katipunero (Philippine revolutionary), the kundiman was transformed to contain revolutionary meaning. Some­times, the song spoke directly about the revolutionary experience, as in the song “Sa Dalampasigan” (On the Seashore), which recalled the martyrdom of Burgos and Rizal in the hands of the treacherous friars and appealed to all Filipinos to take to the mountains and the fields to continue the fight for freedom. At other times, the kundiman took the form of an allegory as in “Iginanti’y Pinatay” (The Favor Returned with Death), a song with the same melody as that of the “Kundiman de 1800” (Kundiman of 1800), known more popularly as “Doon Po sa Amin” (In Our Town). In “Iginanti,” the traveler’s act of stabbing and chopping off a leafy tree that had given him shade could be read as colonial ex­ploitation. In some cases, however, revolutionary mean­ing may have been read into the lyrics, which simply ex­pressed pure, undying love for an idealized woman.

Composer Antonio Molina referred to the song “Jocelynang Baliwag” (Jocelyna of Baliwag), ca 1896, as a kundiman ng himagsikan (kundiman of the revolution). Dedicated to Pepita (nickname of Jocelyna Tiongson of Baliuag, Bulacan), the piece was de­scribed as the “Musica del Legitimo Kundiman Procedente del Campo Insurecto” (Music of the Legitimate Kundiman Coming from the Rebel Camp). This song, together with other folk kundiman of the time, greatly appealed to the revolutionary sentiments of the Katipunero.

The period of the Philippine revolution spawned many songs other than the kundiman. It was common practice among the Katipunero to take marching songs from the Spanish colonial forces and endow these with new lyrics that express the particularities of the na­tion’s struggle. Such was the case with “Alerta, Katipunan” (Alert, Katipunan), originally a Spanish mar­tial song. The Katipunero version sang of the hardships revolutionaries must bear and the extraor­dinary courage they must have to secure the freedom of Inang Bayan.

The triumph of the revolution that was to bring about a free society purified of the evils of colonial rule and consecrated to honor virtue and excellence was already envisioned in Julio Nakpil’s “Marangal na Dalit ng Katagalugan” (Noble Hymn of the Tagalog Region), 1896, a song that could have been the Philip­pine national anthem had Bonifacio lived to become president. Independence, however, was thwarted by America, the new colonizer. The struggle would continue long after the Philippines was granted its “flag independence” in 1946.

The Mass Movements of the 1930s

Voices of protest continued to be raised against the American colonial order. From the turn of the century, poets began to write patriotic lyrics to kundiman music while schooled musicians innovated on its music, modulating it from major to minor. In 1928, the popular poet Jose Corazon de Jesus wrote the lyrics of the immortal “Bayan Ko” (My Country) to the music composed by Constancio de Guzman. Originally created to protest American colonization of the country, the song was revived in the 1970s and 1980s to protest against the Marcos dictatorship. No other Philippine protest song has had the power to evoke such strong patriotic fervor and to unite people of different political backgrounds, consolidating them in the face of violent dispersal. Long considered the anthem of protest movements, “Bayan Ko” is the only kundiman sung with clenched fists. It remains contemporary because its lyrics and melody have always had great affective power among Filipinos and dramatizes the unchanged condition of Inang Bayan:

Ang Bayan kong Pilipinas

Lupain ng ginto’t bulaklak

Pag-ibig ang sa kanyang palad

Nag-alay ng ganda’t dilag

(Philippines! My Country my homeland

Gold and flowers in her heart abound

Blessings on her fate did love bestow

Sweet beauty’s grace and splendor’s glow)

It has been ravaged and shackled by foreign powers:

At sa kanyang yumi at ganda

Dayuhan ay nahalina

Bayan ko, binihag ka

Nasadlak sa dusa

(How her charms so kind and tender

Drove the stranger to covet her

Land of mine! In fetters kept,

You suffered as we wept.)

And yet hope remains that one day the Filipino people will see her free:

Pilipinas kong minumutya

Pugad ng luha ko’t dalita

Aking adhika makita kang sakdal laya.

(Philippines! My heart’s sole burning fire,

Cradle of my tears, my misery

All that I desire is to see you free.)

Because of worsening agrarian and labor con­ditions in the 1930s, pockets of rebellion, and peasant and worker strikes and demonstrations escalated. Radicalized labor­ers and peasants saw the importance of organized action to fight for their rights and to change the social system. Political parties with a markedly revolutionary character were established. The largest of these were the Partido Komunista ng Pilipinas (PKP), which had the Kalipunan ng mga Anakpawis sa Pilipinas and the Kalipunang Pambansa ng mga Magsasaka sa Pilipinas as its labor and peasant arm, and the Partido Sosialista ng Pilipinas (PSP), which had the Aguman Ding Maldang Talapagobra (AMT) for its mass organization.

The desire and the struggle for radical changes in society found articulation in the many militant songs created by the members of these radical organizations. The song form became an important political weapon for organizing and recruiting new members, a means for peasants and workers to confront their collective problems, and a way to strengthen their resolve to continue with the struggle.

Many of the songs of the PKP revolved around the theme of class struggle. The songs stressed the need for the laborers and peasants to unite in order to put an end to their exploitation in the hands of the ruling class, represented by the American imperial power and by local capitalists and landlords. The songs were mostly set to martial music. A few were adapted from the songs of communist parties of other countries, such as “Sulong Ka Bayan” (Onward, Country) from the Italian “Bandiera Rosa” (Red Banner). Most effective when sung in strikes and demon­strations, the song chided the tamad na burgis (lazy bourgeois) who were not ashamed to live off the sweat of the laboring class. Even after the PKP went underground, songs con­tinued to be used to keep the fire of commitment among its members burning and to instill in their minds the justness of the cause they were fighting for. Songs like “Rebolusyong Sosyal” (Social Revolution) and “Sisikat ang Bagong Araw” (A New Day Will Rise) made more frequent reference to the waving of the red banner and called for unity among the oppressed in order to stage a social revolution and establish a soviet order.

Songs were also created during this period to address the youth and women sectors. “Gumising Ka, Kabataan” (Wake Up, Youth), written for a youth con­gress in the mid-1930s, called on the youth to take on a more active role in the struggle for freedom. “Babaeng Walang Kibo” (Passive Woman) asked mothers to listen to their children’s cries of hunger and to understand their oppressed condition in the context of the class struggle. These songs, along with other PKP songs, survived the 1930s and became standard songs in pro­test actions of the 1960s and the 1970s.

Like the PKP, the PSP, which was founded in the early 1930s by Pedro Abad Santos, made effective use of songs to spread its political cause. Mass meetings and paradas (parades) were always accompanied by singing. Singers with strong and powerful voices were especially recruited by poet Lino Gopez Dizon, one of the pillars of the party, to travel from barrio to barrio to sing PSP-AMT songs that encouraged other peasants to join the movement.

The PSP-AMT was inclined to use traditional song forms for radicalizing the consciousness of peasants. Usually plaintive kundiman and danza served to awaken the unaware to the value of joining a move­ment to fight the unjust tenancy system and to put an end to their darayang kasakitan (bleeding pain). In general, PSP songs showed a great distrust of government. In Lino Gopez Dizon’s “Pasion ding Talapagobra” (Passion of the Peasant Workers) or pulang pasyon (red passion), which was considered the bible of the movement, the government was described as a limatac (a parasite). In the song “Balen, Qng Siping Mu Ding Anac Mu” (Motherland, Beside You Are Your Children), it was a dambualang tampalasan (an abusive monster); and in the song “Masdan Yu ing Palacad ning Gobierno Pilipinas” (Ob­serve How the Philippine Government Rules), it was the people’s enemy responsible for arbitrary arrests, impris­onments, and deaths of peasant leaders. On the other hand, the rich were portrayed as greedy traitors in the song “Mibangun Ca, Anacpawas” (Arise, Worker).

The PSP-AMT songs contained threats that were more pointed and direct in tone. “Masdan Yu ing Palacad Ning Gobierno Pilipinas” warned both the rich and the government of an impending revolution should they continue to be abusive. In “Ortelanong Talapagobra, Sulung qng Labanan” (Peasant Workers, Onward with the Fight), the PSP-AMT members pre­sented themselves as sundalus ning lahi (soldiers of that revolt; literally, soldiers of the race), who fight not for money but for the people’s welfare.

On the whole, the PSP-AMT songs heightened the awareness of peasants of the inherent power of their class, and called on them to never lose sight of the goal of the struggle—that is, the establishment of a society ruled by hustisya ning Bathala (justice of God) whose members were not only the people’s soldiers but, more significantly, pangapala (blessed). The songs articulated the movement’s vision of a society that would replace the unjust and oppressive landlord-tenant system with one where men no longer relate to one another as master and slave but as pamicacapatad (brothers and sisters), where harmony exists because of pamicalulugud (love) and pamidamayan (com­passion for one another), and where everyone can live decently because there is enough for everyone’s needs.

The Anti-Japanese Struggle of the 1940s

In 1938 the PSP and the PKP merged. One of the reasons for the merger was to prepare for the possible invasion of the Philippines by Japanese forces. On the eve of the invasion, the merged PKP-PSP came out with a dec­laration, which, among other things, pledged support to the governments of the United States (US) and the Philippines and called for a united front against the Japanese. On 29 Mar 1942, the PKP organized the Hukbo ng Bayan Laban sa Hapon or Hukbalahap, which, after World War II, was converted to the Hukbong Mapagpalaya ng Bayan (HMB).

Two of the main problems of the Hukbalahap were recruiting volunteers and organizing support groups in the towns and barrios. In Nueva Ecija, the popular peasant leader Juan Feleo experimented with the use of drama and song to attract people to the movement. He organized the Nueva Ecija Cultural Dramatic Association, which accompanied troops to villages and performed skits and songs that served to explain the aims of the Hukbalahap and the impor­tance of a united front against the Japanese. The method proved successful, so the Hukbalahap adopted this and formed the Cultural Information Division (CID), com­posed of talented guerrilla fighters and young women who also served as couriers or first-aiders.

Propaganda became the primary task of the CID. Many of the songs created by CID members explained the goals of the Hukbalahap and depicted the condition of Inang Bayan under fascist rule. The songs were meant to convince people of the necessity of forging a united front against the Japanese and of waging guerrilla warfare. The united-front policy of the Hukbalahap could explain why Huk songs did not manifest any Marxist-Leninist or socialist ideas de­spite the Huk guerilla movement being led by the merged PKP-PSP and instead became highly re­miniscent of the patriotic songs of the 1896 Revolution.

The CID thus became part of the organizing force of the Hukbalahap. To recruit prospective Huk guerril­las or to establish a Huk base in the towns, a group went to barrios and towns to perform for the townspeople when there was no Japanese presence around. Songs like “Hukbalahap ng Bayan” (People’s Hukbalahap), “Pamisan Metung a Panig Mitatag Ya” (Let Us Establish the United Front), and “Hukbo ng Bayan” (People’s Army) reminded the people of their tradition of revolutionary courage and fervor and their immediate aim of taking up arms to drive the Japanese forces away.

Songs also served as the Huk guerrilla movement’s news bulletin. Issues and orders were explained to guerrillas and townspeople through songs and skits. For example, in the struggle waged by Huk guerrillas to gather the palay (rice) harvest before the Japanese could confiscate it, songs were created by CID members to stress the importance of cooperation and the need for secrecy to ensure the success of the operation, as found in the song “Harvest Struggle” sung to the tune of the PKP’s “Awit ng Rebolusyunaryo” (Song of the Revolutionary).

Songs also became the vehicle for launching at­tacks against Filipino leaders who collaborated with the Japanese. The CID parodied the KALIBAPI Hymn “Awit sa Paglikha ng Bagong Pilipinas” (Song for the Creation of a New Philippines) in their anti-KALIBAPI version, “Tindig Aking Inang Bayan” (Stand Up, Mother Country). The song asked the people to join anti-Japanese organizations.

The Hukbalahap became then known as a “singing army.” Huk guerrillas brought to battle not only their rifles and machine guns, but their guitars and bandurria as well. Huk Supremo Luis Taruc testified that in the battlefield, Huks sang martial songs like “Sulong Gerilyerong Sandatahan” (Onward Armed Guerrillas) or “Hukbo ng Bayan” (People’s Army) to boost the morale of fighters and inspire bravery and courage. Because the Huk guerrilla saw the war in intimate terms, whether the song was set to martial music, borrowed martial tunes from the US Army, or to the native kundiman and danza, whether it was a song to recruit or inspire the guerrilla forces, or lament the tragedies in a guerrilla’s life, the language used was always personal and familiar.

Involvement in guerrilla warfare exacted tremend­ous sacrifice and hardship from the guerrillas. “Ing Bie ding Anac Mu, Balen Cung Alipan” (The Life of Your Child, My Enslaved Country) and “Lakad Lakad, Gerilyero” (Walk On, Guerrilla) described how the guerrillas relied on the sap of vines, like the malacatmon, on Mount Arayat in order to survive hunger and thirst; how they pined for their loved ones; and how they consciously disciplined themselves to give up per­sonal wants and needs. All these were borne by the guerril­las because only through struggle and the willingness to sacrifice could the guerrillas wipe away the tears and restore the happiness and wholeness of their Inang Bayan.

In sum, the Hukbalahap songs played the pivotal role of firing up the patriotic sentiments of the people, serving to record the historical experiences and senti­ments of guerrillas during the war, and mobilizing men, women, and the youth in the fight for freedom from Japanese rule.

But despite the patriotism of the Huk guerrillas and their show of support to American troops that had returned to liberate the country, the Hukbalahap was not recognized by the American government after World War II. On the contrary, its leaders and members were impris­oned, harassed, or killed. Soon after, former Huk members took to the mountains to continue the fight, this time against the American military and the young Philippine Republic. The Hukbalahap became the Hukbong Mapagpalaya ng Bayan or HMB in 1949.

Imperialism and class struggle resurfaced in the HMB songs. Old PKP songs were revived, the Philip­pine national anthem was rewritten, and new songs were created to address current needs of the move­ment. As they were hunted down as bandits and brigands, the HMB guerrillas reaffirmed themselves as legitimate fighters for freedom as in “Gintong Catimauan” (Golden Freedom):

E que tulisan, e que bandido

Tau caming manintun catuliran

E bale ing mate, mibual qng parang

Aquit mi yang sumala gintung catimauan.

(We are not traitors, we are not bandits

We are men and women seeking justice

Death matters not nor does falling in the battlefield

So long as we witness golden freedom rising.)

The Protest Movements of the 1960s and 1970s

The arena for protest action shifted radically in the mid-1960s from the countryside to the university campus. The emergence of student activism in the Philippines was a reaction to the worsening political and economic conditions in the country, the reality of American control over most aspects of Philippine life, and international events such as the Vietnam war and the resulting worldwide protest against it. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, student activism drew inspiration from the revolution in China and the radical student movement in countries such as France, Germany, and even the United States.

Through organizations like the Kabataang Makabayan and the Samahan ng Demokratikong Kabataan, students were exposed to Marxist-Leninist and Maoist ideology. They were increasingly made aware of the manipulations of American im­perialism over Philippine economic and foreign poli­cies. Issues of feudalism and capitalism were discussed in teach-ins and in small discussion groups or DGs. Like other sectors, artists themselves got more in­volved in social and political issues.

In this context, the importance of the song in orga­nizing, mobilizing, and politicizing the masses was underscored. At the start, activists revived and sometimes rewrote PKP songs popular from the 1930s. As the movement gained steam and its Maoist leanings became more evident, they adopted songs from Mao’s Cultural Revolution.

The basic theme of most songs during this period was class struggle, as in “Awit ng Pakikibaka” (Song of Struggle). Songs such as “Ang Masa” (The Masses) followed Mao’s dictum that the revolutionary struggle must emanate from and be directed toward the masses:

Mula sa masa, tungo sa masa

Ito ang ating patnubay.

From the masses, toward the masses

This is our guiding rule.

Other songs sought to depict the three main issues perceived to be plaguing Philippine society: imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucrat capitalism. The three issues were usually treated separately except in “Ang Paglaban” (The Fight), a song composed for the play Barikada (Barricade), and the rewritten version of the PKP song “Sulong Ka Bayan” where imperialism was personi­fied by the tamad na Yankee (lazy Yankee), the bureaucrat capitalist by the tamad na burgis (lazy bourgeois), and feudalism by the asenderong tamad (lazy hacendero). Of the three issues, imperial­ism appeared in the majority of the songs. The imperialistang kano (American imperialist) was identified as the main cause for the oppressed condition of the masses—the enemy to fight.

Though most of the songs of the student move­ment were martial in beat, the plaintive kundiman surfaced now and then in rallies where “Bayan Ko” was sung whenever the call to disperse the demonstrators was issued by the Metrocom, and in programs honoring those who died in mass actions through the song “Araw na Lubhang Mapanglaw” (A Day of Extreme Sadness) and the classic “Mendiola” written in memory of students who died in the clashes be­tween activists and soldiers during the demonstrations on 26 and 30 Jan 1970.

Protests under Martial Law

Mar­tial law period showed greater experimentation in both form and content, and more flexibility in adapt­ing to various types of melodies and styles, both local and foreign, to express varied experiences. Protest singers translated songs from Latin America to Filipino such as Victor Jara’s “La Plegaria a un Labrador” (A Worker’s Prayer), which was translated by Jess Santiago; “Cuando Voy al Trabajo” (Going to Work), translated by Karina Constantino-David; and the internationally renowned Chilean song of Sergio Ortega and Quilapayún “El Pueblo Unido, Jamás Será Vencido” (A United People Will Never Be Defeated), translated by Maria Luisa Torres-Reyes and which became one of the most sung protest songs during the martial law period. Rock music, which began as a protest medium in the West, was also adopted to express revolutionary aspirations, as in the song “Mga Babae” (Women) written by an underground songwri­ter, Ka Arting, then popularly known as the Florante ng Hukbo (Florante of the Army).

The break from the typical ideological songs char­acterized by sloganeering, martial beat, and general­ized messages was precipitated by the migration of poets to the music field. In the hands of poets, the revolutionary/protest song was liberated from its formula structure, which moved predictably from state­ment of oppressive condition to affirmation of revolu­tionary optimism and the triumph of the masses. Now, a wider range of experiences was explored and more issues were particularized. Fresher and novel images were employed and language became more lyrical, more concrete, and subtler. Cultural production under martial law became more creative, if not more powerful, largely because of the need for indirection.

Created right after the declaration of martial law, Heber Bartolome’s “Oy Utol, Buto’t Balat Ka Na’y Natutulog Ka Pa” (Hey Brother, You’re Nothing but Flesh and Bones, and Yet You Sleep) was a powerful dramatization of the conditions in the early 1970s: the cries of pain and anguish underneath the facade of calm and gaiety, the hunger, the repression, the climate of fear. This was Heber’s first composition and perhaps the earliest protest song created during the period, using rock instrumentation as embellishment to an essentially Western folk music (much like Bob Dylan’s fusion of rock and folk). The folk-rock form enabled the songwriter to progress from mere observation to chiding: “At kung tayo’y mananahimik at di kikilos / Ang dapat sa atin ay tawaging / Mga gago!” (And if we remain silent and refuse to act / What we deserve is to be called / Morons!). Heber also tackled the graver issue of the presence of the US military bases in the Philippines in his song “Awit Ko” (My Song), a rock piece that expressed anguish and frustration over the Filipino’s impotence to act. In contrast to Heber’s Beatle-influenced instrumentation and his leanings to rock music, Ani Montano adapted Chuck Berry’s “Johnny B. Goode” to satirize the country’s system of education that blunted rather than sharpened the minds of students in his “Bobo ng Diliman” (The Moron of Diliman). The Nuklus Band, in their song “Dambuhala sa Morong” (The Monster in Morong) used the power of rock to express rage against the Marcos government’s building of a nuclear plant in Morong, Bataan. Poet-songwriter Jess Santiago drew from the tradition of the Western folk song, an ex­tremely popular protest medium in America in the 1960s. Santiago’s songs, most of them in ballad style, were eloquent testimonies of the kinds of oppression suffered by the people. Joey Ayala suc­cessfully fused rock and traditional lumad or native instrumentation in the early 1980s to produce a distinc­tive music that captured the rhythm and soul of Minda­nao in order to articulate the ugly realities of Minda­nao life, such as vanishing rainforests, bombing of markets, and hamletting of whole communities, as well as to celebrate its everyday scenes.

In the countryside, revolutionary songs had a more practical and creative application. Out of the reach of the music industry and the print media, places like Samar made full use of the song as a historical document to record military atrocities and encounters. Waray traditional folk forms were revived and revitalized to become vehicles of revolutionary ex­pression. The ismayling, a traditional song-debate between a man and a woman on varied topics, like court­ship, farming, and other tropical issues, was used to ex­plain party issues or deepen the people’s understanding of national issues from the party’s point of view. The song form was also employed by the New People’s Army (NPA) as a news bulletin to facilitate the transmission of news that would otherwise take three weeks to disseminate. Set to a simple folk melody, the news was learned by heart and dissemi­nated to the people much faster.

Among the peoples of Kalinga, Abra, and Bontoc, song forms like the salidummay, donglala, oynasi, balasibasem, and idi mid were recast in verbal joust form to narrate significant events in the strug­gle of the Cordillera people against the Chico Dam project and the militarization of the area, discuss issues affecting the people, and situate the tribal problems in the context of the Cordil­lera struggle as a whole. In recent years, some of these songs have been recorded and performed by the song group Salidummay. In Iloilo and Cebu, extemporaneous ballads like the composo were utilized to explain the NPA’s role in the revolution, discuss the latest Philippine Constabulary and NPA encounter, or expose the anomalies of the Marcos government. These songs were rich in folk humor, as in the long but never boring song “Ali Macoy,” which bared the prob­lems under Marcos’s New Society, capping each section with the line “Ali Macoy, ali Macoy / Atong dugmukon ang itlog ni Macoy (Ali Macoy, Ali Macoy / We will crush the balls of Macoy).

Political detention centers contributed their share of freedom songs. “Mutya” (Muse), adapted from Bonifacio Abdon’s “Kundiman,” was an offering of love and life to the beloved country and a pledge to remain free even behind the high walls and barbed wires of Bicutan. “Pag-ibig sa Tinubuang Lupa” (Love of One’s Native Land), a poem by the revolution­ary hero Andres Bonifacio, was set to kundiman music in 1979 by Salvador Luis Jorque and became one of the most popular patriotic songs of the period.

The assassination of Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr on 21 Aug 1983 marked the turning point or the dec­line of the Marcos dictatorship. Various sectors and classes of Philippine society became one in their outpouring of grief and indignation. Together with the martyr’s widow, Corazon C. Aquino, they gathered in Liwasang Bonifacio and affirmed the “Panata sa Kalayaan” (Pledge of Freedom), penned by the nationalist Jose W. Diokno and translated to Filipino by Jose Lacaba, “to intensify action and determination / Until we gain freedom, democracy and sovereignty.” The pledge was later set to music by Lutgardo Labad and performed by the group Patatag.

As protest action escalated, songs were spontaneously created to satirize the ex­cesses and repressive policies of the dictatorship, as seen in both Inang Laya’s “Binagoongang Lipunan” (Society of Fermented Fish), a pun on Marcos’s Bagong Lipunan (New Society), and “Turismo” (Tourism), and to decry the indignities and low pay suffered by public school teachers, as in Jane Po’s “Titser” (Teacher). Protest singers like Heber Bartolome, Jess Santiago, Susan Fernandez, Joey Ayala, Paul Galang, Gary Granada, Noel Cabangon, Inang Laya, and Patatag braved tear gas, water cannons, and arrest to perform in protest marches, such as the weeklong march from Central Luzon and Southern Tagalog to Manila called “Lakbayan,” in rallies and demonstra­tions, pulong bayan (town meetings), and open forums held in towns and cities all over the country. Pinoy folk and pop singers like Freddie Aguilar, Coritha, the groups Asin and Apo Hiking Society also joined in the mounting protest.

Protest Songs after the Dictatorship

The toppling of the Marcos dictatorship through four days of peaceful EDSA Revolt from 22 to 25 Feb 1986 was celebrated in song. Protest performers and popular singers joined in the performance of Jim Paredes’s “Handog ng Pilipino sa Mundo” (Filipino’s Offering to the World) in which Filipinos vowed never again to let martial law darken the land:

Ating kalayaan kay tagal na nating mithi

Di na papayagang mabawi muli

Handog ng Pilipino sa mundo

Mapayapang paraang pagbabago

Katotohanan, kalayaan, katarungan

Ay kayang makamit nang walang dahas

Basta’t magkaisa tayong lahat

(We’ve longed for our freedom for so long

We won’t let it be taken away again

Filipinos’ gift to the world

A peaceful way towards change

Truth, freedom, justice

Can be attained without violence

As long as we all stand united)

The return to a democratic order did not mark the end of protest songs. Protest songwriters and performers found the doors of the concert hall of the Cultural Center of the Philippines and the popular culture industry suddenly open to songs that once thrived only in the parliament of the streets. Cassette tapes and later CD albums of Asin, Patatag, Salidummay, Inang Laya, Susan Fernandez, Jess Santiago, Paul Galang, Gary Granada, Noel Cabangun, and other protest singers became available to the general public.

The entry of protest singers into the pop music industry enriched and invigorated Pinoy pop and rock music. Joey Ayala formed a new group, Bagong Lumad (New Indigenous People), and created songs that carried social and environment themes. Bayang Barrios would later leave the group to distinguish herself in creating a unique and beautiful blending of Bagobo chanting and rhythm with pop/rock music to tackle social issues. Dong Abay, a member of Patatag, formed the popular band Yano to give expression to the anti-establishment sentiment of the youth in the 1990s in “Banal na Aso, Santong Kabayo” (Holy Dog, Saintly Horse); to reminisce the bravery of the poor during the extraordinary days of People Power but whose lives have not improved in “Kumusta Ka Na?” (How Have You Been?); and to pay homage to the lowly flip-flops—symbolic of the poor—that have witnessed political repression in “Tsinelas” (Flip-Flops). Meanwhile, youth groups emerged with refreshing new ways of tackling social issues, determined not to sound too grim in order not to alienate their young audience. The Eraserheads, Parokya ni Edgar, Color It Red, River Maya, the reggae band Brown Man’s Revival, and others were extremely popular during the whole decade of the 1990s and produced an extraordinary wealth of songs that served as social commentaries.

Decades may separate today’s rock bands from those who dared to fuse Pinoy lyrics with Western-influenced sounds, but there is today an appreciation for the legacy of protest music as seen in the new productions by young rock bands like the Sugarfree, Dicta License, Radioactive Sago, Jr. Kilat, and Missing Filemon who write lyrics not only in Filipino but in other Philippine languages like Cebuano to express contemporary issues in punk, hip-hop, rap, revitalized reggae, and other forms. There have been other developments that keep alive independent and protest music production outside mainstream music industry and Metro Manila. The astounding speed with which computer technology is advancing now makes available to lyricists, music composers, and performers new devices to produce and new platforms to disseminate their own creations, wage people’s campaigns, and launch protest. At the height of the impeachment trial of President Joseph “Erap” Estrada in Dec 2000, for instance, the anonymous “White Album” that surfaced during the protest rallies encouraged people to copy the CD of anti-Erap songs. When the “Hello Garci” political scandal erupted in mid-2005, anti-GMA ringtones and songs were also disseminated widely via CDs and uploaded to the Internet. YouTube, too, has since become a popular site for protest. But as popular protest gives rise to new groups, new forms, and new articulations, the one song that has been the constant protest anthem is still the plaintive kundiman “Bayan Ko.” Written by Teresita Gimenez-Maceda

text:
The Philippine rigodon is a formal square dance that traditionally highlights prestigious state, provincial, or community functions. The dance was said to have been first introduced in the court of Louis XIII by Rigaud, a dance master from Marseille after whom the dance originally called rigaudon, was named. The quadrille later spread to the other courts of Europe. It was introduced in the Philippines in the 19th century and became an important feature of Malacañan balls in the late Spanish period and during the pre-World War II era.

The rigodon de honor was performed in Malacañan during the term of American Governor-General William Howard Taft to win local sympathy for the colonial government. It was a dance that emphasized a person’s prestige and status, as it was done with much fanfare, with each participating couple announced as they promenaded and danced around the ballroom, to be admired by all the guests. Participants belonged exclusively to high society—representatives from the cabinet, legislature, uniformed services, local government, and cultural sector; the diplomatic corps; and well-known personalities—who took the occasion to display their most fashionable formal wear. The rigodon became the highlight of official Malacañan revelries from the Quezon administration to the time of Marcos. But its popularity declined after. The last rigodon de honor held in the palace in the 20th century was on the third inauguration of Ferdinand Marcos in 1981.

In Jun 2008, at the 110th anniversary of Philippine independence, the traditional rigodon de honor at the ceremonial hall of Malacañan was revived, and it has since then been held regularly. Aside from Malacañan, there have been establishments that cater to the Philippine elite such as Club Bulaqueño and Club Filipino, Kahirup and Mancomunidad Pampangueña, and diasporic Filipino communities such as the Rotary Club of Toronto in Canada, the Circulo Kapampangan of Houston, Texas, and the Filipino-Australian Seniors in Sydney, Australia, which also promote the dancing of the Filipino-Spanish quadrille.

The music that accompanies the dance is made up of separate sections corresponding to the different figures of the dance: zeta (figure Z), casamiento (marriage), hatid or visita (escort or visit), cambio pareja (change partners), cadena (chain), and cadenilla (small chain). The rhythm for each of the figures may be in simple 2/4 time or, occasionally, in compound 6/8 time. There are many versions, too, of the dance, but it always opens with the anuncio (announcement) and ends with the saludo (bow).

The music of each section is usually in two parts, each made up of double periods of 16 measures each. The number of times each part is repeated varies depending on the space available and on the number of couples dancing. Musicians are signaled by clapping or stamping to indicate the end of a dance figure. The change of music for each dance figure heightens the difference in steps and formation.

Folk dance companies like the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company and the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group have featured the rigodon in their performances. A satirical version of rigodon was incorporated into Denisa Reyes’s Siete Dolores, 1988.Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, u pdated by Arwin Q. Tan
