text:
Pinoy rock is a type of popular music in the Philippines that came from the American rock and roll music of the 1950s. Through the latter’s influence in the ensuing decades, Pinoy rock evolved and continues to evolve into many local varieties. Reaching the Philippines via radio, television, and film and the sale of recordings and electronic instruments in the 1950s, rock and roll spread to middle-class Filipino teenagers who formed bands called combos, which made use of amplified electronic instruments, notably guitar and drum sets. A string of imported hits by The Atlantics, Duane Eddy, and, most of all, The Ventures, became templates for Manila’s teenage bands. Amplified noise, distorted sound, and the projection of masculinity were some of rock’s most distinctive characteristics. Rock and roll was mainly consumed by youth cultures that found in the music an outlet for their voices and social experiences.

The first eminent local group practicing the genre was RJ & The Riots, led by then 15-year-old Ramon Jacinto (lead guitar and vocals) with young colleagues Jimmy Colayco (rhythm guitar), Alan Austria (bass guitar), and Bernie Evangelista (drums). They appeared for the first time in the high school Christmas party of Ateneo de Manila University in Dec 1960, riding on the popularity of instrumental rock and roll, called surf music among Manila’s student audiences. Surf was a predominantly guitar-oriented style invented by an American soloist named Dick Dale, who combined rock and roll beats with Mexican and Middle Eastern overtones.

Within two years, the enterprising Ramon Jacinto released a number of his own trendy recordings using an Ampex 300-3 multitrack tape recorder, which was the nucleus of the RJ Sound Studio that he had set up at home, and launched Rajah Records, a record label he had registered. Furthering his initiatives, he assembled his own radio station, DZRJ-AM, manned by a volunteer group of classmates. Popular American vinyl records were imported and broadcast by DZRJ to satisfy a growing demand for the latest international hits. In 1962, The Ventures arrived in the Philippines to perform at the Araneta Coliseum, but appeared only as a duo. The Ventures’ principal members, the guitarists Don Wilson and Bob Bogle, called on the Riots’ drummer Bernie Evangelista and bassist Alan Austria to complete their ensemble. It was clearly a triumph for The Riots, and especially Ramon Jacinto, whose instrumental singles, such as “Weightless,” “Teenstone,” and “Advertising Man,” had by then earned a cachet among rock aficionados as Manila’s premier representatives of surf music.

The Riots released a considerable number of vinyl records in the 45-rpm single format as well as in the long-playing 33-rpm album format. Other musical groups flourished in the surf music bandwagon, particularly The Technicolors from the high school grades of the American School, later renamed International School. Led by the young teenage guitarist Eddie Villanueva, an agile and dexterous instrumentalist, the Technicolors released their own original instrumentals in 1963 under the independent Pioneer Records imprint. Their string of hits, particularly “Sombrero,” “A-Line,” and “Los Arcos,” were imitative of The Shadows, a British group that distinguished itself among the slew of American surf era artists, and who also backed up the English pop star Cliff Richard. The Technicolors included among its members drummer Tony Tuviera (who would gain prominence as a television producer decades after) and rhythm guitarist Paul Pascal, who would resurface a decade after as an influential rock composer.

Other local instrumental combos prospered in this milieu such as The Electromanics, led by two mainstays: young guitarist-tunesmith Ernie Delgado and drummer Lito Toribio. Effectively eschewing the Riots’ upscale direction, the Electromaniacs sounded increasingly less Westernized and more Asian as they cultivated a mass audience. They exploited a network of coin-operated jukebox machines to distribute hits to the farthest Philippine provinces. Dyna Records, an independent label founded in 1959 by James Dy, a Filipino-Chinese businessman, cultivated the Electromanics’ 45-rpm singles such as “Oh I Miss You So” and “Lover’s Guitar.” Spurred by their manager, the screen actor Jose Mari Gonzales, The Electromaniacs doubled their exposure in a series of musical films in vogue, emulating the Hollywood sorties of Elvis Presley, the mid-1950s rock and roll phenomenon. The movie appearances of Jose Mari and The Electromaniacs were billed in competition with actor-singer Eddie Mesa, dubbed the “Elvis Presley of the Philippines,” and his backup band, The Hi-Jacks. The Hi-Jacks was led by a tandem: Nonoy Jereza (rhythm guitar) and Dado Amores (drums), with the dexterous lead guitarist Ben Tesoro. The Hi-Jacks’ records, which predominantly featured versions of popular international hits, were also released by a fledgling Dyna Records.

The largest Philippine record company of the time was the Mabuhay Recording Company (Mareco), which issued their products under two record labels—namely, Villar Records and Mabuhay Records. Its owner was Manuel P. Villar, who later was described as the “Father of Philippine Recording.” In the 1950s, Villar released a novelty song titled “Waray-Waray” (a person from Samar or Leyte) that inadvertently became a Filipino rock and roll milestone. Set in a familiar blues progression (I-IV-V), the song’s theatrical irony of using Tagalog lyrics while extolling the qualities of the Waray regional folk had a comedic spin. Interestingly, the recording artist was the actress Sylvia La Torre, a classically trained vocalist dubbed the “Queen of Kundiman.” The entertainment value of “Waray-Waray” was unparalleled in its time. The ditty was a singular exception to Mareco’s traditional recordings of kundiman, balitaw, and other Filipiniana materials. The success of the novelty experiment led Villar Records to release “Hahabol-Habol” (Chasing After), a Tagalog song with a boogie-woogie rhythm that satirized an apparently indecisive damsel, as a follow-up. The featured recording artist was the stage singer and actor Bobby Gonzales.

By 1963, the newly established Mareco Broadcasting Network debuted its first radio station, DZBM-AM, putting the businessman Villar on a path that allowed him to dominate the Philippine recording industry by amassing franchises of major American labels, such as Columbia, RCA, Warner, Elektra, Atlantic, and Mercury. But ironically, surf music’s commercial expectations came to a standstill. The super nova effect of an English rock and roll group called The Beatles had overturned a popular yet unprepared music establishment. In Apr 1964 alone, the “Fab Foursome” simultaneously occupied numbers 1-5 in the Billboard Hot 100 Trade Chart, a historical feat no act has achieved since. The torrent of the mythical “British Invasion” led by the Beatles and followed by similarly odd-named groups, such as the Rolling Stones, the Yardbirds, and the Kinks, changed prevailing norms of entertainment, fashion, and lifestyles. The spectacular rise to fame and glamour of working-class English musicians demonstrated a new kind of power—that of an entertainment form called rock and roll as a formidable social equalizer. The Swinging Sixties then became especially propitious to Dyna Records, the small and independent startup located on Raon Street, Manila, because its exclusive UK-based record franchises, particularly EMI and Parlophone Records, enjoyed an astonishing windfall.

Domestic reaction to the turn of events was swift and inclusive. Neighborhood combos flourished throughout Manila outside the schools. The British heroes’ fans imitated their songs and outfits. The emerging Marikina shoe industry heeded a surging demand for “Beatle boots.” So lucrative was the market that a combo called The Glenmores rose to promote Glenmore Shoes, whose proprietors were the band’s managers. The popular Glenmores featured a husky vocalist and keyboardist named Mike Hanopol, who would later on play a major role in the unfolding story of Philippine combos.

Most prominent of the new combos were D’Downbeats composed of Tony Jalandoni (lead guitar), Charlie Mielieb (rhythm guitar), Eddie Reyes (organ), Tonet Fabie (bass guitar), and Filipino-American Joey Smith (drums and vocals). They were hired as a front act for the two Beatles concerts at the Rizal Memorial Stadium on 4 Jul 1966. But the resounding success of the sold-out concert quickly took a bad turn. The Beatles’ cold response to Imelda Marcos’s invitations for them to come to Malacañan Palace earned them the Marcoses’ ire. The Manila International Airport’s departure area then became the scene for much regret on both sides, prefiguring the checkered futures of both the Beatles and the Marcos regime. The one redeeming aspect of the whole controversy was the emergence of a rock stalwart named Joey Smith.

Oblivious to the disappointing Beatles episode, Philippine television immersed itself in rock and roll shows through the mid-1960s. Televised dance contests took a sharp detour toward rock and roll, particularly The Nite Owl (Dance Party), 1961-63, on Channel 11 hosted by the Manila Broadcasting Company radioman Lito Gorospe. The show’s resident Wonderers combo, later renamed The Celtics, mimicked the day’s radio hits for a crew of after-office dancers, but the show was poorly received and waned quickly. As Mod, hippie, and flower power paradigms of beauty swept through Philippine households, so did the preferences of its impressionable youth.

Acumen and creativity flourished in this era, with 45-rpm singles serving as launching pads for the new emerging captains of the Philippine recording industry. The Ramrods, consisting of Orly Ilacad (lead guitar), Manuel Galvez (rhythm guitar), Virgilio Bertol (bass), and Tony Tuviera (drums), with the line supervision of Ilacad’s cousin Vic del Rosario, released singles under various imprints, such as ANS Records (“Do The Soul”), Mustang Records (“Venus”), and Pioneer (“Bionic Cha-Cha”). Their efforts were limited but outcomes would be far-ranging in later years.

Newly introduced American TV syndications—namely, Shindig! in 1964-66 and Hullabaloo in 1965-66—were drawing exceptional worldwide viewership. Emulating this, ABS-CBN Channel 9’s new television variety show Nineteeners, hosted by actor Ed Finlan and a young prodigious songwriter, Jose Mari Chan, featured “cage dancers” and cameos enacted by sons and daughters of rich families. A cavalcade of bands took prime time, and the Jungle Cats featuring Nilo Santos (vocals), Danny Bornilla (keyboards), Nides Aranza-Mendez (drums), Tony Aranza-Mendez (bass), and a young lead guitarist named Wally Gonzalez topbilled the show.

By 1967, Wally Gonzalez and Mike Hanopol (now turned bassist) had joined Joey Smith’s newly reconstituted Downbeats, by then regarded as Manila’s top rock and roll band. After a contract show in Guam starring Bobby Gonzales and the singer-actress Vilma Valera, the duo of Gonzalez and Smith proceeded to Japan to scout for further engagements and to look up Filipino drummer Eddie Fortuno (who later renamed himself “Edmund Fortuno”) who was part of the D’Swooners, a Filipino soul music band making waves in the Japanese psychedelic music scene.

The rock historian Julian Cope (2007) narrates that D’Swooners was formed in 1963 and by 1965, it headed for Hong Kong, landing a record contract with the Diamond Records label. Cris Solano (vocals, bass), Charlie Cajilig (guitar), Ernie Espiritu (organ), Ronnie Parina (trumpet), and Eddie Fortuno (drums) released a weepy 1950s-style ballad “Sonata of Love” composed by Cris Solano that brought them offers to do front acts for shows by visiting rock stars such as Manfred Mann. Attending Mann’s show in Hong Kong was the Japanese singer-actor Yuzo Kayama, who arranged for the group to appear on Japanese TV. In 1967, the meek Japanese audiences in Tokyo were captivated by D’Swooners’ wild performances. The band was immediately signed up with the Phillips label of Japan, whereupon they released two albums in 1969 before disbanding. Thereupon, Edmund Fortuno returned to Manila.

In a similar development, after an impressive jam session in Tokyo’s Shinjuku district, Wally Gonzalez and Joey Smith were hired to form a cover band for the Japanese entertainment circuit, which they called Zero History. Their erstwhile Downbeats colleague Mike Hanopol was summoned from Manila to sing and play keyboards, along with a bassist singly named Rino. In early 1970, a performance by Zero History in a Yokohama shopping center caught the attention of Shinki Chen, a known guitarist with strong connections to Ikuzo Orita, the president of Polydor Records of Japan. As a platform for Shinki Chen’s thriving career, a “power trio” named Speed, Glue & Shinki with Joey Smith (drums and vocals) and Masayohi Kabe (bass) was formulated by Ikuzo Orita in 1971, who by then had transferred to Atlantic Records. The trio released an album titled Eve. In 1972, after contractual complications, a second Speed, Glue & Shinki album was assembled by Joey Smith for Atlantic Records, assisted by his Zero History colleague Mike Hanopol, in the wake of Chen and Kabe’s departure.

In the Philippines, martial law was declared by President Ferdinand Marcos on 21 Sep 1972. Midnight curfews were imposed and public gatherings were curtailed, turning Greater Manila into an insular culture. Ramon Jacinto fled, narrowly escaping Presidential Decree 1081, and soon his government-sequestered DZRJ was being helmed by an officer in charge from the Philippine Army. Due to the turn of events, a term called Pinoy rock was invented.

Dodie Gonzalez, the enterprising elder brother of Wally Gonzalez, the musician, had produced an album titled Up in Arms for a group named the Juan de la Cruz Band (JDLC). The band was organized by Wally together with the drummer Edmund Fortuno, both of whom had returned in late 1970 from their respective Japanese stints. JDLC figured prominently as the rhythm section of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Redentor Romero in the 1971 production of Jesus Christ Superstar, the rock opera at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. But an early breakup ensued before their album could be recorded. Fortuno led an exodus of Juan de la Cruz Band members who regrouped as Anak Bayan. This event seemed to convince Wally Gonzalez to start all over. But the elder Gonzales intervened. With blocked prime airtime bought from DZRJ, the album tracks of a new Juan de la Cruz Band were broadcast before an impressionable youth market. Their seminal long-playing album Up in Arms, 1971, was released by Sunshine Records, a subsidiary label of a larger independent record company, Vicor Records, owned by the cousins Vic del Rosario and Orly Ilacad of the 1960s combo The Ramrods. Not before long, in 1973, Sunshine Records issued Gonzales’s second JDLCB album, the historic Himig Natin (Our Music), a bold set of collaborative rock compositions by his touring partners Hanopol and Smith. The trio had reached the critical mass and the Juan de la Cruz Band became a household name.

The rival DZBM station of Mareco was quick to mine the rising commercial trend, airing hit singles dominated by their flagship franchise, Motown Records, and marginally attended by album tracks from their vast catalog of foreign licenses. Perhaps because of their diverse library of hits in all genres, DZBM’s impact on Philippine rock music would have been peripheral at best, if not for the Hotdog band. Signed and affiliated to Villar Records, the siblings Rene Garcia (guitar and vocals), Dennis Garcia (bass), and Jess Garcia (drums) led the group that included Lorrie Ilustre (keyboards) and a medley of female singers, such as Ella del Rosario, Zsa Zsa Padilla, and Maso Diez, who would all become entertainment luminaries. The Hotdog was a subdued version of an earlier Garcia family undertaking, a cover band named Red Fox. They crafted a succession of novelty songs starting with “Ikaw ang Miss Universe ng Buhay Ko” (You Are the Miss Universe of My Life) and “Manila,” initially described as rock ballads. But with each successive release by the band, such as “Bongga Ka Day” (You’re Fabulous, Girl), the group veered farther and farther away from their rock influences and became proponents of a pop genre aptly named Manila Sound—after their song.

Toward 1974, DZRJ’s daily primetime slot of songs featuring the Juan de la Cruz Band was reinvented as a diversified Pinoy Rock ’n’ Rhythm show. As proposed by the station’s disc jockeys Allan Austria (aka Double A) and Emil Quinto (aka Charlie Brown) to their government-led management, the program would feature recordings by Philippine rock musicians from all sectors, including compatible genres such as blues and folk music. A mobile recording studio was set up by Austria, using the station’s four-track tape recorder and mixing board, for live-in-the-booth recordings to facilitate the entries of contestants for one of its sponsors, RC Cola, and its First National Battle of the Bands, produced by RC Cola’s then CEO, Cesare Syjuco. More than 200 new songs were said to have been recorded for the Pinoy Rock ’n’ Rhythm show, and these entries were aired in succession through many weeks. These “demos” paved the way for artists such as Florante, Bong Gabriel, Johnny Alegre of Hourglass, Bob Aves of Destiny, and many others, who thrived in the mainstream Philippine record industry in later years. It did not take long for Pinoy Rock ’n’ Rhythm, the show’s title, to be shortened to Pinoy Rock, the term that would also be used to describe the Philippines’ expansive reinvention of Western rock and roll. The program would be hosted by Sonny Pecson (aka Little Rock), Bob Posas (aka Bob Magoo), and Dante David (aka Howlin’ Dave), all of whom would carry on until the mid-1980s.

In 1977, Nilo Santos, formerly with the Jungle Cats, embarked on a promotional campaign for his spouse, the rock vocalist Tessie Alfonso, who had assumed the stage persona “Sampaguita.” She had been collaborating on original songs with the Olongapo-based guitarist Gary Perez. This culminated in a self-titled album released by Vicor Records. Her carrier single titled “Bonggahan” (Revelry) reaffirmed a local penchant for novelty, with its deliberately gay Tagalog jargon exhorting the audience to “all have a good time.” Santos also crafted an image for Pinoy rock as an entertaining yet probative medium of expression. By then he had also assumed the management of Mike Hanopol’s solo career, whose new material struck a similar chord with the listening public. Hanopol’s prodigious album releases—namely, Buhay Musikero (A Musician’s Life), 1976, by Jem Records, and Awiting Pilipino (Filipino Songs), 1977, and Buksan (Open), 1978, by Blackgold Records—were defining moments for Pinoy rock.

MARECO by this time had recorded but only released two singles, “Jeepney Rock” and “Probinsiyana” (Country Girl), from Edmund Fortuno’s JDLCB splinter group. In 1977, finally, under Villar’s A&W Records subsidiary, the complete Anak Bayan album saw the light of day, becoming one of Pinoy Rock’s resounding successes. In 1978, the first album of the much-admired Olongapo-based band Maria Cafra, led by the brothers Resty Fabunan (guitar) and Jun Fabunan (bass), was released by Jem Records. That same year, the first Wally Gonzalez solo album, Wally on the Road, was released by Vicor Music Corporation. By then, though, the country’s commercial music industry had rebounded from the onslaught of bands and took a new turn for what became known as the Original Pilipino Music (OPM) genre. In a much simpler time, the classic rock era, was drawing to a close.

In the heyday of popular music festivals and when balladeers were in vogue in the late 1970s, folk music artists straddled the fine line between pop music and rock music. Singer-songwriter soloists like Florante, Freddie Aguilar, Joey Ayala (and later, his sister Cynthia Alexander), and Emil Sanglay and groups like Banyuhay and Asin prospered in Manila’s rock venues but retained their entertainment sheen. But the underground music scene faced the opposite way, returning to basics in the early 1980s, as a younger generation of aspiring musicians learned to play guitar from Jingle magazine and borderline music publications that reproduced lyrics without copyright permission.

A boom in punk music was underway. Punk was a rudimentary and hard-edged reaction to the excesses of classic 1970s rock. At the turn of the decade, foreign bands like the Sex Pistols, The Clash, and The Ramones caused punk rock to spread worldwide. By 1985, a record imprint named DMZ Records was created by the couple Leslie David and Jingle magazine editor Ces Rodriguez. The first album DMZ released was by Betrayed, and it was issued on cassette tape format, featuring two lineups of the band on both sides. Betrayed was Manila’s seminal punk band consisting of Eddie Siojo (vocals), Buddy Trinidad (guitar), Chris Carire (bass), and Carl Avecilla (drums). In its second edition, Buddy Trinidad continued with Boyet Miguel (bass), Manny Pagsuyuin (drums), and Dominic Gamboa (vocals). Due to the demand for the cassette’s first edition, it was reissued by Twisted Cross Records, another cassette-based imprint owned by the alternative rock entrepreneur Tommy Tanchanco, whose Brave New World events also highlighted bands, such as The Wuds, Urban Bandits, and the new wave band Identity Crisis. The cultural influence of the events Tanchanco organized led to the emergence of alternative rock stations such as DWXB-102.7, LA-105, and even NU-107.

In 1985, the second major wave of Pinoy rock was underway. Two friends, guitarist Teddy Diaz and drummer JB Leonor, had formed a band called The Dawn with bass guitarist Clay Luna, and later, vocalist Jett Pangan. The quartet performed in clubs and recorded a demo titled “Enveloped Ideas,” a copy of which they submitted to a now-defunct radio station, DWXB-102.7. When the group topped the radio station’s playlist in 1986, the group’s loyal following brought them to the attention of Ricky Ilacad of Octo-Arts Records. By that time, their bassist Clay Luna had migrated to the United States and had been replaced by Carlos Balcells. Before disbanding, their recording career with Octo-Arts had spanned eight albums from 1986 to 1995. It included the contributions from later guitarists Atsushi Matsura and Francis Reyes, who took the place of Teddy Diaz after two albums, after his tragic death in 1988. The band’s reunion in 2000 yielded five additional albums for Sony Music Entertainment, making The Dawn the most prolific rock band in the Philippines.

In contrast, The Eraserheads, a band formed by University of the Philippines students Ely Buendia (guitar and vocals), Marcus Adoro (guitar), Buddy Zabala (bass), and Raimund Marasigan (drums), was rejected at every turn until BMG Records Pilipinas agreed to sign them up and released their first album Ultraelectromagneticpop! in 1993. The album featured a carrier single in the proven novelty vein of rock and roll titled “Pare Ko” (My Dude), a composition with Tagalog lyrics peppered with invectives that talked about the travails of unrequited love. In its maiden release, 300,000 copies were sold. Emerging from the Club Dredd movement instigated by the entrepreneur Patrick Reidenbach, the Eraserheads was at the forefront of a host of alternative rock groups that included Color It Red, Hungry Young Poets, Parokya ni Edgar, Afterimage, Wolfgang, Razorback, and many other bands that would soon gain prominence.

The quartet continues to perform until the present day through a jigsaw puzzle band career that spans seven studio albums, three extended play (mini-album) releases, and four anthologies, with sales nothing short of spectacular. Their second album, Circus, 1994, sold 200,000 copies; and the third album, Cutterpillow, 1995, sold 400,000 copies. The four members are proponents of their own bands as well, with Buendia leading two groups, Pupil and The Oktaves; Adoro leading Markus Highway; Zabala joining The Dawn; and Marasigan leading an unspecified number of bands and projects, including Sandwich, Pedicab, and Squid9.

To make passing mention of groups and artists from the 1990s until the present would be an oversimplification because of the sheer number of bands that proliferated during this period. Bands such as Yano, The Youth, Sugar Hiccup, and Teeth set the stage for much that the Eraserheads would accomplish. The rap-metal subgenre, colloquially termed the Kupaw Movement, fronted in the 1999-2003 period by bands such as Greyhoundz, Slapshock, Cheese (later renamed Queso), and Skychurch, sparked much excitement in 2000-2010, with Slapshock alone selling between 20,000 and 30,000 compact discs a month.

A corporate rock band, Rivermaya, originally assembled by the rock impresario Lizza Nakpil, had its revolving door of musicians that included Rico Blanco and Bamboo Mañalac. It exemplified how the concept of rock music could serve the commercial demands of OPM. Independent record labels in the new millennium, such as Terno Recordings, created a large niche of their own, featuring innovative bands like Orange & Lemons, and Up Dharma Down, whose album Fragmented caught the attention of Time magazine in 2006. Presently, the extremely wide variety of subgenres and styles developing in Pinoy rock, some even effectively merging with OPM, would require much further analysis.Written by Juan Bautista H. Alegre

Source:

Cope 2007.

text:
In Western art music, a solo work prominently features an instrument either by itself or with accompaniment by a single instrument or multiple groups of instruments. Accompaniment is secondary to the solo part, unlike in a chamber sonata for violin and piano, in which both instruments play principal parts. Like most music literature written from the end of the 17th century onward, solo works may be broadly classified into tonal (i.e., with melodies and harmonies constructed in relation to a tonal center) or atonal (i.e., with melodies and harmonies constructed with an obscure or nonexistent tonal center). Solo works may be cast in simple form or as self-contained pieces with two-part (binary) and three-part (ternary) structure; in compound form or as a series of simple pieces or movements as in sonatas, suites, or concertos or concerti; or in other 20th-century innovative forms.

Philippine instrumental pieces that emerged in the late 19th and early 20th centuries were written by versatile and homegrown musicians trained in singing, playing of instruments, and composition in convents and institutions, such as the Colegio de Niños Tiples of the Manila Cathedral during the Spanish regime. Those who became leaders of their generation as church musicians, performers, conductors, or teachers include Marcelo Adonay, Jose Canseco, Natalio Mata, Leonardo Silos, Antonio Garcia, Manuel Luna, Andres Dancel, Diego Perez, and Julian Felipe. Together with Conservatory of Madrid-trained Jose Estella and second-generation musicians like Manuel Antonio Mata (son of Natalio), Rosalio Silos (son of Antonio), and the self-taught musician-revolutionary Julio Nakpil, they yielded a combined output that included piano arrangements of Philippine folk songs, piano transcriptions of European orchestral works, as well as original pieces for piano, cello, or guitar in two- or three-part forms, such as gavotte, mazurka, paso doble, habanera, and waltz, which reflected the styles of light European music and European dance forms popular at that time.

The establishment of the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music in 1916 under the American civil administration introduced the study and performance of a prescribed repertory of Western art music literature. Exposure to various forms in school and to performances here and abroad and through records and tapes led to the writing of compositions modeled after major genres in Western classical music. By the mid-1930s, Philippine solo instrumental literature reached its peak as seen in the works of composition graduates Nicanor S. Abelardo, Francisco Santiago, Rodolfo S. Cornejo, and Antonio J. Molina, a composition student of Abelardo. Altogether, these composers produced composite forms, specifically three-piano concertos, four-piano sonatas, two sonatas for violin and piano, one sonata for cello, and single forms and character pieces such as nocturnes, romanzas, and caprices for piano, violin, and cello.

This initial body of solo works was augmented considerably by succeeding generations of composers who trained locally and/or abroad and who became charter and associate members of the League of Filipino Composers (LFC). Like their predecessors, a number sought to express their nationalism through the creative use of Philippine folk songs or nonmusical ideas or programs pertaining to Philippine culture. Others produced works in the 20th-century neoclassic style and in the avant-garde idioms. In The League of Filipino Composers 1989 Directory and Catalogue of Selected Works, piano compositions far outnumber those for violin, cello, and flute, with the least number belonging to the guitar and brasswinds. Similarly, the contest pieces commissioned by the National Music Competitions for Young Artists founded in 1972 were solely piano pieces for categories A (elementary), B (high school), and C (college), totaling 30 compositions. In 1990 the first violin pieces for categories B and C were commissioned.

Piano

Works for piano manifested influences of the romantic, impressionistic, contemporary, and avant-garde schools of composition. The earliest extant solo piano piece written by a Filipino was Diego Perez’s paraphrase of perceived traditional native Philippine music in Recuerdos de Filipinas y sus Cantares, Gran Potpurri para Piano (Memories of Filipinas and Her Songs, Great Collection for Piano), 1886. Other works before the 20th century include Julio Nakpil’s “Recuerdos de Capiz” (Memories of Capiz), and Filemon Sotto’s “Meditacion” (Meditation), 1892. In the 1900s, the romantic bravura style of pianism was exemplified by Francisco Santiago’s Souvenirs of the Philippines, a fantasy in the style of a Paganini-Liszt etude; Francisco Buencamino’s Mayon, a descriptive fantasy for piano and orchestra also arranged for piano solo, “Larawan” (Portrait), “Lullaby,” and “Kumintang”; Rodolfo S. Cornejo’s Philippine Rhapsodies nos. 1, 2, and 3 for piano and orchestra in the style of Liszt; and A. Doronilla’s Philippine Rhapsody, also of Lisztian influence. All of these works employed Philippine folk songs as thematic material. A 19th-century piano genre called lyric or character pieces, which exploited the evocative capabilities of the piano, surfaced in Nicanor S. Abelardo’s “First Nocturne,” “Fantasie Impromptu,” and “Valse Caprice” (Sudden Waltz); Francisco Santiago’s “Nocturne in E-Flat Minor” and “Valsette in F”; Cornejo’s “Nocturne,” “Song without Words,” and “Etude in A-Flat”; and Lucino T. Sacramento’s “Song without Words” and “Romance.”

The piano works of Antonio J. Molina—namely, “Malikmata” (Phantasm), 1939, and “Camia” and “Dancing Fool,” both 1942—were significant departures from the heavily romantic style of the foregoing pieces. Manifesting the influence of Debussy, these compositions contained devices such as the whole-tone scale, pentatonic scale, and the use of 9th and 11th chords. The first was inspired by the poetry of Rafael Zulueta da Costa (the second part of “Eroica” in Like the Molave), the second by the poetry of Francisco Icasiano (“To a Camia”), and the third by the character Sisa in Jose Rizal’s novel Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not). All three pieces were in ternary design flanked by a brief introduction and coda. The first and third parts were usually in the whole tone and pentatonic scale with 9th and 11th chords while the middle parts were lyric and tonal with conventional harmonic progression. The composer suggested a reading of the poetry along with the performance of “Malikmata” or “Camia,” which he called “piano poems.”

Felipe Padilla de Leon’s “Sayaw ng Igorot” (Igorot Dance), 1939, was “boldly modern” with its vigorously repeated percussive chord-clusters on the left hand and 16th-note motifs on the right. It was an attempt to portray an ethnic dance from northern Luzon. His “Kundiman” (Love Song), 1950, leaned toward late romanticism with its modulatory harmonic progressions and lyrical and original melodies. The title implied cantabile and espressivo vocal lines with instrumental interludes.

From 1950 onward, most solo piano works were written in the modern idiom. Toccatas, brilliant pieces aimed at showcasing a performer’s techniques, were written by Antonio J. Molina, Eliseo M. Pajaro, Ryan Cayabyab, Ruben R. Federizon, Ben Tupas, and Jose Alvarez, whose composition won first prize in the 1983 Young Composers’ Competition sponsored by the LFC. The output in piano literature grew steadily with individual contributions and the commissioned contest pieces of the NAMCYA. The contemporary concert repertoire of individual pieces started with the works of Alfredo S. Buenaventura, Bernardino F. Custodio, Lucrecia R. Kasilag, Ramon P. Santos, and Rosendo Santos. Santos’s three-part Mountain City Suite was inspired by the mountain scenery and festivals of Baguio City and Bontoc, Mountain Province. The piece played easily and each movement had a distinct melodic and rhythmic character. He also wrote 12 pieces in the 12-tone technique. Bernardino F. Custodio’s “Sarimanok ” and “Pauli-uli” (Repetition) were NAMCYA contest pieces and effective recital numbers. “Sarimanok” contained rhythmic motifs suggesting Muslim dances, while “Pauli-uli” was in theme and variation form using the first four measures of the folk song “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut).

Lucrecia R. Kasilag’s “Theme and Variation” featured pianistic techniques of increasing levels of difficulty in a variety of styles. She also wrote the only group of pieces for prepared piano known as Derivations I, II, III, and IV. Inspired by the eruption of the longest sleeping volcano in the world in 1991, she composed “Elegy on Mt. Pinatubo” in 1992. Two years later, she wrote “Serendipity.”

The NAMCYA collection of piano contest pieces was a variety of traditional and mostly contemporary pieces written by LFC members. Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s Emotions nos. 1, 2, and 3 were nocturne-like pieces with expressive melodies and contemporary harmonies. Kasilag’s “Rondeau” and “Derivations V: Caprice,” Bayani M. de Leon’s “Kimkim” (Clenched), and Ramon P. Santos’s “Klintang” and “Abot-Tanaw III” (Horizons), were formidable additions to the piano concert repertoire. “Klintang” was inspired by techniques of playing the kulintang (eight-brass gongs of graduated sizes) and drew from the piano’s upper registers a “stream of kulintang sounds” a la perpetuum mobile through rapidly alternating double notes on the left and right hands. In the middle section, sustained clusters in various registers in the bass, alternating with phrases of rapid single notes on the right hand, suggested a dialogue of timbral contrast between a gong and a kulintang. In “Abot-Tanaw III,” Santos brought together the kulintang and the piano through a novel approach—by using the piano as a sound source. Another piece called “Pal’ok” was inspired by palook, the Kalinga term for a manner of playing or producing various timbres on the gangsa (native gong) with a wooden beater. His latest work for piano solo was “Bantayog” (Monument), 2003.

In the advent of the 21st century, composers began incorporating their urban experience into their works and others included environmental concerns while maintaining the intention to create a distinctly Filipino sound on the piano. Chino Toledo composed Cayco Folio, Solos for Piano, which includes four parts: Altered Images, Reflected Images, Layered Images, and Traced Images. Christine Muyco wrote Misteryo sa Gubat (Mysteries of the Forest), 1991, a piano suite for children that included “Lakad sa Gubat” (Walk in the Forest), “Sayaw Diwata” (Fairy Dance), “Yapak Dwende” (Dwarf Step), and “Tila Guni-Guni” (Imagined); and Paghuhugis (Shaping), 1998, another piano suite, which included “Bilog” (Circle), “Parisukat” (Square), “Parihaba” (Rectangle), and “Tatsulok” (Triangle); and “Dypni sa Kalye” (Jeepney on the Road), 2002.

Jeffrey Ching’s output of works for solo piano was written in the classical or neoclassical style. He completed nine sonatas for piano, the last of which was titled “Superklavier” Sonata, 2001, because it was in a single large movement and would last for approximately 45 minutes. In the last years of the 20th century, a special periodic Jeffrey Ching Piano Sonata competition was held in which pianists interpreted his solo sonatas.

In the field of piano pedagogy, Augusto Espino published his collection of Filipino folk songs arranged for young pianists titled Guhit Tugtugin (Musical Lines) in 2000. The compilation aims to provide alternative recital selections derived from popular Philippine folk songs while at the same time being used as a teaching material for beginning and intermediate piano students.

Strings

Violin pieces with piano accompaniment included slow melodious romanzas in ternary form, cavatinas after the style of short operatic arias, binary dance forms like the habanera and danza in moderate tempo, and fanciful caprices, all written in the style of character pieces of the 19th century. Works in this category included Nicanor S. Abelardo’s “Cavatina,” “Reverie,” and “Capriccio Espagnole”; Cornejo’s “Cavatina,” “Melody in F,” and “Caprice d’ Amour” (Whims of Love); Francisco Santiago’s “Serenade” and “Canto Filipino”; Antonio J. Molina’s “Hatinggabi” (Midnight) and “Ilang-Ilang”; Juan S. Hernandez’s “Romanza Appasionata” (Passionate Romance); Lucio D. San Pedro’s “Melody in G”; and Ernesto Vallejo’s “Habanera, nos. 1 and 2.”

Other forms emerged in Eliseo M. Pajaro’s “Fantasy on a Bontoc Melody,” “Visayan Lullaby,” “Variations on a Fugue,” and “Marilag Fantasy,” written in the 20th-century neoclassic style between 1958 and 1976. The next decade and a half yielded contemporary unaccompanied violin pieces like Francisco F. Feliciano’s “Isostasie II,” Ramon P. Santos’s “Abot-Tanaw II,” Conrado del Rosario’s “Darangun,” Chino Toledo’s “At Maging ang Kwerdas Ay Humihingi ng Katarungan para sa Mundo” (And Even the Strings Are Begging for World Justice), and Alfredo Buenaventura’s “Panaghoy” (Outcry). So far, the last two pieces were the only commissioned NAMCYA contest pieces for solo violin.

The concert arrangement for violin and piano based on Philippine folk songs by violinist Gilopez Kabayao were valuable contributions to the repertoire. Among these were “Visayan Curacha” (Visayan Crab), “Sarung Banggi” (One Night), “Ti Ayat ti Maysa nga Ubing” (The Love of a Young Maiden), “Pamulinawen ” (Stonehearted Lady), “Tinikling,” “Walay Angay” (Not Suited), and “Paruparong Bukid” (Country Butterfly). Violinist-conductor Redentor Romero wrote violin arrangements, including some based on Santiago Suarez’s “Katakataka” (How Strange), Velez’s “Kabukiran” (Green Fields), and the Ilocano love song “No Duduaem Pay” (If You Still Doubt My Love).

Cello compositions written before 1950 were mostly character pieces, such as Nicanor S. Abelardo’s “Romanza,” dedicated to Molina, and “Serenade”; Rodolfo S. Cornejo’s “Chant sans Paroles” (Song without Words) and “Habanera”; and Antonio J. Molina’s “Preludio,” “Romanza,” “Prelude and Romanza,” and “Rondo en Fa.” The last two of Molina’s works were based on Filipino melodies and folk songs.

After 1950, cello works included Eliseo M. Pajaro’s “Variations on Piritpit for Cello and Piano,” Jerry A. Dadap’s “Three Short Pieces for Cello,” Ryan Cayabyab’s “Piece for Solo Cello,” and Rosendo Santos’s “Maria Clara’s Lullaby.” Recent additions to the short list of solo works for violoncello were Jeffrey Ching’s “Souvenir des Song,” 1994, revised in 2012, “Seven Preludes to a Prelude,” 2010, and “Trittico Criptico,” 2014.

Pieces for viola were Rosendo Santos’s “Sketches for Viola,” 1964, and Manuel P. Maramba, OSB’s “Suite for Unaccompanied Viola,” 1965.

Solo-guitar literature was exemplified by Jerry A. Dadap’s “Six Pieces Based on Philippine Folk Songs,” Bayani M. de Leon’s “Kapilas na Giting” (A Piece of Courage), Angel M. Peña’s “Prelude and Fugue,” Ramon P. Santos’s “Abot-Tanaw,” 1981, Lucrecia Kasilag’s “Prelude Etnika and Toccata,” 1996, and Chino Toledo’s “Kal’bit” in the 1970s and 1980s, and “Kwaderno para sa Kwerdas” (Notebok for Chords) in the early 2000s.

Winds

Two pieces in theme and variation form with band accompaniment were composed by Lucio D. San Pedro: “Dalagang Mahinhin” (Demure Maiden), 1939, for B-flat clarinet, and “Theme and Variations,” 1956, based on “O Santisima, O Purisima” (Oh Most Holy, Most Pure) for alto saxophone. Other compositions were Rosendo Santos’s “Concert Etude for Alto Clarinet and Piano,” 1964; Angel M. Peña’s “Four Pieces for Clarinet and Piano” and “Romance for Clarinet and Harp,” both 1982; Manuel P. Maramba’s “Three Pieces for Unaccompanied Clarinet,” 1972; and Jerry A. Dadap’s “Two 3 Short Pieces no. 1 for Clarinet,” 1970.

Compositions for flute in the contemporary style included Eric Barcelo’s “Soliloquy for Flute and Piano,” 1967; Eduardo Parungao’s “Pagsapit ng Tag-araw” (When Summer Comes), 1985, for flute and harp; and Juan Cadiz Jr’s “Panagimpan” (Reverie), 1978, for flute and piano.

Contemporary compositions include Bayani M. de Leon’s “Essay for Flute and Piano,” 1972; Rosendo Santos’s “The Inspired Flutist,” 1978; and unaccompanied pieces like Ruben R. Federizon’s “Flute Player,” 1982, Ernani Cuenco’s “Suite for Unaccompanied Flute,” Jonathan Hayag’s “Sa Alaala ni Ben Pangosban” (In Memory of Ben Pangosban), 1987, and Francisco F. Feliciano’s “Ulog” (Deserted), 1979.

There were only a few compositions for brasswinds, and these included Manuel P. Maramba’s “Theme and Variations for Trumpet and Piano,” 1958; Eduardo Parungao’s “Three Short Pieces for Unaccompanied Trumpet, nos. 1 and 2,” 1973 and 1980; Rosendo Santos’s “Etude Brevis for Trombone and Piano,” 1967, “Fantasy for Horn and Piano,” 1969, and “Aria Veloce for Tuba and Piano,” 1969. The repertory of Western-influenced single and self-contained instrumental pieces created by conservatory-trained Filipino composers represented a literature identified with the romantic, impressionistic, and other early 20th-century idioms, and avant-garde or New Music techniques. The use of Philippine-related programs (nonmusical ideas) invested these compositions with a Philippine identity.Written by Mauricia D. Borromeo, w ith additional notes from Arwin Q. Tan



Sources:

Bañas 1975; Buenconsejo 2013; Espino 2000; Hernandez, n.d.; Hila 2004; Kasilag 1989; Laureola 1973; Maceda 1972; Manuel 1955-86; The National Artists of the Philippines 1998; Peña 2007; Randel 1986.

text:
The sonata is a multi-movement work for solo instrument, such as a piano sonata, violin sonata, violoncello sonata, or flute sonata. In the case of the last three, the piano usually accompanies or supports the solo instrument. The normal scheme of movements is allegro-andante-minuet-allegro. Frequently, however, the minuet or scherzo is omitted, leaving a fast-slow-fast order of movements. In some sonatas of the 19th century, such as those of Franz Liszt, the alternating fast and slow movements were merged into one long, continuous movement with contrasting sections.

As a rule, each movement of the sonata follows a preordained structure. The first movement is almost always cast in sonata-allegro form, which consists of a repeated exposition introducing the principal themes, a development that amplifies this material, and a recapitulation or summing up that restates the themes. In the second movement, any one of a variety of forms may be used: sonata-allegro, a simple ternary (ABA) or binary (AB) form, a theme and variation, or a sonatina (abridged sonata-allegro). The third movement is always cast in a large tripartite form: minuet (aababa)-trio (ccdcdc)-minuet (aba). The same scheme is used for movements called scherzo, the difference only being in the tempo and character of the themes. The final movement is either another sonata-allegro structure or a rondo (ABA; ABACA; ABACABA). The same sonata structure is found in other instrumental music, like the symphony, such as string quartet and other types of chamber music, and concerto, though slightly modified.

In the Philippines, composers learned to write sonatas in conservatories or academies of music. The earliest recorded sonata by a Filipino is the Sonata in G Major, 1921, for piano composed by Nicanor S. Abelardo. Cast in three movements (allegro-adagio-presto), the work was first presented during his graduation recital. This was followed in 1922 by Francisco Santiago’s Sonata Filipina in D-Flat Major in three movements, also for piano. Santiago used folk song melodies as thematic materials. The first movement, “Moderato Assai,” is based on the Tagalog balitaw and the Visayan folk song “Lulay”; the second movement, “Andante,” is based on a kundiman; and the final movement, “Rondo,” uses the “Magtanim Ay Di Biro” (Planting Rice is Never Fun) melody. Like the earlier Abelardo opus, the sonata formed part of Santiago’s graduation recital program. Rodolfo S. Cornejo’s three sonatas belong to this same period, and evince a similar style of writing. Written while still a student, first at the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music and then at the Chicago Musical College, were his Piano Sonata, 1929, Sonata for Violin and Piano, 1932, and Sonata for Cello and Piano, 1932.

The solo sonata literature in the ensuing decades was sparse. Composers favored the shorter, one-movement pieces, which were then in vogue. With their descriptive titles, these pieces were more readily appreciated by the general audience. Amada Santos-Ocampo’s Piano Sonata in D-Flat, 1942, and Rosendo Santos’s Piano Sonata, 1948, were both written as academic requirements.

Toward the end of the 1960s and 1970s, more sonatas appeared. The founding of the League of Filipino Composers (LFC) in 1955 brought about a reawakening of interest in chamber music, particularly due to their annual Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP)-sponsored Philippine Music Festivals. Solo sonatas by LFC members include Antonino Buenaventura’s Sonata for Viola and Piano, 1969; Angel M. Peña’s Sonata for Doublebass and Piano, 1970; Hilarion F. Rubio’s Piano Sonata, 1971; Bayani M. de Leon’s Perlas Sonata for Cello and Piano, 1971; and Eliseo M. Pajaro’s Piano Sonata no. 1, 1976, and Piano Sonata no. 2, 1977. Earlier in 1961, Lucrecia R. Kasilag composed the Sonate Orientale for piano.

In the United States, Rosendo Santos, while serving as band director and resident composer at Wilkes Barre College, wrote several sonatas for wind instruments and piano: Sonata Allegro for Tuba, 1969; Sonata no. 1 for Tuba, 1970; Sonata no. 2 for Clarinet, 1971; Sonata in G Minor for Piano, 1984; and Sonata in F for Horn, 1989. Angel Peña wrote his Sonata no. 2 for Double Bass and Piano while he was living in Hawaii in 1989.

The sonata form has not been popular with the younger generation of composers who have favored more contemporary forms and techniques. The only exception is Jeffrey Ching who has composed eight sonatas for solo piano, three for flute (1985, 1988, and 1989), and one for violin (D Major, 1986-89). His “Superklavier” Sonata, 1992, has been revised a number of times from 1998 to 2012. He has two versions of his arrangement of Wagner’s Wesendonck Lieder—one for mezzo-soprano, viola, and piano, and another for mezzo-soprano, violoncello, and piano, titled Wesendonck Sonata, 2012.Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, u pdated by Arwin Q. Tan

Sources:

Kasilag 1989; Manuel 1955-86; Peña 2007.

text:
Song debate is a type of song characterized by alternating response between male and female singers who try to outwit each other on various topics, particularly love, courtship, and marriage. These topics point to the song type’s origin in traditional marriage negotiations, which are still practiced by the lumad (indigenous cultural communities), particularly in Southern Mindanao, in which representatives of the families of the wife-giver and the wife-taker “debate” or outdo each other concerning the value of the soon-to-be bride in terms of bride price and dowry. In other places where the social exchange leading to marriage is no longer done, the song debate evolved into a public entertainment form in social gatherings, especially at weddings where the male singer expresses and defends the role of men in the family or community, and the female singer, the role of women. Centering therefore on the theme of male-female relations, the debate is often witty and humorous, eliciting loud laughter and side comments from listeners. Philippine song debate forms are called by various names, like dallot (Ilocano), liwliwa (Ifugao), erekay (Cuyunon), balitaw (Cebuano), panonoroon (Maranao), pagsindil (Tausug), setolu (Tboli), and stalo (Blaan). The most popular song debate among the Tagalog and Cebuano is the balitaw. These forms utilize only two singers except the liwliwa, which is sung by two groups of men and women in alternation, and the pagsindil by three or more professional singers who take turns singing.

Philippine song debate forms are often accompanied by musical instruments like kutibeng (five-stringed guitar) for the dallot, yuke (ukelele) for the erekay, harp or guitar for the balitaw, and gabbang (bamboo xylophone) and/or biola (violin) for the pagsindil. Among the Tboli and Blaan, gender opposition and complementarity are symbolically represented in the marriage negotiations by a woman singing, accompanying herself with the bamboo-plucked zither, and a man singing, accompanying himself with the two-stringed lute. The instruments usually provide melodic and harmonic ostinati as support to the singing.

A private and more intimate type of song rendered in alternation between a male and female singer is the Hanunuo ambahan (courtship song) accompanied by a three-stringed fiddle called gitgit. A subtype of song debate called dayunday has evolved among Maguindanaon speakers in Cotabato since the 1970s, in which two men, accompanying themselves on the guitar, compete with each other on stage in front of a woman, using improvised and using playful innuendos in verse about love and desire.Written by Felicidad A. Prudente, u pdated by Jose S. Buenconsejo



Sources:

Gutierrez 1961; Hanunoo Music from the Philippines 1955; Lorrin 1978; Mora 1987; Oh 2010; Prudente 1977; Talusan 2005; Trimillos 1972.

text:
Sound art is a branch of contemporary art and a subcategory of media art that utilizes sound as the main medium or as an associated component. Sound art “pieces” are commonly hybrid in form, with practitioners coming from various disciplines, such as the plastic and visual arts, theater and film, electronic and new media, and popular music. Sound artists frequently utilize the electronic platform but also engage in the acoustic medium, including the human body and the sonic environment, generally employing formalistic approaches as well as improvisation, interactivity, spatial dimension, and extended technique (known within the craft as sound bending). The art, however, may still be considered in its infancy and its definition, including the minimal requirements for a piece to be considered as belonging to sound art, is still evolving.

While sound artists currently distance themselves from music as a discipline (e.g., preference for “noise” over musical sounds and identification as “sound artists” rather than “composers”), sound art falls within the broad-spectrum definition of music as “organized sound,” and the initial examples were associated with 20th-century music movements. Often cited are the Italian Futurist school and Luigi Russolo’s 1913 manifesto The Art of Noises, which called for the use of modern technology in art, culminating in the construction of the intonarumori, an assemblage of noisemaking machines. The early avant-garde French composer Erik Satie pioneered the use of everyday sounds in his ballet Parade, 1916-17, and the recontextualization of musical performance from presentational to ambient and functional in Musique d’Ameublement (Furniture Music), 1917. Advancements in technology, particularly the invention of the tape recorder, allowed for the use of nonmusical sound sources and the electronic medium in the musique concrete compositions of Pierre Schaeffer in the early 1940s. Meanwhile, the musical experimentations of American composer John Cage further established the use of nonconventional sound sources, improvisation, and indeterminacy in compositions such as Imaginary Landscapes, 1939-52. Edgard Varese pioneered electronic music in his works, such as the Poeme Electronique composed in collaboration with renowned architect Le Coubusier for the Philips Pavilion in the World’s Fair held in Brussels in 1958. Other contributing sources for sound art include the fields of acoustics, conceptual art, media art, Dadaism, spoken word, experimental theater, and acoustic ecology. The very first use of the term in the United States, however, is attributed to William Hellerman’s show Sound/Art held in New York in 1983.

What might be considered the earliest examples of Philippine sound art were the works of composer Jose M. Maceda (1917-2004) such as Cassettes 100, 1971, and Ugnayan, 1974, which foreshadowed current experimentations with everyday sounds, the electronic media, and nonconventional avenues of presentation. In fact, Maceda has become a legendary figure in today’s Filipino sound artists circle, being regarded as a cult hero, whose revolutionary musical ideas parallel their own aesthetic principles. The development of the craft, however, took place independently, outside the world of the academe and art music. Pioneering groups began sprouting as early as 1989, such as the Children of Cathode Ray established by Jing Garcia aka autoceremony. Typical of the current crop of sound art practitioners, Garcia’s background was in the recording and media industries, writing as well as a tech editing for The Manila Times. His work Bali-ing at Dawn, 2013, was a 30-minute piece that digitally manipulated a field recording made by Maceda in 1967.

Co-founding the Children of Cathode Ray with Garcia, Tad Ermitaño is one of the most prolific sound artists in the country, active in both the local and international art scenes. Ermitaño is a media artist, writer, and filmmaker who classifies himself as a media artist with a special interest in sound. His piece titled “Quartet,” 2008, featured at the International Symposium on Electronic Art, revealed his interest in elementary robotics. In this interactive work, he installed solenoid beaters on Javanese gamelan instruments that are triggered by the “conducting” motions of viewers.

Like Garcia and Ermitaño, Earl “Tengal” Drilon maintains an active presence in Philippine media arts. Tengal is a filmmaker and music producer who has been involved in sound art since 2005, exhibiting his work, performing, and giving lectures in Europe and Asia. As a curator, his notable projects include Sinemusikalye, 2008, commissioned by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, which involved multiple video projectors, giant screens, and live and electronic sounds. Tengal founded the SABAW Media Art Kitchen, an initiative dedicated to promote works created by artists, makers, and designers from the Philippines and the Southeast Asian region. In his work titled 30 Sounds in a Filing Cabinet, 2013, Tengal fitted sensors in each of the drawers of a library card catalogue, which, when pulled, triggers a recording from the Maceda ethnomusicology archive, allowing for a total of over a million sound combinations.

Instrument builder Lirio Salvador embodies another segment of the country’s group of sound artists. Salvador, reminiscent of the Futurists, salvages industrial refuse, such as gears, pipes, springs, and utensils, and crafts them into sound-producing sculptural assemblages. He founded the ensemble Elemento that regularly performs in festivals and art exhibits using his instruments and homemade synthesizers. In 2012, Salvador’s work was featured at the Vargas Museum at the University of the Philippines in an exhibit titled Sandata.

Other artists who have made significant contributions to the expansion and development of sound art in the country include Cris Garcimo aka BLEND:ER, an electronica enthusiast who has experimented with audio acrobatics and technoid sonic landscapes since 1999. Mark Laccay, an award winning audio engineer and sound designer, worked as the main audio consultant for the Jose Maceda Collection Digitization Project. Laccay established ArtisteConnect, a platform for crowdsourcing funds for local creative endeavors. Erick Calilan aka Ugong, who uses mixers, effects, and other consumer electronic devices in his work, released a CD titled Morka Pica, 2007. Malek Lopez, who began as a classical guitarist as well as a filmmaker, is considered one of the pioneers of live electronica in the country. He has collaborated with international composers, fusion jazz groups, improvisation ensembles, and techno performers. Arvin Nogueras aka Caliph8 is a sound creator and vinyl archivist, who performs and creates music with Malek Lopez and Fred Sandoval of the group Bent Lynchpin.

Among the notable events that highlight sound artists in the country is the annual Fete de la WSK that began as a parody of the French Embassy-sponsored Fete de la Musique in 2008. The festival features performances, exhibits, lectures, and workshops dedicated to contemporary electronic, digital, and experimental sonic art and other artistic expressions. The Lopez Museum held Reverb in 2011, which featured the works of artists like Eric Ambata, Kawayan de Guia, Tad Ermitaño, IC Jaucian, Diokno Pasilan, Ronald Tomas, the collaborative E.X.I.S.T. (Experimentation in Sound Art Tradition), and Christine Muyco. In 2013, the UP Center for Ethnomusicology commemorated its 16th anniversary with an exhibit dedicated to the life and work of Jose Maceda titled Listen to My Music at the Vargas Museum. The affair was highlighted by most of the sound artists mentioned above who featured pieces in confluence with Maceda’s work and philosophy.Written by Verne de la Peña

Sources:

Aguila 2011; E.X.I.S.T. 2010; Licht 2007; The Philippine Star 2008b; Varese 1966; Wong 2013.
