text:
Symphonic literature refers to the musical compositions created for the symphony. The word “symphony” is derived from the Greek syn (together) and phone (sounding) and combined in the Latin term symphonia. Symphonic works are extended compositions fororchestra and may consist of several movements as in a symphony or a suite, or of a single movement with multiple sections, as in a symphonic poem or a concert overture.

The symphony is asonatawritten for orchestra with three to four basic contrasting movements within a musically unified scheme.The concert overture is usually written in sonata-allegro form, like the first movement of a symphony.In a suite, which is an ordered set of individual pieces, the element of unity is either musical or nonmusical. Musical means it has a common key, form, source, or a nonmusical idea. A nonmusical idea, also called a “program,” is usually indicated in the title or described in the remarks accompanying the score.The symphonic poem, also known as the tone poem, is based on a nonmusical poetic or realistic concept.

Early examples of Philippine orchestral writing were mentioned by Antonio J. Molina in his article “Music: Between God and Man.” First performed at the Manila Grand Opera House on 30 Dec 1911 was a set of seven compositions inspired by episodes in the life of Jose Rizal: “Rizal at the Dawn of Life” byFranciscoBuencamino, “Rizal under the Robe of Minerva” by Crispino Reyes, “Rizal on the Pegasus” by Tereso Zapata, “Rizal, the Fatherland’s Crusader” byJuanS.Hernandez, “Rizal in Lonesome Dapitan” by Gavino Carluen, “Rizal in His Last Night” by Antonio G. Escamilla, and “Rizal Glorified” byMarceloAdonay.These seven composers came from diverse backgrounds.Buencamino was a pianist-teacher-composer known for his brilliant piano works, such asMayon Concerto (The Mayon Volcano) andLarawan (Portrait). Reyes was a piano teacher at San Beda College and Colegio de San Juan de Letran and composer of several sarsuwela. Zapata was a violinist and conductor of the First Constabulary Band, and composer of a four-movement symphonic suite and two operas. Hernandez was a pianist and composer of a piano concerto,Maria Clara’s Song, and a Mass. Carluen was a pianist-organist-composer and brother of opera composer Alejo. Escamilla was a member oftheAsociacion MusicaldeFilipinas. And Adonay was the humbletiple who rose to become conductor of the orchestra at San Agustin Church and composer par excellence of church music. The only thing they had in common was that they were all drawn into this endeavor by their innate patriotism.

In 1916, the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music was founded.As enrollment increased, Zapata, and much later, Hernandez, joined the faculty. In 1920, the conservatory started to produce graduates who became the country’s prominent teachers, performers, and composers of symphonic works.

From 1921 to 1950, majority of compositions were cast in the mold of Western classical forms, such as the symphony, suite, overture, and tone poem.Such works quoted or creatively utilized Filipino Folk songs as thematic material and sometimes featured indigenous instruments.With few exceptions, these were mostly written in the musical language of the late 19th-century romanticists which was characterized by well-defined tonalities, lyrical melodies, chromatic harmonies, and rich orchestral colors.

The above trend continued but new approaches also surfaced.Original themes emerged; some were juxtaposed with existing melodies. Music performance resources were expanded to include choirs, soloists, and/or narrator. With certain foreign-trained composers writing in the modern idiom, the musical language expanded to include that of the 20th century.

The years 1951-70 witnessed the birth of three institutions that became potent forces in the creation and performance of Philippine symphonicliterature. The first was theLeagueofFilipino Composers (LFC), organized in 1955 under the auspices of the Regional Music


Commission of Southeast Asia, which held yearly festivals that premiered commissioned works by its members.The second was the MusicPromotionFoundationofthePhilippines (MPFP) created by law in 1956, which funded scholarships for orchestral musicians and awarded prizes to outstanding works.And the third was the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines(CCP), inaugurated in 1969, which founded its own orchestra and commissioned new symphonic works.

As a result of the establishment of these institutions, more commissioned symphonic genres were produced. While compositions in the standard classical forms of overtures, suites, and symphonic poems continued to be written, more works broke away from the previousmold. Moreover, a good number of pieces were written by younger composers who had studied modern composition technique in the United States or Europe, and whose creative energies continue to have an impact on modernism in Philippine symphonic music.

Symphonies

The balitaw-based Filipinas Symphony, 1928, byJoseEstella is considered the first Philippine symphony. Nicanor S. Abelardo’s symphony was left unfinished due to his untimely demise in 1934. Francisco Santiago’sTaga-ilog Symphony in D Minor, 1938, was performed in 1939 at the inaugural concert honoring UP’s sixth president, Bienvenido Gonzales.The four-movement work featured the folk melody“Lulay”in the first movement and the Cordillera barimbawand gongsin the orchestration.

Another four-movement symphony was Far Eastern Allies, 1943, by RodolfoS.Cornejo. Commissioned by President Manuel L. Quezon, the work was based on a five-note musical theme (A, B, C, D, F), with each note representing a nationality in the Allied forces: (A)merican, (B)ritish, (C)hinese, (D)utch, and (F)ilipino.Cornejo wrote the piece 10 years after obtaining a master’s degree in music from the Chicago Musical College, whose alumni included government scholarsAbelardoandSantiago.

In 1959, the MPFP commissioned Antonino Buenaventura’s Symphony no. 1 in C, 1960.The four-movement opus was influenced by tunes from all over the country: the tagulaylay and a nose-flute melody from Luzon, lyric airs from Visayas, and instrumental and vocal music from Mindanao.Compositional techniques included imitative, canonic, and fugal treatment of themes with neoromantic harmonies.The native guitar and Cordillera gongs in the orchestration complemented the allusions to folk melodies.

Eliseo M. Pajaro’s Philippine Symphony no. 1, 1952, in three movements, was written in the 20th-century neoclassic idiom and incorporatesd rhythmic motives and melodic contours of “BahayKubo”


(Nipa Hut),“Pamulinawen”(Stonehearted Lady), and“MagtanimAyDiBiro” (Planting Rice Is Never Easy).In 1962, Pajaro composedPhilippine Symphony


no. 3. Jerry A Dadap’s two symphonies in three movements (no. 1, 1966, no. 2, 1967), with original themes, were likewise in early 20th-century idioms. Dadap’s innovative Alay sa Inang Bayan: Choral Symphonic Ode (Dedicated to the Motherland), 1963, added the rondalla to the chorus and orchestra. Other symphonies included Rosendo Santos’s Symphony nos. 1 and2, 1961, andno. 3, 1962; Amada G. Santos Ocampo’s Symphony no. 2, 1964; Hilarion Rubio’s Symphony for Greatness, 1966; and Rosalina Abejo’s Thanatopsis Symphony, 1967, andBeatriz Symphony, 1968.

After 1970, the LFC directory listed the following symphonies: Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s Kayumanggi (Brown), 1971, andDakilang Lahi (Noble Race), 1978; Lucino T. Sacramento’s Symphony in D Minor, 1972; Antonio J. Molina’s Choral SymphonyAng Batingaw(The Bell), 1972; Rodolfo S. Cornejo’sDedication Symphony, 1976; and Antonino Buenaventura’sSymphony no. 4 in B-Flat Major orThe New Horizon, 1980.

Ang Batingaw byAntonioJ.Molina 1972 was based on Cornelio Dalistan’s poem of the same title. Each movement was named after a type of bell: “Kampanang Tansong Wagas” (Pure Bronze Bell), “Bakal na Batingaw” (Iron Bell), “Kampanang Pilak na Batingaw” (Silver Bell), and “Kampanang Ginto Mandin” (Truly Golden Bell).Molina quoted the Negrito song “Panelan” in the first movement; anawit(metrical romance) melody and a Cordillera mourning song “Na-a-anto-ay” in the second; the Pampangofolksong “AtinCuPungSing-sing” (I Have a Ring) and the children’s song “Banda ng Musika” (Music Band) in the third; and theIvatanrowing song “Kalusan” and a 19th-century popular song, “Paalam sa Pagkadalaga” (Farewell to Maidenhood), in the last movement. Speaking parts by the chorus were included for textual, coloristic, and dramatic effects.The music was characterized by 19th-century harmonies, chromaticism, and neomodality.

New Horizon Symphony, or Symphony no. 4 in B Flat, 1980, composed byAntonino Buenaventuramanifested his mastery of formal design and orchestration.The first movement “Allegro Allamarcia” in sonata-allegro form was followed by “Andantino Lamentuoso” wherein akumintang melody was written with its characteristic augmented second interval while its rhythmic pattern was incorporated in the basic meter.The last movement “Allegro Energico,” in ternary form, recapitulated the composer’s philosophical vision as suggested by the title.

Other symphonies were accomplished byRosalinaAbejo, RVM: Trilogy of Man, 1971; Guerilla Symphony, 1972; Fortaleza Symphonyand the choralPag-ibig sa Tinubuang Bayan (Love for One’s Land of Birth), 1979; andthe Third Symphony (Hold High the Torch), 1981. The practice of titling symphonic genres in the Tagalog language or according to specific programs or extramusical themes relating to Philippine culture is an indication of pride in the Filipino identity.

Overtures

For a time, only the UP Conservatory of Music offered a teacher’s diploma in science and composition. The curriculum required its graduates to present a public recital consisting of an orchestral work and solo vocal or instrumental pieces. The required recital format repertoire was observed until the 1940s. Thus, Juan S. Hernandez wrote Simoun Overture in 1920. Abelardo presented Mountain Suite, among other works, in 1921. However, while on a study grant at the Chicago Music College, he composed Cinderella Overture, 1931, which won for him the Wesley La Violette scholarship in composition. In 1922, Santiago presented Philippine Overture and Intermezzo, both for orchestra, and several solo and ensemble pieces for piano, voice, violin, and cello. Other overtures written as graduation pieces were Antonino Buenaventura’s Concert Overture, 1929; Hilarion F. Rubio’s Florante at Laura Overture, 1933; Lucino T. Sacramento’s Concert Overture in A Minor, 1934; Lucio D. San Pedro’s Overture in D Minor: Malakas at Maganda Overture (The Strong and the Beautiful), and Overture in Bb Major, Voyage for Band, both 1938; Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Mariang Makiling Overture, 1939; and Eliseo M. Pajaro’s Cry of Balintawak, 1947.

The first overture commissioned by the MPFP wasPilipinas Kong Mahal(My Beloved Philippines), 1959, byHilarionF.Rubio, followed byBathaluman (Beautiful Goddess), 1965, by Alfredo S. Buenaventura.The first work quoted Igorotand Itneg melodies and the folk song “Si Nanay, Si Tatay Namasol sa Dagat” (Mother, Father Went Fishing in the Sea).In the recapitulation, the audience was invited to sing “Pilipinas Kong Mahal.” Rewritten for band in 1963, it became a contest piece for the National Band Contest sponsored that year by the MPFP. InBathaluman, Alfredo S. Buenaventura created original and contrasting themes reflecting the combination of aBathalaor deity and the Paralumanor human muse, a paradox further represented through the setting of romantic and lyric themes against a background of whole tone-scale progressions and quartal and quintal harmonies.

Other overtures included Restituto Umali’s Filipino Medley Overture, 1953; Lucino T. Sacramento’s Festival Overture, 1955; Jerry A. Dadap’s Habagat Overture, 1962, and Concert Overture, 1963; Francisco F. Feliciano’s Tomas Claudio Overture, 1964; and Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s Philippine Festival Overture, 1964. Overture 1081, 1974, by Rosalina Abejo, RVM, was dedicated to the late president Ferdinand Marcos, while Restituto Umali’s romantic Dangal ng Lahi (Pride of the Race), 1987, honored the Filipinos’ love for peace and freedom. Additional overtures were Felipe Padila de Leon’s Maynila Overture, 1976, Rosendo Santos’s Destiny Overture, 1989 and Ryan Cayabyab’s Pepe and Pilar Overture, 1990.

Suites

Jose Estella’s four-part orchestral suiteEl Cancionero Filipino (The Filipino Singer), subtitled Los Jaranistas(The Serenaders), depicted the harana through aptly named movements: “De Harana” (On the Way to a Serenade), a gay waltz with adaigonmelody from Cebu; “La Enfrentada” (The Meeting), the serenaders’ “arrival” piece preparatory to the next phase, apasodoblemarch that quotes a Panaybalitaw; and “Declaracion de Amor” (Declaration of Love), with the serenade proper and climax of the work featuring a Visayan balitaw.The last part, in duple time and named “De Retirada” (The Retreat), indicated the singers’ departure after the serenade.El Cancionero Filipinois but one example of a Western musical form with an eventful Philippine program.

Bernardino Custodio’s contribution was Malayan Suite, 1932. Other suites were composed with programs relating to regional, urban, or rural life and scenery, along with folk songs as thematic material. There were outstanding examples of works that referred to regions.PhilippineSuite, 1935, by Ramon Tapales had three movements: “Mindanao Orchids,” “Lullaby,” and “Savage War Dance,” which created sonic imagery through repeated motifs, the use of aTagaloglullaby, vigorous rhythms, and orchestral timbres.MindanaoSketches, 1947, in two movements by Antonino Buenaventura, features gongs, handclapping,Manobothemes, and orchestral coloring that evoke the solemn and exuberant moods of a village festival.The five-part Philippine Panorama Suite, 1969, by Alfredo S. Buenaventura was commissioned by the CCP. Its original themes and borrowed melodies were from different regions of the Philippines: the Tagalog “Inday sa Balitaw” (Woman in the Fishtraps), “Dalagang Mahinhin” (Demure Maiden), and “Matulog Na ang Bunso Kong Sinisinta” (Sleep, My Darling Baby); the Muslim “Daing sa Laud” (Cry for Laud); and the Ifugao “Salidom-ay” and “Dang-dang-ay”—all developed in romantic contemporary styles.

ManilaSketches, 1949, byFelipePadilladeLeon,and Suite Pastorale, 1959, by Lucio San Pedro represented works with a program or nonmusical idea referring to a specific social setting. Early 20th-century urban scenes were depicted with wit and humor in the first work, with the following movements: “MusikongBumbong”(Bamboo Music), “Carromata” (Carriage), “Calle Ongpin” (Ongpin Street), “Aso’t Pusa” (Dog and Cat), and “Otomobile” (Automobile). Suite Pastorale, 1956, portrayed life and scenery in rural Angono, Rizal.Its five movements were “Abot Tanaw” (Horizons), “Dapithapon” (Dusk), “Meditasyon” (Meditation), “SaUgoyngDuyan” (In the Cradle’s Rocking), and “Pistahan sa Nayon” (Barrio Fiesta).

Following the trend of featuring the local setting were Philippine Scenes, 1974, in three movements, by LucreciaR.Kasilag; Luzviminda, 1983, in three movements, by Restituto Umali, which had regional tunes—namely, “Pamulinawen,” “Walay Angay,” “Tabe Noña,” “Sua-sua”—as well as Santiago’s “Kundiman” and the Philippine National Anthem.TheBukidnon Suite, 1990, by Manuel Maramba focused on life and scenery in Malaybalay, Bukidnon.Other “imagery” suites include Rosendo Santos’sLakeside Suite, 1956, andMindoro Sketches, 1961; Hilarion F. Rubio’sBuhay at Kalikasan Tularawan (Life and Nature-Poetry-Portrait), 1971, based on a poem of the same title; Eduardo Parungao’sMga Tanawin sa Bulubundukin(Views in the Mountains), 1977; and Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Tatlong Tunog Larawan (Three Sound Portraits), 1976.Antonino Buenaventura’s Impressions, 1978, and Lucrecia R. Kasilag’sImpressions, 1982, were musical journals of their travels abroad.The last movement of both works ventured into the realm of jazz.

Symphonic or Tone Poem

Based on extra musical concepts, symphonic poems depict, evoke, or refer to a program. The works render a wide range of subjects such as human qualities and virtues as expressed in literary texts, local scenery and place, historical and biblical events,legends and epics, personalities, and even abstract ideas.

Antonino Buenaventura’sYouth, 1946, and Lucio D. San Pedro’sHope and Ambition, 1946, articulated human quality and virtue. Youth, inspired by Jose Rizal’s poem“AlaJuventudFilipina” (Fair Hope of My Fatherland), was written for the inauguration of the Philippine Independence.It won first prize in the National Music Contest of 1946.The symphonic poem Hope and Ambition won another prize in the same contest—a scholarship in composition at the Juilliard School of Music under the sponsorship of the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra. Another work was by Eliseo M. Pajaro titled Ode to the Oblation, 1949, which was inspired by the poem eulogizing the virtues embodied in the celebrated masterpiece UP Oblation by National Artist for sculpture Guillermo Tolentino. Also belonging to this group were Bayani M. de Leon’sPagkamulat(Awakening), 1974, Alfredo S. Buenavenura’s Sandigan (Foundation), 1978, Dulambuhay (Life-Drama), 1978; Dugong Kayumanggi(Malayan Blood), 1979, and Gintong Alaala(Golden Memory), 1980.

The next common subject of symphonic tone was the landscape or place. Included here was Antonino Buenaventura’sBy the Hillside, 1941, which won the top prize during the 1941 Music Festival in Baguio.With impressionistic devices and orchestral coloring, the composer depicted his introspections from childhood to adulthood one late afternoon, and concluded his meditations at sundown with triumphant faith in the future.Another tone poem based on local scenes was Lucio D. San Pedro’s Moon over the Hills, 1952. In this work, San Pedro painted a changing landscape with village activities as the full moon rises over the hills of Angono, gradually illuminating the town and slowly disappearing behind a dark cloud. A later example was de Leon’s Roca Encantada: A Symphonic Legend (Enchanted Stone), 1950, which depicted a rock near Guimaras, Iloilo, believed to be endowed with protective powers.

Monumental events in Philippine history and in the Bible formed another set of program in Philippine symphonic poems. In this subcategory belonged Felipe Padilla de Leon’s works such as Bataan, 1947, and Cry of Balintawak, 1948, which were musical odes to the Filipino’s historic struggle for freedom and patriotic heroism. In 1968, Alfredo Buenaventura also wrote Corregidor Symphonic Poem, 1968, and GomburzaSymphonic Poem, 1981. Biblical events as programmatic elements appeared in tone poems like Lucio D. San Pedro’sThe Transfiguration of Christ, 1950, which was for orchestra and female voices. This was commissioned by the League of Filipino Composers and was followed by Manuel P. Maramba’s work on a similar title, Transfiguration I, 1983.

Folklore, especially legends and epics, was also a favorite program in tone poems. This was seen in Pajaro’s LifeofLam-ang, 1951, which was based on the Ilocano epic and which utilized melodies from Ilocano folk songs, such as “Pamulinawen,” (Stonehearted Lady) “TiAyattiMaysangaUbing” (The Love of a Young Child), “ManangBiday,” and a traditional wedding chant, dallot. The tunes were all in juxtaposition, as countermelodies or as leitmotifs. The sonic idiom consisted of neomodality, triadic, quartal, and quintal harmonies, parallel fourths, fifths, and chromaticism. Another piece was Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s Manik Buangsi and Tuan Putli, 1978, based on a Tausug-Samal tale that unfolds in six sections: “Dreams and Longings,” “Opening of the Celestial Kingdom,” “Courtship and Romance,” “Royal Wedding,” “Dangerous Journey,” and “Death of Tuan Putli.”

Some tone poems rendered homage to endeared people, like Rodolfo S. Cornejo’s Ruby, 1964, which included a choral obbligato, actually a two-syllable vocalise (singing with syllables) on Ruby, the only word sung in the entire work. “Ruby” is the composer’s daughter.Another work is Eduardo Parungao’sParangal at Pagpupugay (Commemoration and Salutation), 1977, which was originally for band and rescored for orchestra in 1977. It honored Mariano Zabat Jr, a prominent band conductor, and all the country’s dedicated band leaders.

Two composers whose program was abstract were Bayani M. de Leon who composed Batong-Buhay (Fine-Grained Stone), 1968, and Ramon P. Santos who did The Chant Symphonic Poem, 1963. Santos would later write his Penomenon, 1980, which consisted of five pieces, each one depicting in the abstract events in Filipino life: Pagdiriwang, Pasyon, Balang, Harana, Agay-ay. The opus creatively explored the atmospheric dimensions and experiential facets of each event.

Other Works

Compositions apart from the aforementioned standard symphonic genres have emerged and could be classified under four groups, all of which manifesting nonconventionality.

One group consists of abstract, single-movement symphonic works, like symphonic prelude, symphonic variation, symphonic toccata, and symphonic rhapsodies.These include Eliseo Pajaro’sVariations and Fugue, 1959; Antonino Buenaventura’sVariations and Fugue on a Mountain Folk Tune, 1972; Francisco F. Feliciano’s Prelude and Toccata, 1973, Variations uber ein Gestalt, 1977, and Prelude and Toccata, 1980; Angel M. Peña’sIgorotRhapsody, 1959, and Symphonic Variations on Two Manobo Themes, 1983;and Lucio D. San Pedro’sIlocano Fantasy and Visayan Fantasy, 1984.

A second group of nonconventional symphonic works is characterized by its use of extended performance media (voice plus orchestra) and includes Pajaro’sOde to the Golden Jubilee, 1958,for soloist, narrator, chorus, and orchestra and Man and Theater, 1963, for baritone, special chorus, and orchestra; Jose M. Maceda’s Pagsamba (Worship), 1968, for 116 instrumentalists, 100 voices, chorus of 25 men; Felipe Padilla M. de Leon’s Awit ng Buhay(Song of Life), 1969, a symphonic drama for baritone, narrator, and orchestra; Bayani M. de Leon’s Revelations, 1982, for even mantric sound-grids for orchestra; Francisco Feliciano’sThe Transfiguration of Jesus Christ, 1983, for chorus, orchestra, and narrator; Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s Rizal,the Great Malayan Antagonist: A Symphonic Drama, 1990; Chino Toledo’s Sandaang Tagpi-Tagpi (A Hundred Patchworks), 1998, for chorus, gongs, and orchestra; and Ramon Santos’s Nagnit, Igak, G’nan, Wagnwag Nila (Alingawngaw ng Kagitingan), 1997, for seven choruses, four orchestral groups, and audience; and UP Dangal ng Karunungan, Dangal ng Bayan (UP Seat of Wisdom, Pride of the Motherland), 2008, for tenor, soprano, speech choir, chorus, orchestra, and gamelan.

Works in the third group are characterized specifically by the use of Philippine indigenous instruments. This group was exemplified by early examples of Lucrecia Kasilag’s compositions, such as Legend of the Sarimanok, 1963, for orchestra and indigenous instruments, and Dularawan (Golden Salakot), 1969, for mixed chorus and indigenous instruments. In a different idiom, but “symphonic” in treatment for it utilized varied tone colors, was Jose M. Maceda’s avant-garde compositions, like Ugma-ugma, 1963; Agungan, 1965; and Aroding, 1983. Maceda’s new music was passed on to Ramon Santos who wrote L’bad, 1995, for kwintangan, three agung, gandang, and orchestra. The title of the piece, which was abstract, was derived from the word lebad, the smallest musical unit that is constantly repeated, altered, and juxtaposed with other units in the piece.

The last group no longer belongs to symphonic literature per se, but is included because the works constituted contemporary integrative art musics. These include Chino Toledo’s Terminal Lamentation, 1982, musical graphics for voice and percussion, and Kulambo: Isang Kayumangging Puntod, 1986, for chorus and orchestra; Laverne de la Peña’s Quadratos, 1981, for three dancers and flute, and Si Suan, Si Suan, 1983, for solo singer/puppeteer/actress; Christine Muyco’s Ginun-ag, 2013, for computer music, solo dance, and voice; Ilig-Duta, 2006 (Flow of the Earth) for large orchestra, bamboos, and gongs; Jonas Baes’s Lisan–Leaving (Sound Film on the Plight of the Iraya-Mangyan), 2007, for solo singer/puppeteer/actress; and Ramon Santos’s Awit, 1983, a multimedia piece for three guitars, vocalists, percussion, dancers, and Daragang Magayon: An Istorya ni Magayon (Daragang Magayon: The Story of Magayon), 2013, a full-length ballet with animation, videos, lights, rondalla, percussion, piano, chorus, soloists, and narrator.Written by Mauricia D. Borromeo, w ith additional notes from Arwin Q. Tan

text:
In its original meaning, the villancico is a Spanish musico-poetic song form consisting of coplas (stanzas) linked by an estribillo (refrain). The term was taken from the word “villano” (rustic) and, though simple in music texture, it was cultivated into a complex secular polyphonic music during the late 15th century and the 16th century. Beginning the 17th century, texture became simple again or monophonic, and the use of devotional and religious themes gained importance. From its secular constitution, villancicos (also referred to as letra or tono) became a genre of monophonic sacred songs with popular elements that were sung in Spanish or in the vernacular. It was this style that was heard in church services in Spain and its colonies, particularly during liturgical feast days such as Christmas, Ascension, Epiphany, and Corpus Christi. There was a rapid decline in its popularity from the 18th to the 19th century, but it continued to be widely cultivated in Latin America and in the Philippines. Although religious in function, the villancico continued to exhibit predominant secular and popular elements. Due to its extensive utilization during Christmas, by the mid-19th century, the term villancico was used to refer to Christmas songs. Since then, this has been the generally accepted meaning of the term.

The earliest existing music source of villancicos in the Philippines probably dates from the second half of the 17th century. This source has been preserved in the Dominican church of San Juan del Monte, and one in the collection stands out because it is in the vernacular, titled “Letra en Tagalo[g]” (Lyrics in Tagalog). This source was followed by another set, probably composed in the 18th century, found in the five-volume anthology of sacred music Manual-Cantoral de Santa Clara published in the early 1870s. Included in volume 4 of a multivolume anthology was a set of four villancicos al santisimo (songs to the Most Holy) performed during the feast of the Corpus Christi, a villancico al santisimo for Holy Thursday, and a set of four villancicos for Christmas—namely, “El Rey de los Cielos” (The King of Heaven), “Ea Pastores” (Come, Shepherds), “O Grande Mysterio” (Grand Mystery), and “Venid Gentes Todas” (Come All Peoples).

Villancicos became songs for Mass Proper (entrance, offertory, communion, and so on) in the Misa de Aguinaldo (nine-day dawn Masses), which starts on 16 Dec to honor the Virgin. It is also sung in the Misa de Gallo (midnight Mass) on Christmas Eve, together with the Mass Ordinary (Kyrie, Gloria, Credo, and so on)—that is, the Misa Pastorela. There are historical accounts that mention of Spanish friar musicians assigned in the Philippines who composed villancicos. Among them were Fray Lorenzo Castello (1686-1743), an Augustinian from Valencia, Spain, assigned to the San Agustin Church in Intramuros, Manila, who composed two volumes of villancicos as well as arias, and Juan Bolivar (1708-54), an Augustinian friar renowned for his exquisite singing ability who was known to have composed polyphonic villancicos and settings of the Gloria and Credo in the 18th century.

Because of the genre’s widespread usage through the annual Christmas season for over three hundred years, traditional Spanish villancicos are quite popular across the islands. The “Pastores a Belen” (Shepherds at the Nativity) and “Nacio Nacio Pastores: Villancicos de Navidad” (Rise, Rise Shepherds: Songs of the Nativity) are popular among the populace, even until now. These compositions are included in the Department of Tourism publication titled Villancicos: Mga Awiting Pamasko (Villancicos: Christmas Hymns), 1971, compiled and edited by Rosalina Abejo, RVM, 1922-91.

Aside from the villancico performed during the Christmas Masses, villancico was also practiced in related cultural devotional practices, such as the pastores, the panunuluyan in Tagalog-speaking areas, and the suroy in Bohol, which are all extra-liturgical folk Christmas traditions. The Bicol pastores is a musical reenactment of the nativity story where singers, wearing colorful costumes accompanied by musikeros (musicians), dance and sing to the villancico tune “Pastores a Belen.” The panunuluyan is a Philippine Christmas dramatization done through song of Joseph and Mary’s search for lodging on the night of Jesus’s birth. This could have originated from the Mexican nine-day posadas, but the panunuluyan is done only for a day. Lastly, suroy in Bohol means “to go around.” It is a unique tradition of caroling in the town of Loboc held for a total of 40 days. It starts on 24 Dec and culminates on 2 Feb. This is participated in by cantores and cantoras (male and female singers, respectively), and band musicians, as well as children. They go to different barangays every day to give Christmas cheer through the singing of villancicos and other songs. Vernacular villancicos, such as the daygon (Visayan Christmas songs), are strong evidence that the villancico tradition has been significantly entrenched in the social life of the people.

The villancico also paved the way for musicians in the islands to compose in the genre. Remigio Calahorra (1833-90), a Spanish peninsular professor of the Colegio de Niños Tiples of the Manila Cathedral, wrote a villancico that has survived and is now part of the archive collection of the UST Benavides Library. Although rhythm and meter are not the distinguishing features of the genre as seen in the 17th and 18th century examples, composed villancicos in the Philippines beginning in the 19th century utilized rhythmic patterns that are a distinctive feature of Misa Pastorela music. Composed villancicos from this period also manifest the use of insistent dotted rhythmic patterns in 6/8 time, as evident in the Calahorra villancico. Other trained Filipino musicians followed suit. Marcelo Adonay (1848-1928), considered the most prominent Filipino church musician of the late 19th century, elaborately composed a villancico titled “A Belen Pastores,” complete with orchestral accompaniment.

By the turn of the 20th century, Filipino musicians trained in the conservatory composed in the genre. By this time, the genre was already codified with the following musical style characteristics: (1) a predilection in the use of 6/8 meter and occasional use of duple meter, (2) extensive use of the distinguishing dotted eighth notes and pastorela rhythm, (3) employment of tra la la la syllables, and (4) utilization of the two-part song form (copla and estribillo). Francisco Santiago (1889-1947) wrote “Philippine Christmas Carol,” a medley of Christmas songs that exhibits the said villancico characteristics. Another composition titled “Gloria de Dios (Villancico Filipino)” (Glory of God) by Antonio Molina (1894-1980), found in the Filipiniana collection of the University of the Philippines Music Library, demonstrates an attempt to recognize the villancico as an appropriated Filipino tradition. The music exhibits clear villancico stylistic features, with text adapted from Henry Wadsworth Longfellow’s famous poem “Christmas Bells.” Tagalog, Spanish, and English lyrics were incorporated into the notated music. Another noted composer of the Filipino villancico is Felipe de Leon Sr (1912-92), who wrote “Payapang Daigdig” (Peaceful World). This piece is unusual because it is a solemn and melancholic Christmas carol. It was the arrangement of Lucio San Pedro (who deliberately omitted the second part) that changed its tone—a closer scrutiny of the original composition, particularly of the second part, shows that de Leon did utilize the distinguishing Filipino villancico rhythm. De Leon also composed “Noche Buena” (Christmas Eve Feast) and “Pasko na Naman” (It’s Christmas Once Again). In the anthology of villancico she herself edited, Rosalina Abejo composed a piece titled “Villancico Filipino.” Lucio San Pedro’s most important contribution in this genre was making good choir arrangements of Filipino-composed villancicos. He arranged “Diwa ng Ating Pasko” (Our Christmas Spirit) by Ramon Tapales and did a Christmas medley titled “Mga Awiting Pasko” (Christmas Hymns), which culminates in the original Cebuano but has been translated to Tagalog and is more popularly known as “Ang Pasko Ay Sumapit” (Christmas Has Come).Written by Maria Alexandra Iñigo-Chua
